description:
I'm not a "reviewer" person but this place made a good exception. Seen this place for a while, and finally yesterday night my friends and I decided to try it. 

Service was Excellent!!! Even though the place was packed, they were just perfect. Food in general was good, I ordered steak frites and they came a little undercooked, the server noticed my disappointed face and  took it back to the kitchen. She came back minutes later with a way better steak. Highly recommended if you are looking for high quality service and good food.
author: Leonam Max A.

description:
Definitely underrated. This place is chic, food is delicious, and service is unparalleled. We went for brunch on a Sunday morning. There was no wait but the place is not empty either. My boyfriend got the salmon Benedict and I got their omelet, both of which are really good. 

I wanted fresh juice and ordered the grapefruit juice. After I got the grapefruit juice, the waitresses brought me another glass of orange juice for free, since the grapefruit juice is not freshly squeezed today (it usually is). Just really great attitude overall. 

This place is super pet friendly. It's located close to SPCA, and lots of pet owners bring their dogs over. The waiters even brought the dogs water bowl to their tables so they keep hydrated. I would definitely come back here in the future.i
author: Jessie L.

description:
Such a gem! Prices are typical of bistro French, but the "flamenkuche" or "tarte flambait" (as I encountered it in Alsace) is cheap and a light lunch. I've had it several times. Their version has thinly sliced  apples or pears under the caramel used onions. I usually get it with a salad, which makes it a not so cheap but satisfying lunch. The smoked trout salad is excellent. I've always gotten plenty of fish on it. Had the butter lettuce salad today which had a champagne shallot dressing. The dressing wasn't equally distributed when it was tossed but oh well. 

They have a smallish wine list but they also have a limited edition wine list which I choose from. That one gives more of a blurb for each wine and encourages you to branch out. I rarely order Cabernet Sauvignon in restaurants. It's never a good deal. They have a Beaujolais right now that's really good. I like gamay and Cabernet franc a lot -- good value for high quality. 

Beer drinkers take note: they have Duvel on tap!!!!!!  I've never seen that before. 

I've also had a lamb navarin here when the spring vegetables are available. It was one of the best balanced dishes I've had. Truly memorable. 

Don't pass on desert. The floating island is very well done here. 

And the sidewalk seating is some of the best in San Francisco. Clean, quiet neighborhood and not next to a bus stop.
author: Tim P.

description: Disappointing. We waited 10 minutes after sitting for someone to acknowledge us. Another 15 minutes before we got bread. Then another 35 minutes until our food came. The Benedict was mediocre and the poached eggs were overcooked as per the attached image. The potatoes were seasoned well but barely warm with no crisp. The orange juice was spectacular.
author: Sheperd A.

description:
Nice local bistro serving French food. Came with friends who didn't want to eat the greasy food truck type food being served at the annual Fillmore Jazz Festival. We had meandered up Fillmore and Hubby found this place which BBF and her hubby agreed to.  Her hubby is a picky eater even though he denies it.  
I decided to eat light and had their frisée salad. It came with a poached egg and lots of bacon bits. The dressing was very good. But it wasn't a huge amount for $15. Hubby had the hamburger with fries. I thought the fries were good. 
The other BBFs had a spinach omelet, eggs Benedict, Florentine Benedict. 
Service was good as well as the complimentary basket of French bread with unsalted butter.
author: Ry T.

description:
I came here with my European grandmother who can tend toward persnickety. It met all of her qualifications for "a nice place" so phew. The en plein air seating is lovely on a nice day, the inside has a pretty typical cute French cafe feel.

The food was totally fine. Nothing special. Nothing horrible. I had the poulet roti with frites. The chicken was a bit dry, but spiced nicely. The salad was nice. And the fries were fine. 

All in all, you can definitely get better food elsewhere, but if you want a nice atmosphere, it's a great choice.
author: Megan B.

description: Came here for dinner on a Sunday night. We started with a kir royal which is one of my favorite drinks. We sat lazily on the sidewalk sipping our drinks and enjoying the sun. The staff was friendly but not smothering. We then had dinner, splitting the muscles to start. The muscles were a fantastic garlicky dream. I sopped up all the broth with bread because I couldn't let an ounce go. We then shared the steak frites. The steak was tiny, seriously about 6 bites. That was disappointing and the reason I cant give this place 4 stars.The meat was good but not good enough for 30 dollar steak gone in 6 bites. The fries were very skinny and perfectly crisp. I really enjoyed them. All in all this place is high average level food for a larger than value price tag.
author: Anne S.

description:
The best part of this restaurant is the Fillmore Street location and that you can get in without a reservation or have much of a wait for Saturday brunch. 

The brunch menu is mostly egg/omelette, salads, small plates and a few entrees. Service is good but the food is rather pedestrian. The salad nicoise (ahi tuna) and the poached egg salads are so bland and tasteless, I swear I can do better with some greens and a bottle of salad dressing off the supermarket shelf. The omelette is not fluffy at all but the potatoes were quite good. Prices are average but so is the food.
author: Eleanor C.

description: Nice little bistro next to Fillmore St. I had the Niçoise salad and some bread. Both were great: service was friendly, by both a French waiter and waitress. They tolerated everyone using their French skills on them  nice awning, street side dining. And the Rose was very pleasant. Took me back to Paris for a few minutes!
author: Julie N.

description:
Came here with my friends for holiday gathering on Dec 23. Everything is great. Service was amazing. We got seated in no time.  And the server is very pleasant with our nonstop request for bread.
We ordered 3 bottles of wine (1 white and 2 red). They are all good especially the red Georgo's that was recommended to us.  
Food was amazing but was a little disappointed with the shell less escargots.  We ordered 3 appetizers: escargots, mussels with fries and foie gras pate. Lamb and duck confit for entrees. Both dishes are very tasty.

This place is great and we will definitely be back.
author: Brenda W.

description:
The vibe here was super cute, with big windows facing onto the street, but unfortunately the food was disappointing. The pasta was flavorless and nothing else was particularly exciting. 

Service was not great either. One of our dishes smelled and tasted funny, so we left it untouched. After the waitress noticed, she came by and took it back, but left the charge on our bill. A bit disappointing considering we didn't get a dish to replace it. Overall, we were not thrilled.
author: Nicole D.

description: We were out to have a quiet dinner on a Saturday night.  The place we had in mind was closed for a private party.  We saw this restaurant and wandered in.  It was by far the best meal and nicest service, in a long time!  I am still dreaming about it - after two weeks!  We had really good glasses of Pinot to start and each had the steak frites.  Creme brûlée for dessert.  It truly was worth every penny.  The staff was so attentive and the cozy place was warm and just the right amount of chatter.  I'll be back...
author: wendy j.

description:
UPDATE (1.20.18 w my 11 month old English setter):  loving my neighborhood bistros all the more because they've put up a warm and beautiful patio tent AND they've hired the nicest wait staff ever! In addition to Mark and Pamela, we now have happy people conversing and happily serving amazing dishes!! We love Chouquet's alllllll the more!!! 
And all of this makes the food taste even better - which seemed impossible


LOVE this amazing French joint in my neighborhood. I've loved them for their food and ambiance for years. As of 11 weeks ago, I got an English Setter puppy and since we walk by this darling gem every day, we stop into the beautiful patio seating and eat! Mark, Israel, the awesome owner and pamename) treat us like the princesses of Pac Hts! It's lovely and endearing. Also, we've met SO many other dog lovers (with or without their dogs) and it's become a social haven for me and Kennedy. I cannot say enough about Chouquet...you must try it. The patio and interior remind me of Nello (except FRENCH!) on Madison Ave during my days living in Manhattan ...
author: Whitney H.

description: Chouquet's is definitely IRA rated - excellent lunch. Everything was delicious from the authentic French onion soup, salmon in an amazing sauce, organic vegeys through the fabulous deserts and bread and French butter. It's a wow and Mark and staff did a great job serving and paying attention to our needs.
author: Ira M.

description:
The place is definitely under rated... gret space, amazing service and the food is legitimately French.

I will cone back
author: Gabriel F.

description:
If I could give this restaurant 10 stars, I would! 

Ordered: French onion soup, tuna tar tar, and filet mignon

Good: Everything I ordered was flavorful and delicious. The onion soup was traditional and not too thick or watery. The tuna tar tar is more similar to Hawaiian Poke and came with thin taro chips that were perfectly paired. The filet laid upon a bed of potatoes gratin and mushrooms.

Bad: Nothing

Service: Exceptional! The servers were attentive and accommodating.
author: Patricia I.

description: Oysters fresh / salads fabulous / Rose crisp and service was French as it should be... I'll be back. Great quiet neighborhood spot w/ indoor & outdoor seating. Outdoor seating receives pretty spectacular late afternoon & evening sun.
author: Matt T.

description:
Spent a memorable evening tonight at Chouquet's with two people who mean a lot to me. The service, food, and ambiance were absolutely perfect. I don't mean that in a Michelin star kind of way, but rather in what truly matters. Great friends, food, and wine in a convivial environment is what makes an evening special. 

The service was prompt, accurate, and most importantly, absolutely thoughtful. The food was delicious. And we received excellent, personable, friendly guidance from our amazing server. Their wine list is absolutely excellent. Massive kudos to Mark for creating a noteworthy wine list... even by San Francisco standards. 

My lovely friend who suggested we dine at Chouquet's is a nearly lifelong "regular" (throughout the various incantations the location has had over the decades) and I'm grateful to have shared the experience.

I have a hunch that we'll soon be booking the place in the not-too-distant future for an "announcement-type" party. It's THAT special.
author: Jack D.

description:
Delightful neighborhood Jem. My daughter and I had the halibut and salmon. The fish was extremely fresh and the accoutrements were distinctively French and well done. My only regret is that I waited far to long to try this charming spot. 
Mark, our server, popped over with three little surprises for my Little which kept her busy. Even her cup had a hand drawn picture of her with her name on it. Well done Chouquet's!
author: T W.

description: A great french restaurant that is very inviting. Staff was super kind and it is animal friendly. Everyone (staff + customers) seemed like they were having a great time. If you are looking for a quick and delicious bite in Pacific Heights and a step away from all the tourists go here.
author: Jack Y.

description: Solid 4 stars came during restaurant week and the food was pretty good,the French onion soup was spot on not to salty..steak frites are pretty standard but my dates French style beef stew was good,definitely a date night atmosphere
author: jonathan h.

description: Great experience here, staff was friendly and food was YUM. We got the quiche, omelette and bloody Mary's and all was delicious
author: Ellen G.

description:
My husband and I went here for brunch yesterday and we were just confused. The manager(??) and a server were behind the breakfast bar chatting and drinking coffee while my husband and I were sitting in front of them at a table with zero acknowledgment. They were complaining about how they lost two reservations because of the new POS, but we were ready to walk out and we were sitting right in front of them. When we finally got the woman's attention, the service was curt, inattentive, and impersonal. She seemed annoyed to have to take our orders. 

There was one gentleman busting his tail serving at the tables outside, so those patrons may have had a different experience!
author: Julie C.

description: Quite good!!! Oysters, butter lettuce salad, roasted chicken and butternut squash tab on the table... outside on a lovely Fall day. Lemon tart a happy splurge. French folks dining next to us. We'll be back!
author: Spunky M.

description: Great oysters, great food, and excellent service. Sat on the patio with our dog and had a lovely brunch. So dog friendly, too - our server kept bringing our dog treats!
author: Brooke L.

description:
I am so surprised this place doesn't have more stars than it does! 

I absolutely loved this restaurant. We came here last night and had a three course meal that was to die for. For starters, we had duck frois gras, and for our mains we had the burger and the chicken with black truffle sauce. For dessert, we had the chocolate fondue. Everything was so amazing, even the wine selection chosen by the waitress was perfect. We're going to make this our local Friday night dinner spot. 

I am French, and have lived in many different countries and eaten at various restaurants around the world, and I'm confident in saying that this restaurant is truly authentically French. Every bite reminds me of my childhood!
author: Marina D.

description:
I read the reviews of Choquet's & was wondering if I was taking a huge chance.  But as it turned out we had nothing to worry about.

This is a nice place for a casual meal, and that's what we had today.  The location is on a busy corner of Pacific Heights on Fillmore St.  So there is always alot of things to view while awaiting one's meal(s).  Loads of dogs taking walks with their human friends too.

The food was very good and tasty.  We ordered the onion soup, steak frites, and quiche ending with creme brulee and espresso.  Wine list has something for everyone.  And the service was friendly and welcoming, timely too.

But I must say that maybe it's the location as well that makes the prices quite expensive for the portions.  I'll liken the portions to snack size more than meal size as the prices are (at least to me) quite steep for what one receives.

I would not hesitate to return though as overall otherwise it was a hit to us.
author: Luisa T.

description: This is a great place for brunch on the weekends, especially if you have a dog or kids or even a large group. I went with a large group and the derive was fast and thoughtful. Parking is difficult in this area, there is street metered parking. The food was fantastic, I had the special Crab Benedict and I loved it.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
Awesome brunch here! Walking down Fillmore with my best brunch companion after urban hiking and stumbled on this place. 

Very cute inside and has outside seating. Outside table was 45 min wait so we opted for sitting inside. Beautiful space!

We ordered two jardin omelettes and they were really fresh and light. Came with roasted potatoes and green salad. Great service too! Food was pretty under seasoned though--I had to add quite a bit of salt and pepper to the omelette. The restaurant was also REALLY loud-when we arrived it was fine but then it filled up and I could barely hear the person sitting next to me.

Really want to come back and try more dishes!
author: Semuteh F.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant for brunch or dinner. I live across the street and This place is ALWAYS busy for lunch/brunch. Came here for Sunday brunch- I had to finally try it for myself. Had the croque madame (super crisp/delicious) and the burger (perfectly seasoned). I loved the fries!! Servers were also very attentive :) we will be back!
author: Daeun J.

description: Looking for a great spot to lunch in Pacific Heights?! Well... This is it! Quaint ambiance, intimate setting and best of all the food and service.  Steak Frites is a must a this place.  The entire staff was courteous and kind.
author: Brenda Z.

description:
Food tasted OK but the entire experience was a reminder of what happens when greedy owners take shortcuts for short term profits. 

The orange juice was from concentrate, so cheap that they wouldn't even serve it at San Quentin. 

If I had known my $30 steak would have been 4oz of meat and $20 worth of fries I would have gone to another lunch spot from the myriad of other good proven choices on Fillmore. Guess it turns out there's a reason why they didn't put the weight of the steak on the menu. If they had, no one in their right mind would have been willing to expose themselves to such financial molestation. 

There's a reason why the average yelp review is so poor, if only I had read it before going though!
author: William M.

description:
I waked in at 6pm on a Tuesday evening. It was pretty slow with only three tables of customers. The waitress, who was with a coworker looking at pictures on his cell phone, looked up with a smile and told me I could sit anywhere.

I sat myself near the entrance and, for the next ten minutes, watched the waitress and her coworker as they ignored me and continued looking at photos.

I didn't even get a menu and finally left.

This the my first and last time I go here.
author: Tuan V.

description:
Fantastic small neighborhood cafe
With great food and a wonderful staff of help
Get there early for weekend brunch
author: Gary M.

description:
I had dined at Chouquet's 20 years ago and it lacked decent food, poor service, and a less than a polite staff.

Last Sunday we went there for brunch.  We waited at our outside table with no acknowledgment for 
15min.  We tried to get servers attention to no avail.
Finally a female server took our order.  Another 
20 min. Went by and some server brought us the wrong food.  Another 10min. go by and we get our omelette over cooked with what the restaurant called "with salad" which was 4 pieces of mixed greens drenched in some dressing.  Oh yeah, our coffee came after we were served the eggs.
I told our server I had been here 20 years ago.  And she told me it was bought some years back and had new ownership.  I told her the placed still sucked and she asked me why.  I told her and she thought I was joking.  When she realized I wasn't, she said, " will that be cash or credit on your bill?"

This place wasn't busy for a Sunday brunch.  They are lucky there is minimal nearby competition.  If this is 20 years later, it reminds me of Groundhog Day.  Kinda scary if one thinks about it

This place absolutely positively sucks!
author: Nicholas F.

description:
Don't waste your time and money coming here.

Reading the past reviews...one said a mouse or rat was found in the soup in 2015 and the place had to be shut down.

Croque monsieur - seriously, what a joke!  The width was the same as my samsung phone and that includes the extremely thin slither of ham and cheese...I needed a magnifier to find the béchamel sauce. $14 + tax + tip

Salad that accompany's it - wow, pathetic.  Blah.  The waiter spilled a 1/3 of it and didn't even offer to replace.

My friend had the mussels with fries - under-seasoned blah sauce for the mussels, and they were minuscule. 

French fries - wow, it's hard to screw up french fries, but they managed it.
Absolutely the worst fries we have ever had, not even fries really...most were an inch in length (dregs of the frier I imagine), dry, and old rotten potatoes were used!!!

Restaurant - Untidy restaurant. Dirty bathroom with water all over the floor, tissues everywhere, disgusting sink, no soap...awful!  I had to point out that the bathroom was filthy before they even bothered to clean it.

Service - Reasonably quick.  Somewhat sour attitude.  Didn't even followup after serving the food.  Salad spilled all over the laptop table floor, and didn't replace or offer to clean up with a wet cloth.

Price - definitely overpriced for what you get.

This place has an arrogant attitude. Clearly don't value or respect their customer.

1 star for location.
author: blink v.

description:
I initially came here because of San Francisco Restaurant Week (SFRW), but because I didn't really check that they only served brunch on weekends, I wasn't able to do the SFRW with my friend as planned. However that was my fault and we were already there, so we decided to stay there to eat anyways.  But right when we arrived, I was already not receiving great service already because they had a sign in sheet at the front of the restaurant where you write the amount of people in your group and your name to be called, yet after 15 minutes of waiting for them to call someone's name, there was another group of customers that showed up and talked to the waitress and got seated immediately. That was when we realized that they weren't even utilizing the sign in sheet that they had outside by the front, and I honestly wish they had said something since we were standing right at the front of the restaurant. In the end we talked to the waitress, and got seated immediately as well. 
We didn't realize that this was only the start of a long waiting game here. After being seated, we waited about 10 minutes before menus were given to us -- and then the servers never once came back to check on us to see if we're ready to order or wanted something to drink. After about 15 minutes of waiting and the waitress repeatedly dropping by to check on the table next to us and not even acknowledging us or looking at us, we spent the next 10 minutes trying to get their attention so that we can order our food. After ordering, suddenly a waiter appeared and asked us if we would like to have some complimentary bread and butter (something that the waitress also neglected to ask us about despite asking the table next to us about it -- I wonder why that is). The food came relatively quickly afterwards, and to be honest, it was good but it was also very similar to many other places that serves brunch. Then, once again, it was another 20 minutes of us desperately trying to get the waitress' attention so that we can get our check and leave because we were never checked on even though it was very obvious that we have been done with our meal for a while since our plates were already empty.

I really think that if we had the same service as the table next to ours, then I would definitely love to come back to this place. Yet we were neglected for most our time there, which made our experience slightly frustrating because we couldn't even get our own server's attention. To make matters worst, it wasn't even like the restaurant was full and packed that day. Better off going to a different place for brunch.
author: Elaine H.

description: Ordered Moules Mariniere (Mussels and Fries) for delivery and when it arrived there were no fries.   On top of that mussels were not meaty at all.  If you cant get good mussels please take the dish off your menu.  Poor quality food just makes your restaurant look bad.
author: Victor S.

description:
The bf and I came here for Sunday brunch because there was no wait. 

We should have ordered more of their traditional French food but instead ordered an omelette that was kinda bland. The croque Monsieur however was delicious.
author: Daniela J.

description:
In a nutshell, mediocre. 

I ordered the cheese plate, which was wildly overpriced at $14 for what it contained, that is, a trio of small wedges of entirely unremarkable cheese (the blue cheese was especially mundane and a good chunk was left uneaten), a quarter of an apple sliced thinly and a meager portion of bread that was sliced thinly as well, so much so that although it was served warm and wrapped in a napkin, dried out almost immediately and cooled off just as quickly. If croutons/stale bread are your thing, you might like the texture. Not me. 

I can quite honestly say that it was the most mediocre cheese plate I've ever received at any restaurant in my life. If you go here, don't order it unless you want a disappointing experience. 

They cheaped out on the cheese that they used, but it would be an insult to Costco or Trader Joe's to suggest that Choquet's is sourcing their cheese from either location. Maybe they buy up stale cheeses past the "sell by" date at bottom barrel prices from who knows where? Grocery Outlet? A strong accusation but that's how their cheese *tasted* to me.

They also provide free bread and butter in the form of generic supermarket quality baguette slices and equally generic butter (but kudos I suppose, that the butter was served soft and warm, not cold). 

Two stars only because the service was okay (though it took them awhile to bring out the cheese plate) and the outdoor seating was pleasant. My friend received her tuna poke dish more promptly. But I gotta say, poke's not French! One star for the food.
author: Maya B.

description: We tried this during the restaurant week for a Sunday brunch. For $25 I had cauliflower soup, salmon and chocolate lava cake. We also ordered flatbread, burger and strawberry layered cake. Everything was simply delicious! Their drinks are ok, nothing great. The Kir Royal is refreshing. We would love to come back soon.
author: Sridevi K.

description: I wanted to love--or at least like--this place, but not to be. We popped in for a late lunch, and ordered an ahi tuna nicoise salad and a burger with french fries. The nicoise had all the requisite ingredients: green beans, greens, with hard-boiled egg and boiled potatoes, green and black olives, cherry tomatoes. It came sprinkled with with their mustard based house vinaigrette. The burger was on a sesame seed bun, pickles, and the like. The salad, though I tried to gussy it up with extra dressing, was insipid and had no oomph, no pizazz, no sparkle. It was worth eating only for the nutrition. The tuna, mercifully, was fresh and grilled well, tender in the middle, and the fresh anchovies were beautiful, added just the perfect amount of flavor to the mix. The dressing was as bland and unassuming as any I've had. The burger was inedible, dry and not a bit moist, no flavor from the meat or the bun. The fries were terrific, excellent crunch to soft centers. Maybe it was our fault for ordering the meat well-done--except that we usually get it that way, and many places manage to preserve the juices. This was like chewing on a block of sawdust. We did not eat it. The service was fantastic--warm and friendly, prompt, from everyone from the busboy to the hostess and server. They split our plates, smiling and sweet. Such a shame that the food sucked, because the service couldn't be better, which is why I'm giving it a higher rating than I otherwise would. The ambience is everything you'd expect from a small French bistro--polished wood tables with cloth napkins, small and intimate space, restrooms to the rear. I appreciated that there was no blaring music. Quiet and dignified, with the option to sit outside on a sunny day. People also brought their dogs for the patio, where they seemed set up precisely for this. Also, weekday chalkboard specials. If I lived in this neighborhood, I can see myself coming here for a quick bite or taking stuff home--but I'd have to specify the food more precisely to my taste--or bring my own salad dressing--lol :-)
author: Ranjan P.

description:
We had some real good time here, too bad the food was not as enjoyable as the discussion we had with the manager of the store!! :)

What we liked:
- This French bistro ambiance that reminded us of the south of France!
- Excellent service and very nice waiters !! We also really enjoyed the great and fun discussion we had with the manager Robert!  Really nice guy :)
- The seating area: Indoor and outdoor heated area, sweet and cosy in the current San Franciscan winterish weather.

What needs improvement:
- The FOOD!!!! (Did I say it loud enough ?! ;). Really , for a French Bistro, we were disappointed by the food quality and taste. Let me explain more:
     * The bread and butter: tasteless
     * The ice tea: I tasted water rather than ice tea
     * The steak & frittes: great steak sauce (au poivre), though the steak meat was not. The French fries were ok (cold thought)


I really hope this restaurant can revamp its "cuisine"... and start offering spirits like the Pastis.
author: Gilbert B.

description: Excellent food, great ambience and wonderful service - a true neighborhood gem ..
author: DJ J.

description: Fast and polite service! I ordered the omelette and a peach Bellini and both were good!
author: Tori M.

description: We really like this restaurant for brunch. We made a reservation for 10am today, 6 adults and a baby, outside table. Service was great. Omelettes and gazpacho were delicious. No long wait.
author: Sebastian G.

description: This is a great spot for a warm sunny afternoon. Sit at the patio for a while and enjoy the iced cocktails. I'm not a salad person but the waiter highly recommended the salmon salad. It turned out to be one of the best salads I've ever ordered.
author: M M.

description:
I don't understand why this restaurant has such a low rating given the great quality of food and fast service. The omelettes are excellent, which also took about five minutes to arrive after we placed our orders. 

I'm hoping that this continues to be a hidden brunch gem because the wait time on a Sunday was non existent.
author: Greg M.

description:
No wait during prime time weekend brunch hours -- should've taken this as a red flag, but we were in a rush and had limited options!

I had the smoked salmon benedict, and asked for the hollandaise on the side. It was super thick and the benedict itself wasn't anything special. The eggs were overcooked and I didn't get the beautiful oozy yolk that I love about benedicts! The salad that it came with was also pretty bare bones.

My sister had an omelette with potatoes, and said everything was bland bland bland.

Fancy name for a disappointing meal :(
author: Kathy L.

description:
There's probably something to be said for a spot when there are nearby brunch spots with lines topping two hours and a place like Chouquet's finds itself with a wait to speak of. I risked, it, but my intuition came back to bite me a bit and my brunch experience wasn't much to write home about. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

The service and atmosphere at Chouquet's a fine, but it's nothing special. Be advised that the outdoor seating can approach sweltering temps when the actual outdoor temp is anything about 80, but that's offset by friendly and fast service in addition to the fact that you probably won't have many of those days anyway. All in all nothing to complain about. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

For the most part, Chouquet's brunch in particular is priced fairly, with standard dishes like eggs benedict and various omelettes somewhere between $12 and $15. I instead opted for the Steak Frite, which was a hefty portion but came with a pretty hefty price tag amounting to $25 for the dish. That's a bit high, but again that's unique to what I ordered versus the status quo here at Chouquet's. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Like I alluded to early in the review, my dish, and the dishes of those in my party, were nothing special. My steak was fairly plain and a wee bit tough considering I essentially paid $25.00 for it, and the fries were actually the highlight of the dish (crispy on the outside soft and flavorful on the inside). My friends didn't seem blown away by their egg dishes either, and at the end of the day I can kind of see why there wasn't a line out front. No Stars Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

I've had much better brunches than what I experienced at Chouquet's, and they're going to need to up their game to compete with the spots that are racking up serious lines on weekend mornings. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: Cockroach!!! That pretty much says it all, we were having dinner and it crawled across the table, I trapped it in a glass and got one of the wait service people to remove it. I would not normally address this issue on yelp but the way this has been dealt with by the restaurant that night and the fact that I just phoned to deal with the matter personally and was told quite curtly that there was no-one I could speak to is the reason I am. That night there was no apology, nothing from the staff at hand to amend the situation, (actually I told them I should at least get a comped glass of wine) in all fairness I was calling today to see if perhaps an owner or manager would hear my issue, my curt response from the girl on the phone answered that.
author: Lorna S.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to chouquets (moved to a different neighborhood), but there I was finding myself strolling in Pacifica heights around lunch time and decided to pay a visit to them. 
The place hasn't changed much decoration-wise, except the new and colorful patio: love it. I could recognize some of the old staff (which to me is always a good sign if you see waiters sticking at a place for a very long time, usually means they are treated well and happy). 
Anyway, their trout salad is still there and amazing. 
Service is still attentive and pleasant and everything seemed clean and tidy. 

I should definitely find the time to come back more often...
author: Vincent N.

description:
This is a fantastic place for brunch on a sunny day in SF. No lines, no fuss. One could sit outside and sunbath while sipping a glass of mimosa. The food comes super fast. A little adorable french girl will bring out two glasses of water with hands barely big enough to hold the glasses. The waiters are super friendly and very responsive. Good coffee.

Smoked trout salad was delicious.  The fish is not too salty. The fingling potatoes were light. Great start to a weekend.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Go to French restaurant in the neighborhood and city-delicious. Brunch lunch and dinner are all great. Personal favorites are the croque monsieur (which is never too heavy) omelettes French toast modules frisee salad and onion soup.
author: J M.

description:
I was really hoping to love this place because I love French food, I've spent some time living in France, and I wanted desperately to find a go-to place for French food.  Unfortunately, the dishes we ordered reminded me of going over to your friend's house for a homemade dinner -- a dinner that was edible, but a little rough around the edges because your friend is just a home cook with a non-culinary day job, passionately cooking from recipes from a cookbook.  Nowhere near restaurant quality.  With $25 - 29 price tag for most of the meat/fowl entrees for dinner, I can't see myself dining there again.

First sign of trouble was the charcuterie board, with a ramekin of mousse de foie gras ($20).  The cured meats were fine.  But I will bet my first born that mousse was no foie gras!  Or it had so little foie gras mixed in relative to regular liver that it made no difference!  It was hard, dense, grainy and bland.  It was a bit better with some salt, and was tasty as just a liver pâté, so we finished it.  Either the chef was putting one over on people unfamiliar with real foie gras, or their supplier was putting one over on the chef, who is unfamiliar with real foie gras.  I'm not alone -- I checked the Yelp reviews after I came home to find that someone else had observed the foie gras mousse was grainy and bad. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/chouquets-san-francisco?hrid=9F4RAojlKTKcWSBkcN6-OQ)

The cassoulet ($25) and canard à l'orange ($29) did not save the experience.  The beans of the cassoulet were well-seasoned, but the meat and sausage inside the stew were totally bland.  The beans were so overdone that they totally fell apart and disintegrated with the slightest stir, and the stew took on the consistency of refried beans or dense mashed potatoes.  The confit in the stew had an exterior that was harder than jerky.  Neither of us could chew through it and had to spit it out.  

The canard à l'orange would have been fine except for the $29 price tag.  For that price, I expected at least the cook on the duck to be done expertly.  The main disappointments were the blandness and the uncrispy, unrendered, flabby skin.  After a liberal sprinkling of salt, the flavors of the orange-infused brown gravy were quite nice and I finished my serving.  Like I had mentioned, edible, but not going-out-to-eat special, not for $29 and with so many other restaurants around.

Since the duck and the pâté were all eaten, we didn't feel right commenting on it to the waiter, but we couldn't let the cassoulet go.  It was a struggle to eat it and we gave up after a few bites each.  We showed the waiter the half-eaten dish and the crusted-over meat, and he agreed to take it off our bill.  Otherwise this would be a one-star review.
author: Rhys C.

description: I come here for a basic breakfast fairly regularly and I like it. Nothing fancy but very reliable. The outdoor area is very nice (and quiet) and the staff is very sweet too.
author: Tilly D.

description: This appears to be a neighborhood place and it was packed on a rainy Sunday morning.  Tables are close together, so an intimate brunch was out, but there was a lively vibe.  Service was good.  I had French Toast, which I have to admit was only so-so, and my companion had an omelette which he says was excellent.  We enjoyed our meal and would definitely return.
author: Michael C.

description: Enjoy the good service and the comfy ambiance of this spot but skip the roasted chicken.  My entree was a very scrawny, small half chicken roasted to a dry and tasteless condition.  Served with an unimaginative mixed green salad that appeared to have been straight from a grocery store mix.  The mussels looked good...maybe next time.
author: Cal M.

description:
Came here with one of my friends for brunch. I had made reservations via OpenTable to eat here. She was coming from the South Bay and was running late with traffic. I called the restaurant and they said no problem. When we got there, the hostess/waiter looked grumpy and said "I waited for as long as I could and gave your table away." Really? you couldn't wait 20 minutes, especially when I am a long running VIP on OpenTable?? We had to wait another 15 minutes for a table open up, and it wasn't outside as I had requested. Double fail. 

On to the food and service. It took forever for our waiter to come back to take our order. Once it came, they forgot a few things, and I had to flag them down to get it a few times. Annoying. They also never came to check on us during the meal. The meal itself was okay, but nothing memorable. I then had to flag them down to get the check and again to pay. When we left we got no thank you or good bye? Really, is this what happens restaurants in Pacific Heights? Sad. 

Yelpers, don't waste your time here. Not worth. Go to the Grove instead. Peace.
author: Sonia A.

description: It was 2 PM, not crowded. My order took forever to arrive. the server (Adrien) was rude and sassy when I complained. I shall not return.
author: Abe B.

description:
Came here due to a restaurant.com certificate. I love french food and liked the selection online, so I decided to try it out. Most of the food was okay with some hits and a fair amount of misses. Our waiter was super nice and attentive.

The good:
$1 oysters! They were having a special and I love oysters so we ordered half a dozen. They were so good (super plump and creamy with a nice brininess) that we decided to order another half dozen!

The bad:
Ahi tuna appetizer - The salad that came with it was super salty while the ahi was underseasoned. Wtf?! I had to eat them together to get a decent bite, but eating each component separately was all bad!
The mousse appetizer - I don't even know how to explain how bad this was. You know that nice creamy flavorfulness that pates should have? This had none of that. It was almost like eating butter with a weird mealy gaminess to it. My mom, who can finish a whole 5oz jar of foie from bouchon couldn't even finish this tiny portion!
Salmon entree - We had asked that the salmon be on the rare side since I hate overcooked salmon, but it came out flaky, meaning super overcooked. The texture was just awful. None of the nice fatty slipperiness of the fish remained.

The rest of the dishes, I only recall as being okay. Nothing exceptional or bad about them. Honestly if I was just judging the food, I would give this place 2 stars. But I really liked our waiter so 3 stars overall!
author: Elena N.

description: I've been here a few times now for brunch and dinner and I've only had good experiences. The atmosphere is cozy and welcoming, the wait staff is helpful but not intrusive and the food is great! The omelettes and the newly added French toast are great options on a sunny Sunday morning.
author: Chris S.

description: This is my new "favorite restaurant ", one that reminds me of those little French bistros in France where the cook and the waitstaff intimately work, hand in hand to bring the most delectable morsels to a diners palate. Forgive that the restaurant floors is slanted at a certain angle in one section of the dining room and that you're practically rubbing elbows with your neighbors, that's called charm.  If you want great French food at a great price and from what I can tell, should be consistently good cooking, Chouquet's is the place to go!
author: Tony Y.

description: I had dinner here one evening with a friend and we shared our meal. We had a kale salad and the burger with pomme frits.....it was tasty for what it was. The atmosphere and neighborhood adds to the charm and curiosity for new dinners.
author: Stacie J.

description:
Was there yesterday. The creme brûlée was too "sticky and chewy" and the capuccino was cold and too dry.

I don't recommend this place, although the location is great !
author: dominique l.

description: Roxy was such a sweetheart. The food was really delicious and I had a glass of champagne to follow.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Chouquet's has been on my bookmark list for close to a year.  When Google had a $20 for $40 worth of food at Chouquet's, I jumped on the offer.  

RESERVATIONS:
I was able to make reservations on opentable.com for a party of three for Tuesday night.  Even though it was a bit on the empty side, I recommend making reservations since the place is on the smaller side.  Recently I noticed that reservations are available on Savored (take advantage of the 15-30% off your bill discount!).  There is both indoor and outdoor seating available.

SPECIALS:
Tuesdays - $1 oysters
Wednesday - no corkage fee

Note: Portions are on the smaller side.  The three of us ordered oysters, 3 appetizers, and 3 entrees and it worked out perfectly

APPETIZERS:
*Escargots de Bourgogne ($10) - The dish was okay.  Though the dish is nicely presented, creamy white sauce doesn't compliment escargots very well in my opinion.
*Kobe Beef Tartare ($15) - An appetizer must order!  The beef was extremely tender and had the perfect balance of tart to it.  Served with crispy crostinis. 

ENTREEES:
*Moules Marinieres ($18) - Delicious! This dish was the winner of the night.  Thin cut French fries are served on the side.  Though the mussels were on the smaller side, what really made the dish was the cream white wine sauce.  Make sure you use the bread to soak up the creamy sauce!
*Raviole aux Epinards ($18) - Pass.  Though the sauce was, there just wasn't enough of it.  The five pieces of spinach filled raviolis just didn't have enough flavor to it.
*Seared Dayboat Scallops with Black Risotto ($23) - Three large scallops are served on a bed of black risotto with a creamy vierge sauce.  The scallops were tasty, but the downfall of the dish was the risotto.  The only way the risotto had flavor to it was by using the sauce...and the risotto temperature wasn't even hot.   On the other hand, the accompanied asparagus were good. 

SERVICE:
Our waiter was nice and friendly.  He made a great wine recommendation and he didn't give us the wtf look (as we often get) when the three of us ordered 7 dishes.

PARKING:
We lucked out and found parking across the street, however it can be a bit difficult in this area.
author: Nicole S.

description:
I'm shocked at the favorable reviews I see.
Fact: my daughter ordered onion soup.
         After eating SEVERAL bites, she uncovered a mouse or a rat in her soup.
Fact: neither she or I could eat out again for about a month without feeling nauseous.
Fact: restaurant owner did call that evening to apologize.

We called the health department the next day.
They called us back six days later saying they had just inspected the restaurant and closed them down immediately to clean up.  
Good luck.
author: Kim H.

description: This place is very underrated! Cute, quaint, little and charming restaurant that reminds me of dining in Europe. Prices are good, but the food is seriously delightful!! We really enjoyed our desserts- the bread pudding and apple tart. Will definitely be back, with friends and family, especially for brunch. Their brunch menu and outdoor seating area are what Sunday morning brunchy mimosa dreams are made of. Highly recommended!!
author: Cassie B.

description:
Chouquets has the perfect daytime ambiance, a dozen colorful tables spilling onto the sidewalk, tucked away in a quiet and peaceful corner of Pacific Heights. I happened upon this place by accident one afternoon about two months ago and have been back several times already. A great place for people watching and the wine list by the glass is great. 

The smoked trout salad alone is worth five stars. The croque madame is good too. The burger is okay, I was hoping for a more serious bun. But the ambiance is great and the service is very friendly. I'll be back!
author: Ambrose H.

description:
Food is ok.  Not great not bad. The reason for the 1 star is the chef.  He is a loud, obnoxious man who yells and has no respect for the neighborhood.  He smokes on peoples porches and is rude to the neighborhood.  

If you're not from the area, maybe it doesn't matter.  But if you are an SF citizen, with respect for the community, you would be more than taken aback from his actions.
author: Gareth L.

description: Smoke trout salad was delicious. It was a great surprise when the new chef Juan came to see us at the Terrace.  Nice French bistro atmosphere.
author: Stephan R.

description: I LOVE this place.........LOVE the staff.........LOVE the food..........LOVE the patio...........it has been here for YEARS!!!! It is the BEST thing going!!!! See you soon!!!!
author: Amavi D.

description: We had a wonderful outdoor sidewalk lunch on a sunny Saturday.  Great bistro experience.  The staff was very nice... and patient with our kids!  Salade lyonnaise, poulet roti and the burger, all very well prepared.  We'll return.
author: Javier C.

description:
Since last nite, I have been searching this site (and others,) for "Coq Au Vin."  My entree at Chouquet was such a bad version, I am now on a quest to order it elsewhere ASAP ie "chicken done right!"
It's not that it was horrible, the chicken was tender, on the bone (boiled?) it's just that it wasn't even close, too dark, bland, etc.  The service was attentive, and the restaurant was charming, but it will be a long time before I return for dinner I think.
author: Vince C.

description:
I don't know how this place received so many stars. It's about a 2-3 average. The food isn't THAT good. I'm surprised people actually had positive thoughts about this place. 

I came here about 3-4 times with the bf during brunch. Each time we felt that the food wasn't stellar compared to what we paid for. For some strange reason, we just kept coming a few more times to TRY to love the restaurant. But we couldn't.

The last two times we went there, they made mistakes to our order. The funny thing was that we were basically the only two customers there (we would have early brunches). They messed up and gave the bf a completely wrong dish that they tried to compensate by giving us a free dessert (that's why they get 3 stars and not 2). It was really nice of them but the last time we were there, they messed up the food again and the waitress was not that accommodating. The food is still seriously mediocre.
author: Ashlee B.

description:
Cozy little place with a really nice atmosphere. 

I came here for the first time for their Dine About Town SF menu. I had the smoke trout salad, filet mignon, and chocolate fondant with vanilla ice cream. Please forgive me for not knowing the exact names for each dish. You can find it on the menu =P

The waitress was very nice and friendly. The food was not overbearing and not bland at all. I was able to enjoy each dish I had one after another. They have different specials each day and would love to come back to try other dishes on the menu. The wines accompany the food very well. I had the Kris, a berry wine cocktail which was mixed very well. The drink still tasted like a wine but with a slight sweet berry taste.

This neighborhood has a lot of interesting restaurants and I plan to explore more of it ^_^
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
For a relaxed, low-key bistro, Chouquet's fits the bill nicely. Had dinner with 2 colleagues here and we had a good night of food, wine, and conversation.  

I started with the smoked trout mache salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4YQg81cDjn2Ei7NYvRHXpA?select=nWZQwFItipWKoeWkfpnjLw) and this was the highlight of my meal. I can honestly see myself coming back alone, sitting by the bar with a book, and enjoying the salad with a glass of wine. It's just a well-composed salad where all the ingridients work together. The smooth and rich dressing binds the trout, tender greens, and fingerling potatoes into a delicious symphony - so yummy!

Had the rack of lamb (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4YQg81cDjn2Ei7NYvRHXpA?select=vHPGK76D5WOgEkR55W2J9w) for my entree but it paled in comparison to the salad before. Flavor profiles were alright but nothing unforgettable. I thought the cuts were inconsistent - one piece was way smaller than the other and looked like a reject that they had to throw in becuase they ran out. The chocolate fondant (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4YQg81cDjn2Ei7NYvRHXpA?select=5n-ll3HWUswkokX3udvRMg) for dessert thankfully made up for the lamb some. Rich and decadant, the molten chocolate center just kicked it up to a whole other level. 

Split a bottle of wine and we had a great night catching up. I'll be back to Chouquet's, not for a full-blown meal perhaps, but for a salad at lunch with a glass of wine, it sounds like quite the perfect lazy afternoon excursion.
author: Jon L.

description:
I wanted to try this place since I have heard about it through last dine about town.  Since we were in the neighborhood, we thought we would try.  The line was a bit long, but we thought it would be worth the wait.  The menu was simple but reasonably priced for a French establishment.  They seated us in 25 mins and the host was very accommodating.

The problem was the waitress.  I had the hardest time flagging her down.  She didn't get us a high chair as requested on our wait list.  I had to ask a busboy.  She didn't come by to take our order until I almost left by baby by herself while my husband went to repark the car.  She never stopped by after our food came to check on us.  I had to get up to find her for an extra utensil. Our son never got a drink nor was he even asked.  The kids were non-existent until the end when we had to pay. My husband had no idea who our wait staff was since she was busy with everyone but us.

The food was French portion but delicious.  Hence two stars rather than one.  The host guy was nice.
author: Kaela H.

description:
I've driven past this restaurant many times on Fillmore, and finally today, on a whim, we decided to walk in, without Yelping.

This place reminds me of those little French cafes around the different arrondisments in Paris that serve their locals, not the tourist traps. Small, quaint, authentic. The chef speaks French for Christ's sake!! While that is not always an indicator of good French food, this one is.

We Ordered:

Escargots: Baked in a sweet garlic medley, atop a puff pastry. I couldn't help but sweep up the remaining drizzled and sauce with their breads even though the escargots were inhaled.
French Onion Soup:  Perfectly portioned, dark flavorful onion soup.
Lamb Shank: Tender, falls off at the knife. The potatoes were melt in your mouth.
Saumon a La Parisienne: I'm a bit of a salmon snob, and this dish hit every criteria of a good salmon dish. Perfectly pan seared salmon, atop a delicious leek fondue with grilled asparagus. Truly a Parisienne staple!!

Every dish was perfectly flavorful, and satisfied our hankering for the real deal French Food. I'm yet again surprised to stumble upon a great eating spot that gets 3 stars. 

We'll be back for sure. Can't wait for our dessert to come out!!
author: Natalie W.

description: Great neighborhood spot. Food always reliable and service great! Romantic atmosphere.
author: E H.

description:
French food, ooh la la!

A big group of us came in a few nights ago while on a work trip, and they put tables together as the party grew, so we were all able to enjoy each others company, as well as share the wine and escargot.

I had the french onion soup, and the beet salad. Both were good, though the french onion soup was too small and the beet salad too large in portion sizes. As well, there was hardly any broth.

Additionally, I did find a hair in the escargot sauce, which is I'm sure quite uncommon, but can still put one off one's appetite (as though eating snails wasn't already doing that).

I see a ton of potential, as mentioned in the other reviews, but just had several things that undermined a wonderful service and flavor experience.
author: Valerie S.

description:
Just really unimpressed. (Breakfast)
-Food seemed like I could have easily made it myself. 
-Bloody Mary's have WAY TOO MUCH horseradish. 
-Service is excellent, and the guys have french accents which was the best part.
-Overpriced for what you get (even by Pac Heights standards).
author: Andrew O.

description:
Is everyone doing brunch these days? We were in the area and we happened upon Choquet's so we decided to give it a try.

Our French waiter welcomed us with a smile and he automatically gets extra points for having a cute accent. I liked the complimentary crusty baguette and butter, I just wish it was served warm. Service was quick, our dishes came out in 10 minutes. 

My arugula salad with seared shrimp and grapefruit segments were tossed in a lemon-mint vinaigrette. I'm not creative enough to put grapefruit and arugula together, but this combination works because the fruit takes away some of the bitterness of the arugula. Bf had their eggs benny; the hollandaise sauce was on the thick side but still tasty.

Choquet's pales in comparison to other brunch spots in the area such as the Elite Cafe or the Grove. Not even a server with a cute accent is enough to make this a 4 star brunch destination.
author: Janice C.

description: Worst. Service. Ever.  We went for brunch on Saturday.  We asked for water twice, our food came, and still we had nothing to drink.  They were not that busy.  I finally got up and got the water myself.  Not impressed with the food either.  We asked the same guy we asked for the water to bring the bill and got the same response, "yeah, it's coming."  It never came.  We ended up flagging down another guy.  These people couldn't care less.  Will never eat here again.  I've lived in SF for over six years and this is THE worst meal and experience I have ever had in this city.  Not sure how this place is still even open.  Please let me save you the trouble.  Don't waste your time or your money at this dump!
author: Nicole W.

description:
A delightful choice if you are in the neighborhood!

I stopped by to enjoy a couple of cold ones with friends.  It was a sunny day and there is nothing better than sitting outside with friends, enjoying great food in a darling place.  

Vincent was our server and he was on his game.  Beers always replaced, great suggestion on what to eat ( a croque monsieur for those of you keeping score) and just friendly, competent service.  We were there right before they closed down to ready themselves for the dinner rush but we didn't feel rushed or hurried at all.

The friends who I had met here are regulars and it showed, with people coming up to greet them . . .made me feel like a celebrity!

Loved the whole place .  . .and experience! I can't wait to return!
author: Carol K.

description: Last Saturday showed up for lunch.  They were not that busy and was told to sit anywhere.  We selected a table for 4 in the corner away from everyone (though only 2 of us) and then were told by the bartender to move to a table for 2.  No problem.. we sat at a table for 2 where he dropped down water and left.   After 10 minutes(seriously 10 minutes!) of no service, no menus and no one asking if we wanted anything to drink... we got up an left.  Again not busy at all and I don't think they even noticed we left... Second and last time I will go there... Service is part of the experience of dinning out and they don't have any...
author: Sean S.

description:
This reviews comes after my third visit to Chouquet's. My friend and I dined this week during Dine About Town, but the special menu here was a bit lackluster for the price, so we went with the regular menu, which was totally fine. 

I ordered the scallops and it was the best scallops dish I have had in a very long time. Five perfectly cooked day boat scallops surrounding a mushroom risotto. The sauce was amazing and not too rich...each bite was full of flavor and I ended up cutting a few of the scallops into fours just to make it last longer. Nice, right!?

My friend had the filet and it was a also great and cooked to a perfect medium due to the fact it was cooked by the French chef (inside joke...sorry). Is it me or are the steaks at French restaurants underrated? 

We skipped dessert, but had some dessert wine and sunk into excellent conversation about everything from retirement real estate in Mexico to capital punishment around the world. Good food and drink make you stick around the restaurant to enjoy the ambiance and soak in the moment. The view of the street and passers by also contributed to the overall atmosphere in and around Chouquet's. 

I'll definitely be back as I have no reason not to return. Great service, great food, and an overall great time is what this restaurant consistently offers.
author: Karim V.

description:
Just an unremarkable restaurant and I'm surprised by that.  Stopped in because it looked popular for a Sunday afternoon and decided to have breakfast.   It's a cute place with the french bistro feel and had a lovely outdoor sitting area.  We opted to sit inside but might have enjoyed our experience more if we had sat outside.   The service was fine and the food was fair but nothing that stood out.   I guess that's why it was a disappointment because there was no "WoW" factor to make me want to come back or even linger.   

I'm not surprised by the low reviews, I can't quite put my finger on it except there's nothing that I would recommend or encourage me to return again.
author: Deena B.

description: Lovely Saturday brunch bistro with outdoor seating.  Eggs Benedict, French Toast, and Goat Cheese Tartlet were all tasty selections without being heavy.  Regular coffee was good and so was the cappuccino.  I would recommend--French food without the fuss.
author: Moses O.

description: A hidden gem of authentic French style and flavor! The food was exceptional both in taste and prices. Thanks to the chef for a wonderful time.
author: Eileen B.

description: Food was great. But overshadowed by everything else. Utensils were dirty. Server had a sour attitude disputed us trying to cheer her up. Our waters were delivered holding the top of the glasses while sporting a bloody bandaid on his finger. And the chef was arguing with the server. Failing at Restaurant 101 kinda stuff. I now understand why this place was half empty during Sunday brunch.
author: Britton R.

description:
3.5 stars. 
My dad wanted to try French food so I bought a gift certificate at Restaurant.com for Chouquet's. $25.

I made reservations for three at 5:30pm on a Sunday night (tonight). 

We arrived at 5:20pm and was told they open at 5:30pm

We come back and were the first table to be seated. They let us pick so we picked the one in by the wall. Later we were told to move to the table next to it cause that was a table for three because later they were going to get "busy." Whatever.



We ordered a 

Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad  12 - I didn't realize it was a salad. Haha. I thought it was smoke trout with a side salad. When I saw it come out I was like OMG! Cause I ordered it for my dad and he is a carnivore! Sigh. We shared our meals. It was actually pretty tasty. There was quite a bit of trout in there. 

Half Roasted chicken - I ordered this. Normally, I am not a huge fan of anything with bones but this was tender and juicy. Cutting it off the bone wasn't a chore. Also came with carrots and fingerling potatoes. Yum. 

Grilled Alaskan Salmon with white wine sauce, veggies & truffle mashed potatoes  22 - I ordered this for my mom. The salmon is cooked to the point where it is just right. My mom likes her fish to be a bit more overly cooked. I hear people like it when it is just cooked. Mash potatoes wasn't a lot. Veggies are asparagus and peas - grilled. I liked the veggies. 

The waitress handed us each a dessert menu. Originally, I wanted us to get fro-yo but what the heck! We're already here. We ordered this thing and they weren't even making it so I just asked for the check. 

The service here is really good. The waitress we had was really friendly and heard my timid voice through the French music. The price was 65 including 18% gratuity for the three of us. Not bad. I don't know if I would return. Nothing really sparked my taste buds although everything was cooked right.   

We finished eating around 6.30pm. There was never no more than 4 tables and the table we were originally sitting at was still empty. Our waitress was nice but I felt the one who came in to eat and then start working had an air of attitude.

One bathroom for all. It is nice.
author: Sarah C.

description: This little gem of a place offers lovely French cuisine with pretty good service and a nice atmosphere. Great for a date or a small group. The escargot and house made foie gras were delicious and I'm still reminiscing about the delectable the tuna tartar. The meat in the Boeuf Bourguignon was amazingly tender and tasty. The sole and salmon were thoroughly enjoyed by those who ordered them. Great restaurant, recommend it.
author: Tatiana N.

description: I like sitting outside on this relatively quiet stretch of Fillmore and watching the parade while eating their yummy food and enjoying French wine. Dog-friendly.
author: Michael J S.

description: Amazing French restaurant....they have a warm and cozy place....food is total French delight....and I've been to France 8 times..this place is fantastic. Atmosphere is warm....charming ..service is A#1.
author: Russ T.

description:
Can you give lower than 1 star?  I would

Long story short my wife and I went here with another couple for NYE and were forced to pay a $65 prix fix meal.  The price of $65 was fine but the service and food was not.

To make a long story short, they screwed up Lobster.  LOBSTER.  You know...the crustacean that you put into a pot of boiling water, take it out after about 10 minutes and put butter on???  Ya, they didn't do that.  The decided to put some disgusting white/celery sauce on top of the split tail.  The Lobster itself was tough and stringy, and was almost impossible to pull out of the shell.  The sauce tasted something between a bad homemade tartar sauce and an overly celery'd lobster roll. 

Before the main dish I had lobster bisque, which was nice, and the smoked salmon app, which was ok but had too much creme cheese wrapped into the fish.  After the lobster debacle, they finished off the menu with a "Easy Bake oven'esque" chocolate and vanilla ice cream dessert.  Needless to say, after I only ate 1/2 of the lobster tail and truffle risotto, I was not hungry for dessert.

The funny thing that happened is when the bus boy came by to pick up our plates, he said to me "Hey you have 1/2 a lobster tail on your plate" and I replied "Ya...there's a reason for that...it is terrible."  He said that he would get the server and she came by.  Visibly upset she asked me what was wrong with the lobster tail and dish and I told her.  She replied "Well since it's a prix fix meal, we can not deduct cost or offer a refund, so if there is anything else we can do please let me know."  I simply ordered a nice Bordeaux and left it at that, but I was not happy.

Other notes:

1.  They forgot to leave menus when they seated us, and didn't realize until about 20 mins later.

2.  They sat us outside, where it was chilly and uncomfortable, especially for the wives with SKIRTS ON!

3.  After the lobster tail episode, the server returned and said directly to me "Oh you're back" to which our entire table was extremely confused.

4. Rude and S...L...O...W... service.  Arrived at 830 pm and left at 11pm for a 3 piece meal.

5.  If you want a substitution, don't expect one.  If you want an answer from the chef, don't expect one.  If you want a good meal, MacDonald s has a dollar menu and is better quality.

The bottom line is, this restaurant is not good.  A wise man once said "The French are assholes" - Walter Sobchak (The Big Labowski) and at Chouquet's it the truth!
author: Jeremy E.

description:
Had a Sunday brunch here and not a place that gave me anything extra. Had Lyonnaise sallad that was OK, but not really rocket science to do that type of sallad. I also had cappuccino and it was very poorly prepared. Neither the milk or the beans was good. They call them self a french hip restaurant it was either french or hip. The name Chouquet's insinuate that they have pastries but they didn't even have croissants! 

The best thing with the restaurant was the outdoor seating area
author: Petter B.

description:
Do you know how long I've been wanting to try this place? Long time. Think five years working two blocks away and passing it up thinking to yourself, "Another time." Not today.

I felt good, it was such a beautiful sunny afternoon.  And I was dressed for winter. Eh, so be it, I'm from the city. I wanted a salad after I messed up my arugula from home. No one says this, or I actually don't know anyone that says this, but I actually was CRAVING a nice salad. Check out my little quote, "I ain't no salad eating chick." Well, I gotta change that now. Change is good.

The salad that appealed to me was the Arugula and Frisse salad with proscuitto, cherry tomatoes and poached egg. My memory cells really must be gone because as soon as the salad arrived, I thought the white stuff was cheese. Nice. I was wrong though. It was the poached egg because you shoulda seen the look on my face when I accidently popped it and all the yolk started dripping onto the greens. It was a look of surprise and "Oh yeah! Poached egg!" I obviously have not had a poached egg before, but because of this salad, I'm gonna do my hardest to try and poach an egg.

This salad was so wonderfully refreshing, delicous and satisfied my craving so bad that I ate it painfully slow, really savoring all the interesting flavors coming together in my mouth. It was so excellent that I thanked the really pretty server for recommending it to me and I swear I'm coming back just to have it over and over again. Then again, I guess I could make it at home. But the dining experience alone is just so... I don't know, an experience I love having.

The atmosphere of the place is great. You can sit outside and enjoy people watching, but it's located on a quiet corner of Fillmore. Being inside was just as fine, the colors were sienna and white. Wait, do you care about that? I guess not, but just being there made me smile.
author: Sharon B.

description:
My friend had a Groupon here, so we decide to come here one evening.  I recommend coming here on a Sunday, because this area can be hard to find parking. When i walked in the place gave me a feeling like I was in New York. It was semi like an open kitchen decor, which made it super cute. The waiter here was very nice and attentive, he brought us our drinks and bread and he gave us refills on both constantly. 

They have a Prix Fixe menu set at $30.00, but it is only good between the hours of 5:30 to 7:30. Their menu does not include a huge selection, but their Prix Fixe menu is good enough already. You can either order clam Chowder or their trout to start off. For the main course you have the option of their Veggie Gnochhi, Seared Ahi Tuna or Kobe Beef Burger.  And for desserts you can chose from their Chocolate Fondant or Creme Brulee..  

My friend ended up getting the  Clam Chowder and Ahi Tuna. I had a few sips of her chowder and I must say, it was the best Clam Chowder I ever had in the world!   I think the reason why I love it, is because you can tasted the bacon and potatoes in it and they give you so many clams in the soup.  I also took a few bites of the Ahi Tuna, which turned out pretty good as well.  

I actually heard that their lamb was pretty good so i ordered the Lamb shoulder braised, mushroom truffle oil & pommes salardaise.  What is Pommes Salardase you ask? Well it's not salad.  It's like potatoes, but fried like chips.   I fell in love with this dish! The lamb was so tender and juicy, I have to say it must be true when they say they braised it for 7 hours.  I loved their potatoes, it went perfectly well with the lamb the their sauce.  

For dessert my friend and i shared their Chocolate Fondant.  It was made to perfection!  It was warm and fluffy. So fluffy you are going to die! The chocolate came oozing out when second you cut into it and it went great with the Vanilla Ice cream.  

I wished i had an extra Groupon ticket so I can come here again, but even without it, I'm already planning to come back. I absolutely love it here!
author: Belinda C.

description: I have eaten at this place a couple times in the last couple years. It did not appear to be well taken care of. A little on the dirty side.  This time (March 18th) I ate there and while waiting for my food decided to check the Yelp ratings. That's when I noticed a food safety warning on the Yelp app. I would think that a business with such a bad rating with the health department would do something to clean up their act. It does not appear they're trying. I will not be back!
author: Michael R.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday September 2, 2009 @ 6:45pm
Company:  Jin A w/ Brownie & Jack
Crowd:  Well-Heeled Neighborhood Couples w/ The Ladies in Tory Burch Dresses & Prada Shades w/ Pampered Pooches in ipuppyone Harnesses & Young Families w/ Quinny Strollers
Vibe:  Understated
Decor:  Dining Al-Fresco for Deux
Service:  Polite, Professional, Courteous
Imbibe:  Arnold Palmer.  Cocktails Available
Devour:  Beef Carpaccio & Steak & Frites
Skip:  Bland Seafood Chowder
Note:  Thank You Jin for the Great Company & Wonderful Meal=)
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Really very good. Can't wait to go back. Dined al fresco under the heaters. Service was slow which was just fine. Waiter was excellent.
author: Zene B.

description:
My bf and I love all the food here (but we never really tried their desserts tho. The first time we went there, a forgetful but nice lady with a thick French accent was giving us a super fab service, and also the kobe beef tarte, escargo, and the mussels were so good that we decided to go back to try more dishes. 
The second time we went there, we used the Groupon thing for 30% off and we suddenly saw that on Tuesday, it will be a $1 oyster special night! We will go back to devour all the oysters next time!
author: Joelle K.

description:
Outdoor seating? I'M IN! C'est tres chic!

Came across Chouquet's while my friend and I cruising down Fillmore. I love cute little restaurants with an outdoor seating. It was in the late afternoon, so they were pretty empty. Sat down, ordered, immediately enjoyed the friendly customer service.

Food:
*Spicy tuna tartare with taro root chips - tuna was well seasoned and taro chips were crispy and seasoned well also.
*Butter lettuce with bay shrimp - big portion, and not stingy on the shrimp either! The champagne vinaigrette was exceptional, light and brings out the flavor in the shrimp!
*Seared salmon on a bed of organic vegetables with parisian sauce - MY FAV! it fit in my paleo diet and it was absolutely delicious! the sauce is light and buttery. The salmon was cooked perfectly!

Definitely will come back next time for dinner, wait for the update review :)
author: Mindy C.

description: The service was slow, but the omelette was tasty as was the cappuccino.  I would go back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Heather S.

description: Cons: Food is meh,  and plenty of better options in the area. Pros: Nice little sidewalk seating area reminds me of nyc. 1/2 off bottles of wine on Mondays isn't bad if you need to extend the weekend
author: Louis D.

description:
3.5 stars

The grapefruit mimosa ($7?) was super delicious w/ juicy pulps.  We waited longer than needed because our waitress forgot to put in our order, which is fine.  My water glass had lipstick mark on it before I touched it.  The bread plate was dirty so I swapped it.

I was debating between the shrimp arugula salad or the smoked trout salad, waitress suggested smoked trout - great choice, it was very tasty.

What we had:
Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad  $13 - plenty trout, the mache was super yummy.  The fingerling potato was nicely grilled to a crisp.

Omelette Parisienne with prosciutto, gruyère, & mushrooms $12 - this was quite delicious but on the smaller portion, came with a small mixed greens and some breakfast potatoes.

Hubby said coffee was pretty good.
author: Gloria H.

description: Just wanted a quick bite, waiting to check in at my hotel...Ordered the chicken breast sandwich with a side salad, should have gone to Subway! The chicken breast was so thin, thank goodness the roll it was on was sufficient. Don't understand the popularity of this place.
author: Susan M.

description:
I have liked Chouquet's and disliked it. In reality, it deserves a little more attention than it does right now. I would recommend for everyone to try for themselves. This can be a romantic neo-French diner, with some Californian influence. I like the Chateau Rose half bottle wine honored by the French ministry of agriculture (I was only able to find it here).  The crab salad was memorable. The main courses quite decent. 

There's a bit of inconsistency i.e. my experiences have varied from time to time day to day. The greatest restaurants don't do it, but still, it is decent. Walk a bit further up Fillmore towards Pac Heights hills to reach this restaurant, and after dinner walk above and beyond towards Pacific Ave. to see the beautiful Golden Gate bridge view, Palace of Fine art at Broadway and Pacific
author: Dilys S.

description: Had Chouquet's catered today at my office using catering service Zesty. Vegetarian sandwich looked nothing like the photo and tasted blegh, with burned toast. Tuna sandwich was reported to be just 'meh,' and the chicken sandwich was only passable. Would not recommend this place for catering.
author: Marcella D.

description:
A cute little spot with indoor and outdoor dining. Very simple decor with stacks of wine glasses against the wall, and a small bar that seats may be 6 people. Good for small groups.
The staff was very polite and professional, offering advice on what is good to order. 
We ordered the Carpaccio and the Ahi Tuna. Both were excellent. And the Frites were great as well. 
For desert, we had Chocolate Fondant Cake with Vanilla Ice Cream. It was good, but I've had better.
Overall, a great place to have dinner.
author: Ron Z.

description:
No line for Sunday brunch and the food came out quick But service was painfully slow and not very welcoming or friendly. 

Took at least 20 minutes to get coffee... And then more time to order.. Then 20 minutes to clear our plates and get the bill...

Breakfast and coffee were good but nothing special.
author: Shanna N.

description:
Chouquets is one of those little hidden gems amidst all the good dining options in the Fillmore area. 
I have been there a few times through the years and it has never disappointed.
We went last time for NYE and had a great time. You could tell that they were really busy but all the staff was still very polite and helpful and took the time to explain the menu. 
Drinks came fast and food was delicious.
We never felt rushed or unappreciated.
I would go back again and recommend it to anyone who is looking for a cozy and yummy French meal.
author: Sabina A.

description:
3.5 stars.

Brings me back to the lovely Parisian culture... except not quite close enough. Went here for dinner:

The bread doesn't exactly speak "FRENCH" loudly at all, but BOY oh BOY, the BUTTER--I was just bummed that they took away the butter before I could eat it all. Then again I guess I have to thank them for saving me from cholesterol death.

Got the kobe beef carpaccio and that was delish. Then split some rib-eye which was a little too chewy and cooked almost right, and the ahi tuna dish, which was perfect minus the sesame it was coated in. In my opinion, the sesame took away from the great flavor of the ahi tuna, but oh well--c'est la vie. Split the banana hazelnut crumble which was alright... and then finished French-style with an expresso, which was made by illy. Poo! You'd think the true French restaurants would throw in some of their own coffee, but I guess illy is acceptable enough for this round.

One of the servers didn't speak English too well... and I can't speak French! I struggled to ask how big of a cup of coffee I'd get for a cafe, but regardless, the French girl brought authenticity to the meal. Besides, I thought it was endearing! How I miss Paris...
author: Joanne Y.

description:
