My gf and I decided to browse around for a brunch spot while walking on Fillmore but it was raining and cold so we wanted to go somewhere without a wait.  We both had not been here before and decided to give it a try.  

There were a couple of people outside eating in a tented area since they had dogs and inside there was another group but other than that empty at 10am on a Saturday.  Our waitress was French which was nice at a French restaurant and she suggested we get the mango mimosas which was the highlight of the meal.  I got the Omelette Parisienne with bacon, gruyère, & mushrooms.  It came with some potatoes and a simple salad.  The portions were small compared to let's just say, the Crepevine.  It was nice though to have less food since I've been watching my waistline lately.  My friend got the Croque-Madame which was a better looking meal minus the potatoes.  

Overall, the brunch was good.  3 stars seems low when all you see is 4 star reviews lately.  But the meal was what it was, A-OK.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Great service! Loved the salmon and grilled veggie dish ... Server made sure that I was happy with my Red Zin... I Sat outside on a lovely SF day with attentive service and good food. What could be better?
author: Kimberly R.

description:
I love coming to Pacific Heights, walking Fillmore and driving by expensive real estate picking which mansion I'd live in if I successfully robbed a bank....and I also love a good brunch, which brought me to Chouquet's- specifically because they were participating in Dine About Town, so we thought we'd give em a try.

We were seated immediately, and were served orgasmic ACME bread while we perused the DAT and regular menu.  We decided on the regular menu because well, we didn't feel the DAT choices.  

So for $11, we started with a half dozen of Effigham Oysters.  They tasted ok, but I've had oysters that tasted more fresh and oceanic, if you will.  For $13 I ordered the Smoked Salmon Benedict, served w/a side salad.  The Smoked Salmon was perfect, the hollandaise sauce was on-point, the eggs were perfectly poached, but the bread was drier than a nun's ti-.  So I let out a lil yelp-cry of dissatisfaction when I made that discovery.

For $11, mon cheri ordered a Niman ranch burger served with pommes frites.  He ate it pretty quick.  (But he eats fast, regardless.) He barely touched the pommes frites but I took care of that.   He said the burger was cooked "right".

The ambiance is your typical Fillmore earthy clean-lined modern cuteness, they have outdoor seating available, and I believe lucky in location to be a corner restaurant.  The service was ok, but I felt the busboys were more friendly and attentive than our waitress.

Unfortunately the highlights of our visit were:

1. A lady walking in like she was all that and a bag of chips but scrubbed hard.
2.  The bathroom.  Check the pic.
author: Rho T.

description: Not getting the lowly 3-star rank at this cozy Pac Heights place. With Michelinization, inflation and crowds tainting so many other spots, this place is a blessing. The Frenchie-style ambiance is perfect to meet friends, have fun, and drink some wine. On the food front, I would 100% order the chicken, it's some of the most tender breast I've had, even better than those rotisserie chickens you find elsewhere. When asked about the secret it was revealed that this place gets 'small' chickens, something you can't buy at the market. The sole fish dish was excellent too. It is hard to mess sole up, but the subtle flavors here combined with the delicate fish were great. The beef bourgogne was par, great sauce, less fatty but slightly dry meat, wouldn't get that again unless I was craving it. The wine comes in half bottles but you may want to bring your own. Very pleasant staff that dispels the French are rude stereotype. Will return when the time in right.
author: Brian J.

description:
My girlfriend and I really enjoyed their Thursday night special on mussels: larger portions of mussels, plus fries, for $22. We were totally full after eating ~3 dozen mussels each, a full side of fries, and their tasty bread. Usually we split an appetizer and sometimes split a dessert also, but there was no chance after eating all that. A choice of six sauces for the mussels is offered. We picked saffron and spicy tomato. Both were good, and the spice with the tomatoes was mild, yet flavorful. 

Our server was very nice. In addition, the pacing/speed of a meal has never been a problem at Chouquet's, which can allow for a slower or quicker meal, especially for a French restaurant. I've eaten dinners inside and brunch outside here.

Combining all this with an easily accessible location creates a very good, yet casual, experience.
author: Mike H.

description:
Love, love LOVE this restaurant!  This is my favorite cafe in Pacific Heights for Saturday or Sunday early afternoon mimosas, oysters and a salad (although dinners are also delicious).  

Choose between classic, mango or grapefruit mimosas (or enjoy all three!).

The arugula salad + a dozen oysters is my go-to brunch/lunch.  I used to get the endive salad, but they recently changed their menu.  However, the arugula salad is equally tasty.  My betrothed (the love of my life) tried the trout salad and really enjoyed it.

The goat cheese and tomato tartlette is divine, but fairly rich, so sharing is recommended.

Request an outside table under the heat lamps for the best weekend afternoon dining and day drinking.  When they crank up the heat, it almost feels like you are in Southern California!

This place is a popular neighborhood spot, without being overly crowded.  After brunch/lunch, walk over to Alta Plaza park for scenic views of downtown and the bay.  Can't recommend this place enough.
author: Wolfgang C.

description: Pretty standard brunch. Nice sunny dining room. I like the corner seat for 2. Very cozy. Mussels was slightly small in terms of portion for the price, but the flavor was good.
author: Sherry L.

description: Great French food in a calming wine bar-line environment in Lower Pac Heights and excellent service. Highly recommend.
author: Mike L.

description:
Dropped in during Dine About Town week and was surprised by the huge portions and friendly service, but was disappointed in the lack of flavor in all the dishes. I ordered the Natural Ribs as an appetizer, the filet as an entree and creme brulee for dessert. The Rib appetizer could have seriously served as an entree in itself and the size of the filet was no different. The portion sizes were impressive, but the food didn't do much for me. I don't want to go as far as calling the food bland, but the flavors just didn't wow me. It just felt like I was inhaling a bunch of high end meat at a discounted price. The creme brulee wasn't bad and again portions were huge, which isn't a bad thing but I just felt like it was a waste of food because I couldn't finish it. 

Everything about the appearance of the restaurant, a quaint little restaurant on the corner of the block, and the food, nicely presented and large portions, would draw me to try Chouquet but sadly the food just didn't deliver.
author: Queena T.

description:
I agree with their 3 star rating.

The setting on a nice day can be very nice. Especially sitting outside. But the service and food was mediocre. It seemed like they only had 1 waitress for the entire restaurant so it was SLOW. I had a croque monsieur and it was just a huge flat piece of bread with a thin slice of ham and tons of cheese. Definitely not anything special and something I could make at home.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Only had the seafood here  and appetizers. Would come back to try their meat dishes.

The mussels were done perfectly and were delicious in a wine butter sauce.

Oysters on a half shell were okay

Beet salad with crumbled cheese and candied nuts were good

My fish stew was filled to the brim with a variety of seafood (mussels, clams, scallops, fish, etc) and served with crusty bread with a wonderful garlic topping.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: Pretty cozy neighborhood French bistro! First time dinned here and had a good time with hubby. We ordered oyster, mussels, seafood stew and chocolate fondant. The first two are just ok but the last two orders are really good!!
author: L K.

description: Mediocre omelette even worse service. We came on a Saturday at 1030. There were maybe 7 tables of people and yet it was like pulling teeth to get any service. The waiter came by our table maybe twice and was pretty unresponsive to requests. The service was so bad that after twenty minutes of waiting for our check (after requesting it from our waiter and busboy) we went inside and just made them run our cards.  I won't be returning here again.
author: Dan M.

description: Stopped in because we needed to find a restroom and those are impossible to find without dining. I had the trout salad, my wife had the Niçoise salad and we split a quiche de jour. We loved it! I'm not sure why it only has three stars but for lunch it deserved five. The fifth star is for a perfect espresso which is rare in restaurants.
author: Josh T.

description:
I never knew what the hype is about when it comes to Brunch in San Francisco.  I never understood the long lines for eggs and toast and I don't think I'll ever will but this particular Sunday just proved to me that I am still sane because of my impression on Brunches.

We were seated right away on this sunny Sunday during prime brunch time by a friendly hostess.  Server greeted us shortly after we sat down and gave us the special of the day.  A bus boy brought us a glass of water a few minutes after.  

We ordered the following: Crab Omelet with avocado and cheese with a side of potatoes and Croque-Monsieur with a green salad.  

The Crab Meat Omelet lack flavor and accompanied by the lack of potatoes.  It almost felt like that they didn't want to make any more fresh potatoes so they just scoop what ever they had left and tossed it on my plate.

The service did not show any enthusiasm and it lacks vibe.

This experience just proved to me that Brunch with long lines in SF is overrated.

"It's just fu*king eggs people!!!"
author: C Y.

description:
I first visited Choquet's back in 2011. It was a cute little bistro in the quaint little upper Pac Heights neighborhood, right on the corner of Washington and Filmore. We had brunch there. It was decent, but nothing really to write home about. 

That is, until I decided to give it a try recently. Best decision. 

Chicken liver pate was rich, creamy without over-powering. Scallops are perfectly cooked with delicious green. The filet mignon was better than many steakhouse I've been in the city. Whatever sauce they had for the veal special sort of blew my mind. 

Everything was simple, yet very well done. Down to the bread they provided: butter-toasted points with knife-slip-right-in soft butter. M is the picky French eater gave it a two-thumbs up. 

Bonus point for the uber Parisian feel when we sat outside on a warm fall night. 

There's dollar oysters on Tuesdays. 
I will most certainly be back.
author: Fiona S.

description:
*** NOTE: This review is based only on their brunch ****

I certainly wouldn't drive a cross the town just to have brunch here, but it is a useful place to know if you were planning on a day of shopping on Fillmore Street on a nice sunny day.  Their outdoor seating, which is on Washington Street, has a nice layout with the sight of Alta Plaza and the quiet neighborhood leading to the park on Washington Street, away from the busy traffic on Fillmore.  Indoor seating is also very nice for a weekend brunch in this 'L' shaped restaurant with most of the seats in close proximity to the big windows with plenty of light.

As you would expect from a French restaurant, their brunch food is more of a polished kind, rather than the all American diner breakfast food.  They have greens w/ nice balsamic vinegar instead of hash on the side.  I had their Croque-Monsieur which was pretty good, but I liked the one at Butler & the Chef Bistro (http://www.yelp.com/biz/NYP4d9HiiDHt9iYYgoqnxw) more.  Their brunch menu had 12 selections, but for some reason, I felt that it lacked selection.  Perhaps because if you don't want a salad (I like real food), then it wipes out half of the items on the menu.  Most items are $9-12 which was quite reasonable.

Perhaps 3 stars was a tough rating for a nice restaurant, but I felt that their brunch was average and there are so many other places offering better brunch, including Elite Cafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz/NhvqEIpcLbwFhW1cEVSzoA) just down the road.
author: トモ T.

description:
We came to Chouquet's on a Friday night. The menu is pretty standard French food. I had dayboat scallops (3 pieces) with black risotto while my friend ordered pork medallions. I was actually quite happy with my dish. The scallop was nicely cooked while the black risotto and cream sauce complemented the dish well. My friend's pork was quite mediocre and rather plain. 

Overall, we had an OK experience here. I wish I could give a 3.5 stars rating here.
author: Saran R.

description:
What a fantastic hidden gem!!! 

Simple, classic and French. 

My gf and I found this place awhile ago and have been coming for months now. It's our little escape from everything. The atmosphere is lovely and perfect for a date night in San Francisco. The service and food always good and friendly. 

An example: 
My gf is allergic to shellfish and we had decided to go on NYE but knew there was a prefix menu with lobster so we called before reservations were made and explained and they were happy to substitute the lobster for something else. Understandably, we knew they would be crazy busy it's NYE. We had a fun experience. We brought close friends. We all had so much fun and the staff although SLAMMED were still able to be attentive and as considerate as they could. 

Furthermore, go try out the brunch!!!  I tried  the fermiere omelette. ( ham, gruyere, and mushrooms. And they usually have a special omelette which is always good too.

Dinner, some faves to try is the veal blanquette , Trout salad and pork medallions. Yum!!! 

Literally, it's the coziest dinner spot. I had to let people know to check out this quaint French spot. Seriously, perplexed on others not so great experiences. 

Some negatives are that the place can be a little too chilly because the front door seems to always be broken and lights are too bright during dinner service for my liking.
author: Natalie F.

description:
I came here on presidents days...I was a bit disappointed that the dine about town menu was not available.

The French toast was good, although small (and looked like a small bauget was cut for it into 4-5 pieces), at least they had mimosa.

Service: Good, but it was pretty quiet when I get here, (close to 2pm). 
Parking: Lots of street parking (metered).
author: Omar L.

description:
Brunch only - 

I think the service was okay.  It's nothing great, but good enough.  

Food was average.  The croque monsieur was like a pizza.  Fries were good.  

It does not strike me as a place I'd come for dinner though, as there are so many options in San Francisco.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
13 dollar Wagyu Kobe Beef Burger was a RIP-OFF and BULLSHIT!!!

First of all, there is no such a thing call: Wagyu-Kobe Beef.
"Wagyu" means Japanese beef. So, "Wagyu-Kobe Beef" saying beef twice. It doesn't make any sense saying it. OK? OK!
And, you can't import Kobe-beef. That's against the international law, period.

THERE IS NO KOBE BEEF FROM KOBE, JAPAN IN U.S.

Second of all, 
I said medium but I got well-done. The chef doesn't know how to cook a medium burger. What a waste!

Third, soggy french fries, Goddamnit."

Fourth, there was a long ass hair in.
Fxxx me. They might use their arm pit to make the hamburger patty.

Super good location but there is nothing special about it.
What a shame!

French goes bad is here.
Oh well, 
I smell the owner or chef will be changed soon.
This French stinks, doesn't know how to cook.

Ken K. said, "This French stinks, doesn't know how to cook. And sadly doesn't know America style hybrid beef from doggy style."

I think French likes doggy style, don't they?
author: Nobu K.

description:
I had a decent meal here with some friends.

I ordered the burger, which turned-out to be pretty good, it was juicy and cooked just the way I liked it, although it really didn't have anything to make it stand-out from other better burger spots.  My friends ordered a few other items (a fish dish and a vegetarian dish), and those were okay too.

All in all, I didn't think the food was particularly fantastic, but it was good.  The setting is pretty cool since it's a small, neighborhood restaurant and has a very cozy feel to it.  The service was attentive and very good.
author: Ken G.

description:
I came here with two friends for Dine About Town and really enjoyed my  experience!  The place had a really cute atmosphere, (can't quite put my finger on it, but it was kind of like a laidback, all-about-the-food, sophisticated atmosphere), and the service was pretty good.

The food itself was, for the most part, delicious!  I started off with the smoked trout salad, which I wasn't expecting to be wow'ed by, but I was!  The trout was good, the little pumpkin seeds (which I didn't know were pumpkin seeds but I asked cause I liked them so much in the salad) were great, and the salad overall, mmm!  I split this and the crispy rolls of Baramundi with one of my friends, and the rolls were ok, but not that memorable (also gingery, so if you don't like ginger, it is infused with the taste even though my friend said she barely knew it was there).

Then I moved onto the Ahi Tuna Carpaccio..  I felt slightly mixed about this one.  The tuna itself was really good, but it was covered by the green stuff on top (cilantro, was it?  Tasted a lot like cilantro) and that's all I really ended up tasting.  I think probably it could've used a lot less of that.

Finally, we all ended up getting the Chocolate Fondant, and it was sooooo good.  I love chocolate and I love melted chocolate in chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream on the side.

Overall, good food, good service, cute place!  Thanks for the good DAT experience Chouquet's!
author: Alice M.

description:
I loved coming here for Dine About Town. I highly recommend reservations. The place was almost empty except for my table and another couple sitting in a corner, but I still saw a couple rounds of people get turned away because they needed to save the tables for the reservations they had booked later that night. The service is great. The servers are friendly and knowledgeable about their menu and wines.

I was with a friend for dinner - our first time at this restaurant. We both decided to get different items from the Dine About Town Menu so that we could share and maximize the dishes we could try.

Starters:
- SALADE DE TRUITE FUMEE (Flakes of smoked trout with mâche, fingerling potato , shaved red onion, & toasted pumpkin seeds): I love this dish! The tastes from each ingredient go very well with one another. The potatoes were warm, which added another level of intrigue to the plate overall

- Escargots  de Bourgogne (parsley butter, garlic, bread crumbs, white wine in a flakey pastry shell): This dish is so much better if you eat it while it's still warm. LOVE the butter garlic and the falkey pastry shell was a dream

Entrees:
- HOMARD (Lobster tail, dynamite sauce with mushrooms risotto): The dynamite sauce was great on the lobster tail. I usually love mushroom risotto, but not this time. The risotto was very bland.

- FILET DE BOEUF (6 oz Kobe beef filet with Bordelaise sauce, gratin dauphinois & vegetables): We asked for medium rare and it was perfect. I could eat that gratin all day.

Desserts:
- Chocolate fondant with butter scotch sauce: rich and decadent, our plate came with some ice cream, which paired with the gooey, melty chocolate very well. A perfect way to end the meal.

- Grand marnier crème brulée: Too sweet. Sweeter than the chocolate fondant.

I would definitely come back during Dine About Town. Probably wouldn't purposely make it out to this area otherwise.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I found out about this place because of restaurant.com and their $25 coupon or I probably never would have tried this place.  I had the Kobe beef burger which was awesome.  I paid extra for the cheese and bacon and it was quite cheesy and the bacon was perfectly crisp just the way I like it.  

My wife had the trout salad and she said it was perfectly dainty for a chick salad.  The waitress was really sweet and although she looked asian, she had a french accent which reminded me of a certain movie star that I won't mention.

Will definitely be back even if I don't have a coupon.
author: James H.

description: This restaurant is truly underrated!  You need to order correctly:  I can individually vouch for the delicious tuna poke for a light lunch/appetizer or the to-die-for(!) hamburger.  (It is better than Roam burgers down the street, I guarantee you.)  Sit at an outdoor table on a sunny day, bring your dog (they have individual water bowls for them) include a glass of wine, if you are so inclined and enjoy!  A real treat!!
author: Ellie Y.

description:
Minimalist decor to match minimalist servings. I like a generous brunch plate, a plate crowded with salad & garnish & eggs so big & fluffy, they threaten to overtake the plate. 

Chouquet's Parisienne omelet ($12) is miniscule & its accompanying side of potatoes & salad--a sad, sad portion. Nothing noteworthy. 

We usually split a carb (French toast, pastries, pancakes, etc.) for 'dessert' after our eggy entrees, but the boring food, non-existent waitress & super hot & stuffy room made us say, 'check, please!' the first moment we could grab someone's attention.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Way to ruin our Mothers day! 
I have never had worse service than this any where else in SF. It is disappointing because the place is actually really cute with outdoor seating but I'm still waiting for our waitress to offer the desert menu or ask if we need anything else. They were so rude that I was embarrassed that I had suggested and had brought my Mom and my sister here for Mothers day. Mickael Azoulay "the owner" really needs to make some major changes in order for this place to turn around or just shut down the place and give it to a new owner to make this place a decent restaurant.
author: Kajal P.

description:
Casual french food. 

The fillet mignon on the brunch menu is quite good. It was served just the way I like it (saignant), with the right amount of sauce, fries, and salad. The decor is kinda post modern, and the bathroom is nicer than most. However, this restaurant doesn't have all the normal pomp and show of a traditional french restaurant. If that's what you're looking for, this isn't it. It seems like a nice place to have a relaxed meal on Sundays, or a casual dinner with friends on a week day. (Not exactly the best place to take a first date.)
author: Alejandro V.

description:
Came in on Friday July 19th, 2013 to a pretty full restaurant without a reservation and was still able to get a table which was nice.

After being seated --- we were given ample time to review the beverage menu and select our entrees. Overall, the food was on point --- we chose the "Creekstone Filet Mignon with garlic green beans, cauliflower gratin & sauce poivre at $28" and the Pan Seared Halibut Special at $28 each plus a glass of Chardonnay and a 1664 Kronenbourg for $76 plus tip or $90 out the door.

My only complaint --- which I usually never complain about was the extremely fast service. At $90 for two people --- I would have preferred for our dinner to last a little longer than 15 minutes from when our order was taken to when the entrees were brought out.
author: Brian D.

description:
(See pics)

More of 3.8 stars.

Came here for dinner. A nice very cute place with red and white and yellow decoration. Love the fiber glass style artwork on the wall.

It's a narrow L shape restaurant with pretty decent food. The seafood clam chowder with sancerre wine (my top favourite shell seafood wine), potatoes and applewood bacon was rich and very delicious. I took a bite of the asparagus and frisee salad with proscuitto with a little chive and truffle dressing, and a properly made poached egg. It was really fresh and refreshing. The presentation was impeccable and was like art. Definitely a 4 star to start.

Instead of regular monkfish, they had halibut "Meuniere" style served with rainbow chard, peas and some green. Very juicy fish with good crisp edges. A solid 4 stars.

The Wagyu kobe beef burger with conte cheese, 1 slice of butter lettuce, duck fat galette and choron sauce was good but the bun was a bit on the dry side. Pommes gaufrette was unfortunately soggy possibly because it was served in a small cup instead of a metal cone style container that would have given better air circulation for the packed frites.

It's a pretty slow evening, probably because it's rainy and was a Sunday. The service was phenomenal, nice and very informative.

Will have to come back to check out the brunch sometime.
author: T L.

description:
We were desperate to find a dinner resolve before our film at the SF Film Society, and after my initial craving for Peruvian at Fresca was dwindled by the ridiculous 2 1/2 hour wait for merely a bar seat for two, we stumbled upon this cute place tucked just a few blocks up.

It was a nice enough evening to enjoy a seat outside underneath the heated cafe-style terrace out front.  I ordered a superb Riz St Jacques seared scallops with creamy black rice risotto, with mild shallot vierge & citrus zest.. Delicious.

I am thankful that our handsome French waiter was very accommodating with our tight schedule, and I can't wait to enjoy another meal here when I am not in a rush.
author: Ty T.

description:
Really undecided if this place deserves a 4 star.  3.5 for now.

Came here for dinner.  We did asked our server how to say "Chouquet's", almost had it.  

Nice place, we sat by the window.  With the location, it's a good place to people watch.  

***Watch out for that open small window in the bathroom.  If people starts paying attention, they can actually see you doing your business in there - not good...or is it?

This is very French, meaning tiny portions.  The dishes were tasty but we left still hungry.  We ordered the salad with apples and walnuts and the flamenkuche to share.  And a plate each of the shrimp (8 pieces) in garlic and pastis.  I get it the shrimp was appetizer but a side of breador something would have been nice to dip in its creamy white sauce.

Nice service but lacking towards the end.  

Tip:  Always check out Groupon NOW for deals!
author: Pam S.

description:
I have been here twice, and both times with Groupons. My first time, I had gone on a Saturday night. The servers were nice and the food was good but not to say I have to go here again. 

Now the second time, it was so good, that I would defitnelty come back without the groupon.
We got there on a Monday night half an hour before our reservation and they were happy to seat us. We actually got the Pre fixed menu that is from 5:30-6:30pm. Do not know if its everyday, but it was really worth it. 

They also have and again do not know if its every night, but half of wine bottles, that if you do not finish you can take home. 

For entree I had the ahi tuna, with an arugula sald with cucumbers and a delish dressing. It was really really good. Defitnetly going back there again.
author: Sheyla A.

description:
I liked this place. not quite 4 stars, but a definite 3.5 star-worthy place.

I made a reservation through Savored for 30% off, but it didn't somehow register (not the first time it happened), but they were totally cool about it.

the place was almost as good as empty.. there were 2 other groups, and we ended up being the only two people eating in the place for a good half an hour.

service: very nice, attentive, and fast. 

atmosphere: it was perfect for the rainy san francisco sunday evening.. cozy, and warm!

food: overall good.. but nothing special to it. nothing necessarily blew me away, but i thought it was reasonably priced, and i enjoyed eating most of them.

appetizers: 
vegetable puree soup: very good, nicely seasoned.. nothing special.
chicken liver and duck pate mousse with acme bread: quite good, just as i expected them to be.

entrees:
boeuf bourgignon: it was good, not my favorite kind of food, but it definitely worked for the windy weather!
scallop risotto: maybe i expected too much from it, it was overall bland for my taste.. if you want to try this dish, go to Bistro Central Parc.. they do it so well.

dessert:
chocolate fondant with vanilla ice cream: weird, this was the best dish we had tonight. it was decadent, rich, and just great.. great!

I am not sure i'd go there anytime soon, but over it was a pleasurable experience.
author: Sung C.

description: Service was fine, food was ok, but it is barely french. The omelettes were ok, baguette based french toast was ok (if a bit burnt and under egged), but even the most touristy cafe I've eaten in Paris would have beaten them. I'd be surprised if anyone there was French or even learned to cook in France. For an American diner it was passable. As a French cafe it would have be out of business. One last thing a real Croque Monsieur/Madame is a sandwich between two slices of rich brioche, not an open-face on pain de campagne.
author: W D.

description:
My sisters took me here for lunch to celebrate my birthday.  

I love that this place has outdoor seating (WITH HEATERS... after all, it IS San Francisco, and we get that frequent chilly breeze).  The service was good, but nothing exceptional to rave about.  This seems to be a popular place for moms.  There were so many strollers along the outside patio.  

I ordered the Eggs Florentine and a glass of orange juice.  The eggs were poached perfectly.  My sisters ordered the Wagyu Kobe Beef Burger and an omelette (I forgot which one).  My sister ordered her burger medium rare, but they probably heard medium well.  =/  The fries were good, and it came in a cute little parchment cone.  The omelette was a bit dry for my taste.  Overall, the food here was ok.  The presentation of the food here was beautiful though.  

Price:
It costs around $15-$20 for an order of food + drink here. 

My overall experience here at Chouquet's was just ok.  As you can probably tell, I'm not all that enthused about it.  Oh, and I wish they had more than just one bathroom here.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
Eh, not so impressed.
Didn't want to wait in line at Sweet Maple for brunch so I wandered off to Chouguet's- wish i didn't

Ordered the french toast, expecting it to taste great considering this was a French restaurant after-all...Results, a large burnt slice of bread trying to pass as the breakfast dish! boo!
author: C M.

description:
Delicious. I came here and was pleased to find a small, cute little french restaurant. I ordered the Sandwich Thon which is the Ahi Tuna sandwich. From the very first bite, I was in love. There are incredible flavors exploding in your mouth as you chew, making you never want the experience to end. 

My friend ordered the chicken dish that I tried and it too, was amazing. Super tender and juicy, what more could you ask for?

The staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. The only thing I did not like was I felt their french fries and potato chips were overly greasy but the actual entree was amazing. 

Would definitely come back to eat here again!
author: Stephanie P.

description: I went to this place for a Saturday brunch with a couple of friends. We sat inside, had a nice table by the window with a great view of fillmore street. I tried the Salmon Benedict which was quite good, for dessert I had the French toast which was OK, but not impressive. The cappuccino was really good too. Overall, a solid choice for brunch.
author: Sasan A.

description: The food is great, but I'm lowering my star count because I am SO annoyed with Chouquets for spamming me. Ever since I reserved a table through Open Table, Chouquets has been sending me advertising emails every week.  I never opted into their marketing email list.  I have asked to be unsubscribed from their marketing list THREE times with no success.  This is unacceptable, and a great way to lose regular clients.
author: Sherri H.

description: This place is very bad.  The service is horrible and the food sub par at best.  Save your money and go somewhere else in the neighborhood as there are tons of other options.
author: S J.

description: A nice sunny spot for a Sunday brunch. The menu has a lot of standard French (or Americanized French?) breakfast and lunch dishes, plus some American standbys like a burger. The food was good, but nothing special. The staff were friendly and didn't hurry us.
author: Allison P.

description:
My friend wanted to try this place, we drove down on Thanks Giving week-end. We ordered 3 dishes and shared, I think the food was average. I can tell they used a lot of dairy as how my stomach reacted afterwards.....Some French food doesn't affect me so much though.

Anyways, realized I shouldn't do French at all......
author: Yoko S.

description:
Had a special occasion fixed price dinner here.  They fell completely flat, obviously not an accident given that it wasn't just one dish.

The place is neighborhood-y, cute and sincere... though with a little more sincerity they could step up their food quality.

Some of the dishes were pretty good.  There was some nice lamb.  Others were ridiculously bad.  Two salads for two people.  One was all greens with almost no topping, the other half the size with lots of toppings.  An amuse was semi-cold and tasteless.  Two dishes were next to inedible - first was a seafood rissoto of obviously not fresh seafood that came out room temperature.  When we asked if they had any way of warming it up the waitress helpfully said yes, then the same dish came back to us ladled with a lots of pasty untasty slightly sweet sauce.  The other was a dessert, some kind of berry tart or something.  It was watery and bland, as if someone had poured a quarter cup of tapwater on top.  I normally don't complain but when the waitress asked I mentioned it, and she tried to explain that that's what happens when you cook fresh berries.  Excuse me but I've made a pie before.

Overall, the food was so sad I was depressed.
author: Gil S.

description:
Love the vibe in this place!  Service is quick and friendly which I value quite a bit since I've served tables in the past.  And the filet...OMYGOD yum!  I've been back two times now and really felt I scored when I went for breakfast - omelettes are phenomenal and a must try, plus mimosas = perfect Saturday brunch.

Another cool thing I found out while I was there is they are paired up with MOGL so I get 10% cash back EVERY TIME I go.  Money for eating amazing food?? Um yes please! I signed up for MOGL at http://mo.gl/1yzi8s8 ...pretty good gig :)

All-in-all I am pretty obsessed with this place, service, location, food, and deals are 5 stars - I'll definitely keep going back
author: Lauren H.

description:
let it be known that this is the first time that I've felt compelled to write a review while still in the establishment being reviewed.   As I like to review based on the overall experience of a restaurant, I just felt that this place deserved a quick on-the-spot review.

The service here has been superb...both of the waitresses as well as the owner have been delightful the entire time, being friendly and taking a second to chat in passing even as the crowd picked up.  

The wine selection is pretty nice, and while I am no fine wine connesiuer, I can still tell when bad wine is well...bad...and this was a rather lovely pick by the waitress.  

The decor is modern & inviting, albiet a bit orange...but hey its french, whatcha gonna do?  Everything is clean and its not too loud, nor does a person feel too isolated, even sitting at the bar (which I currently am).  

Definitely enjoying my time here & will be sure to be back to enjoy the food more thoroughly in the future.
author: Justin Y.

description:
I was a little concerned about eating at this place. Every time we've walked by there were some empty tables and the other reviews seems mediocre at best. 

Boy was I surprised. First, I'll commend them on their wonderful customer service. The male waiter (with the sexy strong accent) was very helpful and he offered to pour us several wines to taste to ensure we were selecting a malbec that we liked. 

The food was fabulous. The smoked trout mache salad was so simple and yet so tasty. 

The scallops over a black risotto was very rich, but that's exactly what I wanted when ordering scallops. 

The shrimp dish elegant and we wiped up the sauce with the baguette they gave us. 

The mushroom ravioli was probably our least favorite dish, but it was still good. Just didn't like it as much as the others. 

We finished the meal off with their chocolate fondant (pretty much a chocolate lava cake) which was warm and gooey on the inside. The vanilla ice cream they served with it tasted like it was store bought. I would recommend purchasing a high quality vanilla bean ice cream from Three Twins, Bi-Rite, or any of the other gourmet ice cream places in SF and then just scoop some of that on the plate. 

Overall, it was a nice experience, and the food was great!
author: Philip H.

description:
Came here for Valentine's day with my wife. After making the reservation on Open table. I had walked by this restaurant a few times and was excited to try it out.  Our reservations were for 6:30 but showed up early at 6pm and they were able to accomodate us early.   I wasn't too happy with the Price  Fix menu since it rarely, if ever, is a good deal.  The portions were very small (even smaller than other french restaurants). The initial appetizer was good but tiny. The squash and "microscopic"  truffle soup was o.k but was luke warm at best and could have filled a shot glass.  For the entree,  I ordered the Rack of lamb which was more of a rack of parakeet and not very warm either.  The dessert,  small chocolate cake was very good.  

Overall, I felt the service and delivery speed was  good.  After spending $180  (Taxes and tip) for just food (Didn't drink the champagne),   we were both still hungry.  So I left with an empty stomach but also an empty wallet. I even thought about hitting up the frozen yogurt place on the way home, but was stopped by the wife.
author: Mike T.

description: This might be a suitable restaurant in an up and coming neighborhood where your only options are burritos or fast food. Up and coming this neighborhood is certainly not and so I can't over look the poor food and atmosphere provided.        First off the furnishings are cheap. The table and chairs looked and felt like they were purchased in Target's outdoor section. They were super flimsy feeling. They served the wine in a fluorescent green plastic ice bucket. It was made of pool toy material and certainly did not belong on a table.    The food didn't taste fresh! Both my BF and I had the muddles. The sauce was nice but the mussels had been frozen for too long. The fries were old. I did like the aioli but when I'm spending 20 dollars I shouldn't have to fill up on bread.  One of the people we were with got the croque-madame. FYI they can't make it with out the ham because it's made ahead of time.        It looks cute, but just look, don't for any reason eat here.
author: Corey Jace W.

description: We went to this place for a Sunday brunch with a couple of friends. The food was very good And the service very fast. I'll be back!
author: Nathalie S.

description:
Came here for Vday dinner with my hubby. I made the reservation 3 weeks ahead of time with really high hopes.  You can tell where this review is going. 

We showed up early for our 6:30 table. Hostess escorted for outside seating (it was 50 degrees with draft) and promised the overhead heaters would keep us warm. Lies. We kept our wool coats on the WHOLE time. A few other customers who they tried to seat outside left after they felt the draft. Only one other couple was brave enough to sit outside under the other heater.  It's not like it was romantic anyway, if anyone else sat outside, there was only 6 inches between tables.

Food was underwhelming and unforgettable. Dessert took FOREVER.  The other couple who finished dinner AFTER us got their dessert before us. We asked to take the dessert to go since the cold weather was giving us cramps.  When we got home,  it looked ugly and tasted blah.

Next year, we're going Johnny Rockets for Valentine's Day dinner.
author: Irene D.

description:
This is a very cute place that has a neighborhood feel of Pac Heights.  We came here for brunch and I was expecting the food to be better than it was.  Brunch in the city is a Sunday tradition but menus lately seem to be very similar and not well executed.  

I ordered the omelet with spinach, mushrooms and goat cheese and was pretty disappointed.  The eggs were overcooked to the point of being somewhat rubbery, the mushrooms were flavorless and so was the goat cheese.  I think overall it's pretty disappointing when you go out for brunch, especially on a cold rainy day and end up thinking I could have been at home, warm and eating a much better omelet.  

My friends seemed to like their coffee and dishes, but I think I'm far more critical of omelettes and expect the traditional French preparation where the eggs are full of air and extremely tender.
author: Inga W.

description:
WOW! 

Tartlette of goat cheese & roasted tomato with balsamic sauce -
I don't think I've ever tasted goat cheese prepared as unique and amazing as this before. The roasted tomatoes were delicious. It was THE perfect appetizer!

Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad -
The potatoes were really good, but the salad as a whole wasn't anything special. It's definitely a good choice if you want something light to begin your meal.

Black Risotto with scallops and prawns -
I've always been a huuuge fan of Risotto, and this was definitely one of the best Risottos I've ever had. Scallops tasted fantastic. Highly recommend this for entree.

7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes -
Lamb at its best. Sooo soft and juicy, it was perfection. The mashed potatoes tasted really weird though. Buuut the lamb made up for it.

I forgot the names of the desserts we had, but everything was faaabulous. There was this one dessert that had bananas with chocolate... that was my absolute favorite. They also had this tasty apple tart which of course I loved.

The owner of the restaurant was very friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere was cozy and intimate. Portions are small, but the food is pretty rich, so you won't feel starved or anything. Love love love Chouquet's!
author: Christine A.

description: Love the salmon! It was so fresh and crispy on the outside. The creme Brûlée was delicious also!
author: Michelle J.

description: There was a hair in my food. The server apologized and took it back. I was disappointed though that we did have to pay for it. The omelette was not cooked correctly. It was over cooked     They folded the eggs into the over cooked veggies instead of cooking them with the eggs.   I do not write reviews very often but after going there, I wanted to let others know so they can save money.
author: Cat A.

description: As a Southern Californian up in SF for a few days, Chouquet was a great place to go. I went and had dinner with my aunt, who lives in Pacific Heights, and she had a groupon for the restaurant, so we decided to go there for dinner. We ended up sharing a few things. One of the things we got were the muscles, which were so good. We also shared the scallops; also delicious. This place was definitely nice and worth checking out if you want French food :)
author: Meagan T.

description:
Stopped off here Saturday morning, while waiting for a friend to meet me on this corner for a stroll.  I sat at the bar and ordered only sparkling wine.  I will be back to have brunch outside, though. While I don't speak French, and everyone around me did (waiters/waitresses, and customers alike - what a nice surprise!  I felt like I was transported), everyone was very friendly, and it seems like a welcoming place for regulars.

The food looks delicious, and the outdoor seating is ideal.  I could have sat here all day just listening to everyone speak in warm, excited tones, in a language I don't know, but love just the same. I am marking this on my list as a walkable brunch destination, perfect for sunny days and relaxation.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Eh, I just don't know why I payed 14 dollars for a pear & goat cheese salad.  It was small, somewhat wilted  and  just plain lacking enthusiasm.  It was a seat yourself situation and the tables did not get cleaned until after we sat down.  My concern was that I'd pay alot for a generic meal and a salad would be safe.  It was safe, but too safe.

The only thing considerably authentic about this french spot  is the waitresses, but hey.... at least the orange juice was good.
author: Hannah A.

description:
I love Chouquet's, it's a very great little french restaurant with a lovely outside.
Very nice staff hepful and attentive.
My favorites : Mushrooms Raviole, The Wagyu beef kobe burger and they make wonderful french tries also !
author: Tatia C.

description:
Chouquets is darling, cozy and refined. What was it about Friday, besides for staying up spontaneously late into the wee hours of the morning, getting all sorts of lucky perks. We found parking right in front of the restaurant and were seated at a corner table which I had pointed out from outside and had mental dibs on. I like that this restaurant sits on the corner street and is lined with glass windows. 

Came here with a  group of three, a fourth arrived later- after the entrees but before dessert- and was accommodated immediately and even given his own bill at the end- this gesture, truly makes for a skilled and observant server! We shared the mussels, it was heavenly, perfect broth, perfect everything (I'm going to try to copy this at home). I always prefer my shellfish in white wine over red wine. Came with a side of skinny, non greasy fries. Two of us ordered the Riz St Jacques - the scallops were perfect but the black risotto- whoa, the black risotto with visible melted butter on top was divine. I never knew risotto could be so succulent, it wasn't mushy or watery, it had the perfect consistency. My friend ordered Cassoulet, Muscovy duck legs cooked in confit, I wish I tried this to provide some kind of reference but I was too full and content with my own plate. We kept the drinks coming, I had the wine that tasted like a peach Bellini, it was iced and thirst quenching. My friends tried the port and other wines, not one bad wine.  
For dessert, it was chocolate cake with a rich fudge-filling that oozed out and filled the air with great sweetness. I'll upload pictures shortly. 

Say what you will about the French. I like French people and French food and can't wait to visit its country, planning is in the works. The food is outstanding and not heavy, the server is a complete doll. She humored back with us a couple times and took absolute care of us. As we were the second to last table to exit, I couldn't help but tell the guy holding open the door, "I'm going to write you a 5 Star Review on Yelp". So mark my words, here I am. 

What was even more memorable was the sound of an opera singer coming from within the kitchen, we debated whether he was a real man or whether it was music beaming from the speakers. We finally settled on the fact that it was a happy chef and continued to hear his melodic voice echo and accompany us all the way to the end of the street. 

What a lovely end to the beginning of a long night. 
Merci.
author: Thuy M.

description:
Visited Chouquet's last Saturday night for the first time...and it was grand!
My wife and I, who eat out often and are not easily impressed, loved the place. Read many of the reviews here-and they were so negative....we almost avoided the place. We are glad we trusted the positive reviews more. We had the trout salad-fabulous. We had the soup du jour (vegetable puree with cream)-fabulous. We had the mussels-fabulous. We had the chocolat fondat-fabulous. We tried one white and two different red wines as well as the kronenburg beer on tap-fabulous.
We sat outside in the warm evening air-fabulous. The service was low key california, breezy and friendly fun-not snooty french. Nice place, good food, nice people....gee....what is not to like? Prices are reasonable, portions are decent, parking is not impossible....this is about as good as it gets for french in the city. In a word....FABULOUS.
author: Laurence T.

description:
My husband and I paid a visit here on a romantic dinner date. We ordered three appetizer, two entree and a dessert, which was a bit too much food. but everything looked so good on the menu. We were especially impressed by the presentation of the mussels, served with french fries in the cup. The salad and escargot were both really good. My husband had the mushroom ravioli and  I had the lamb for entree. I thought the mushroom ravioli was better than the lamb. We finished the meal with creme brulee, which was a pretty big size and also pretty good. We took some of the ravioli and lamb home and ate it the next day for lunch, everything heated up well. 

the restaurant wasn't so busy, not sure if it's because we went right after Christmas. The waiter seemed like a real French guy with the accent and all, which always makes a French restaurant more interesting. it also impresses me that his English was so good, as they didn't speak so well when I went to Paris. the ambiance is also nice, being seated next the window we got to do a bit of people watch. the only thing was it was a bit cold in the restaurant. I wore a dress, but kept my coat on for half of the time.
author: Cicie W.

description: This is my 2nd time here and I'm wondering how it is not packed! This place is amazing. Maybe not the French ambiance for a dinner you expect but the food is phenomenal! This is a 100% must for any San Fran trip.
author: Andrew C.

description: I really enjoy this place for brunch. The coffee is good, the servers are very nice. I always sit outside with my dog, and they bring her water. The food is great, but portions are smaller than you're typical American brunch place (as this is a French restaurant).  The only thing stopping me from giving it a five star is that the service can be slow.
author: Alison M.

description:
This is one of my new neighborhood go to places! I honestly thought I had already been here,  but I guess not! They recently revamped their menu, which most people like in a restaurant, but I miss some of their old dishes. Some of the best ones are still there though: their trout salad appetizer - yum! Definitely get that. I got the flamenkuche, which was good, but didn't live up to some of the other appetizers. The endives salad is also really delicious.

For entrees I really like the lamb. It was perfectly cooked and the sauce was delicious. The desserts at this place are AMAZING. The chocolate fondant is to die for, I come here just for that. The new banana hazlenut option is also really good. 

The bad news is that the service here, while nice, is incredibly slow. I've only been on the weeknights until recently, so the restaurant was pretty empty. I went this Saturday and it was PACKED. What I thought was a cute quiet restaurant had turned into some crowded loud joint. So I recommend going on a night off during the week, you'll get faster service and you'll be able to hear your friends better. Other than that, enjoy!
author: Ashley H.

description: This was a waste of time and a disappointment. The place was empty on a Saturday night, likely for a reason. Food is overpriced and mediocre. Only plus is the service, friendly staff.
author: M K.

description:
No bread, cold, slow service. That is the brief explanation. 
When I arrived they said the only seats was outside. They said "It is warm outside under the heater".
author: Rowland D.

description: Sorry to say this place had nothing to offer.  We were able to get a last minute reservation on Valentines day so decided to give it a try.  The lobster bisque could have been out of a can.  I was excited to get lamb, potato gratin and green beans for my main course but each element was inedible.  I love lamb so much that I wouldn't have thought it possible but this lamb had a strange, off taste.  The gratin was too sweet and the green beans were too oily.  If it had been a nice olive oil that would not be terrible but the oil was bland and just tasted greasy.  Our waiter was nice but lacked skill.  The runner was working hard, maybe picking up he slack for the waiter but he had a roughness about him when he slammed candles, plates and silver on the table that was a little extreme.  Was he mad at the waiter?  For a much nicer experience in the neighborhood I would suggest Curbside Café.
author: Amy R.

description:
WORM in my husband's salad!!!

I must be on a roll in the last days with this round of bad restaurants. The bad mojo must be spreading to my poor husband too.

We had brunch there today-we have gone a lot. We ordered an omelet for him and I had my usual trout salad. The service was a little too quick. We ordered our food and ten minutes later, it was there..

He ate his omelet. And then I was working on my salad.

He's more than half way through his food when I spot a green worm in salad. I point it out to the waiter. He removes the plate.

From there, the service went on a cliff. They removed the salad from him. but there was no acknowledgement of what happened. I am still working on my salad and they bring us the bill as to rush us out of there. They did, however, give us a discount of $12.

There isn't even an offer for coffee or dessert. They gingerly treat us like we are lepers.

Look, you guys left a worm in a diner's salad. A WORM. Try to be nicer about it. Don't pretend that we are no longer eating at your restaurant. Don't shove the bill at us when the other person is still eating.

Well, we are not going back. 

Unless you want an Anthony Bourdain experience of eating worms for protein, I think you might want to give this place a miss.
author: Peggy B.

description: This is one of our go to places for Brunch with our little Maltese.  Food is always good.  Staff if friendly.  Awesome fries and delicious Benedicts. Ample seating outside. Even if it is cold they have heaters and can enclose the area to keep out the wind.
author: Jerry W.

description: I used to really like it here - until one evening my and bf ordered oysters and 2 out of the 12 were rotten! It was so gross I may never eat oysters again...best part was server didn't even offer to comp us for them so we fully paid for rotten oysters and that was the end of Choquet's for us. Its a shame because they have some good stuff and location is good but obviously need to clean up their act a bit.
author: L.B. B.

description:
Normally I don't write negative reviews about a place I've been to once- most places deserve a redemption day. This review is an exception.

The service was poor. Let's just say they don't manage a sunny patio well. And that they don't know how to "let the customer be right" when it comes to them messing up two dishes for two people. 

If the menu offered something worth coming back for, I would in a heartbeat, because as an ex server, I know every restaurant has a bad day. But for an extremely average overpriced omelet, bah. There are so many wonderful brunch spots in SF - this one shall just be erased from my memory. Should have gone down to Crepe Vine where we originally planned to meet.
author: Meredith R.

description: Have been going here for six years. Just went for brunch and was surprised by the following 1) rose was corked and only after debate was it swapped.  2) entrees were brought w the appetizer which is really rude and rushed. 3) steak AU poivre was brought with no sauce. After I ate half I asked about the sauce and it was brought. Service has gone downhill for sure perhaps the food as well.
author: Honest A.

description: This place is amazing !! I was itching for French food, especially since the boyfriend hadn't had it before. I had the fig-stuffed pork medallion dinner special and he had salmon. Both were to die for ! I'm drooling just thinking about it. We sat outside because it was a packed restaurant for a chilly Friday evening. There was an awning over our heads and heat lamps so it was pretty cute. Our waiter was great too ! Would def come back.
author: Mai N.

description: I came here with some friends for Dine About Town, and it was great.  I ordered the escargot, mussels, and creme brulee, and all of it was fantastic.  The food was spaced out perfectly so it's great for a longer night of conversation with friends and good eats.  The ambiance of this restaurant is really cozy; there were maybe 12 tables tops inside, and they had a heated patio outdoors.  Glad we made this choice!
author: Mel G.

description: On way to the pet decided to have breakfast. Seating outside was nice and the person that finally sat us was very nice. Food was good but service is bad. Waited forever for coffee and bill. Forget that no one checked how everything was, when we requested a second cup of coffee and cream the gentleman asked "cream too???" I said yes and he rolled his eyes. When he returned I said "it's a problem requesting cream?" He said "no no". I'm in no restaurant business but that's a slightly rude attitude. Will we go back? Doubt it especially that food was average too. No love lost.
author: Aziz S.

description: We had a good dinner at Chouquet's. The most memorable part of the meal is the escargot with buttery puff pastry. I like that dish. Aside from that, we can eat this meal pretty much in a lot of other similar restaurants in the City. We did get pretty good service and our waiter kind of reminded me of Sean Penn but without all the wrinkles.
author: Missy X.

description: Went tonight for dinner. Had to wait a bit for a table. The bar doesn't serve alcohol, bummer. It is just a sitting spot.  But the meal was good. Butter lettuce salade and braised lamb dish. Delisious!
author: Karen F.

description:
This is easily my least favorite restaurant on Fillmore (perhaps in all of San Francisco?). This is extremely unfortunate, since it's literally a block away from my apartment, but even that level of convenience could not drive me to eat here again.

Chouquet's is perfect if you're looking for horrible food and mediocre service as a premium price. While I've been to Chouquet's many times, and experienced the lackluster food and inattentive service each time, the proximity to my apartment kept me coming back, but after my last meal there I don't think I can put myself through it again.

The day after a late night out with friends visiting from out of town, I meandered over to Chouquet's for brunch with my visitors. I was craving something really hearty so I ended up ordering the "Wagyu Burger" (I highly doubt this was Wagyu beef) which was something like $13. Now I'm more than willing to pay for a good hamburger, but what was brought to my table was the most pathetic excuse for a hamburger I have ever seen. The pale gray/brown color of the perfectly round/obviously de-frosted patty was hard to even look at. It reminded me of some sort of frozen/microwaveable beef dish you might find at Wal-Mart. On top of this patty sat 1 strip of bacon that looked like it had been under a heating lamp since the previous weekend - dry, flavorless, and with the same gray undertones of the patty. All of this was served atop a bun that dwarfed the undersized beef patty. I somehow managed to eat the entire thing along with the soggy french fries even without 1 refill of my water glass the entire meal. I wanted to ask for more water but I didn't want to interrupt the very interesting conversation all the waiters were having while we went unattended.

When I finished the meal, I sat there feeling as if I had just been robbed. In a city with some of the most amazing restaurants in the country, there is NO reason to ever eat at Chouquet's. Unfortunately 1-star is as low as I can go with this rating, but it really doesn't even deserve that.
author: Marc C.

description:
I just had the Moules Normandes and they were spectacular.
Dessert was ok. I would definitely go back, even just for the Moules! :)
author: Peppe R.

description:
Well, I was on a streak of good restaurants reviews but here comes one I hate to write...I'll keep it short and to the point.  Came here for a sunday brunch and here are my thoughts:

1) It shouldn't take 45 minutes to cook an omelette & throw in a bowl of fruit

2) Waitress never checked in once with us during this ridiculous wait 

(there's nothing more bothersome than seeing the couple who ordered after you, finish their dish while your table has unused utensils and an empty bread bowl....)

3) They get 1 star for finally apologizing at the end.

Sorry Chouquet...won't be back.
author: Darren B.

description:
I wasn't wowed by dinner, but it's a great spot for a nice lunch. Especially on sunny days! My fave is the shrimp salad with arugula, grapefruit and cute little tomatoes...4 star dish. The croques are good too. I've usually had good service. Almost a 4 star joint, but it's not cheap. 

Still, occasionally Well Fed Ted heads in and hangs out where the "ladies who lunch" lunch, 'cause there's not enough South-facing (sunny side) sidewalk tables to be found on a nice day in SF.
author: Ted R.

description: What a wonderful find. I asked for steak tartar instead of Filet Mignon. I got extra score for that!
author: Andrey P.

description: The perfect escape from the busy city. Irene (our server) was warm and genuine, recommending the perfect wine- at a reasonable price point- to complement this autumn day. Her service won us over immediately and made us feel at home. The food was classic French cuisine- simple with fine ingredients and absolutely suburb. Highly recommended.
author: Katy S.

description: I got food poisoning from the smoked salmon Benedict.  I am absolutely sure of it - it was the only meal I ate all day.
author: Alex M.

description:
Check out their brunch, skip it for dinner.
Their croque monsieur is my favorite in the city- thin crispy bread, covered with a delicious layer of ham, gruyere and bechamel, served with a tasty salad. Divine. Omelettes are also excellent. Burger is delicious, served with perfect fries. Fresh baked croissants are excellent!
I've only been there once for dinner, and think that explains the overall 3 star yelp rating. Nothing was impressive- all either too salty or too bland. Not sure where the disconnect is but just stick with brunch and don't bother figuring that out.
author: Maggie Z.

description:
This is a great neighbourhood restaurant.  The food selection is great and so are their wines by the glass and it's not a pretentious setting.  I love their Salade Lyonnaise (very light and refreshing, try the Scallops with risotto , and the molten chocolate cake for dessert is yummy.  I've had other dishes and they were consistently good apart from the steak.

It's an overall safe and consistent place to head to either for brunch or dinner.
author: Favoloso M.

description: We came for brunch after walking around one of the Fillmore festivals. We had mimosas, the smoked salmon benedict, and a croque madame, but honestly it wasn't too memorable. Maybe it's better for dinner? During the day it was pretty empty, though the people eating outside always look like they're having a good time.. May come back to check out the dinner, but would advise to skip the brunch.
author: Vivian C.

description:
If it wasn't for the staff Anton, this place would just be your average eatery.  

The food was just Ok.  Never knew rare ahi tuna was a french cuisine. It seems as though they are trying to change with the times.  Different items on the menu. updating certain items on their menu to satisfy the crowd.

Ahi Tuna.............it was aite
chicken...............very boring, just a half chicken on the plate with nothing else.  I should have taken a picture.  It had a side of fries that came with it but no vegetables.
the wagyu burger  It was ok.  Nothing really special.  16 dollars.
salmon............looked good and my friend said it tasted good.  Looked very 80ish  Bed of mashed potatoes with some peas and carrots.

I would actually go as far as saying the food is probably 2.5 stars and the service was 1.5 stars.

Anton, our server, was amazing.  I never had such great service in a long time.  Allowed us to sample wines, so we ended up buying a bottle.  Then at the end of our meal he gave us a round of port wine for dessert.

Take note Chouquet.  You need more staff like Anton.  He is probably the only reason why I would come back.
author: jason g.

description:
Just got back from having brunch there and we left on a bad note.  This is our second visit here and  we decided to come back because we were hoping for the same good food and service we enjoyed on our first time.

My wife had the omelette and I had the burger.  The food took awhile but it was sort of busy, everyone was running around.  When the food finally came, it was just dropped off and the server kept on running.  It would of been nice to ask if we needed anything else since ketchup goes well on an omelette, burger and fries.  I even left my empty glass of lemonade so they may get the idea that I would like a refill.  We both sat there trying to get someone's attention and after a few minutes, we got the attention of the bartender.  We asked him for some ketchup and mayo, he went into the kitchen, came back out and forgot about us.  While we were waiting for some service, I was able to get a hold of some Tabasco by walking out of the restaurant and grabbing it from an outside table.

After seeing our server bussing some tables, which must be more important than checking up on her tables, we finally got her attention and finally got some ketchup and mayo.  By this time, my wife's ice tea and my lemonade were empty, sitting at the edge of the table.  You would think that the server would notice this since it's the first thing you see when you approach the table but, clueless.  We did get our refills after flagging her down again but at the end of our meal.

Couple of other things that bothered us were seeing the bartender wiping down the counter and dump the crumbs onto the floor right in front of us.  Also, seeing the busser pick up our plates then wipe down our table with one of our napkins.  

We were planning to have desserts but why waste our money and time here. Yea, we had a good experience the first time but you only need one bad service to ruin an experience.
author: danny m.

description:
** Dinner **

2.5 Stars.

It was just ok.  Service was ok, food was ok.  

I ordered pork tenderloin, my companion ordered the ahi.  I think we also ordered an appetizer, but it never came.

Unfortunately, there's nothing very inspiring to write about.  I don't think I'd return.

Sorry Chouquet - though I'd love to have a French boyfriend, I don't think you're him.

Bonne chance.
author: brandie y.

description:
I tried this place out on the Dine About Town offer. It's been a while since I had French.

I wouldn't classify this place as I would a classical French restaurant. Chouquet's is far more casual and modern. I had the gazpacho soup as a starter and the Croc Monsieur sandwich as the main course. I've never had gazpacho soup or any cold soup before - it was cool and refreshing and the buttered crostini with roasted garlic butter provided a salty and creamy contrast to the soup. The sandwich was weird in the fact you have to eat with a fork and a knife - it's a open face toasted ham and Gruyere cheese sandwich. 

The service was pretty adequate, and I'd come back again. This place is one of the most casual French establishments I've been to.
author: Navi T.

description:
Dinner at Chouquet's was so forgettable it doesn't even merit a full review.  The smoked trout, fingerling & mache salad was bland, the filet of beef was tough and not cooked as I had ordered, and the dessert was the most disgusting thing ever ... some sort of Nutella crumble tart that tasted like dirt.  And to boot, the prices are in line with other SF restaurants that serve much higher caliber food.  Me thinks not.    

The fact that the restaurant was dead on a Saturday evening at 8 p.m. should've been an indication.  I'll never come back here again!
author: Doug V.

description: Amazing brunch! The best mussels (in creamy white wine sauce) I've ever had.
author: Maria S.

description:
My favorite salad joint in the city. 

The smoked trout with fingerling potatoes and mache salad is no joke. I come here just for this salad. It's just that amazing. The greens that they use for this is always so perfectly crisp and the dressing melds well with the smoked trout. The fingerling potatoes are a fantastic touch to keep the flavors from overpowering each other. 

The service here is super excellent. Always very pleasant and attentive. Dog friendly! They'll even bring a bowl of water for your pup if you decide to bring one along.
author: Vanessa M.

description: Went there for brunch because all other brunch spots in the area had an hour wait. Food was definitely good, the price tag didn't exactly match. I had the frisée salad, yummy but not $13 yummy. I might try dinner sometime.
author: Adele A.

description:
Will not be returning after they forgot to put in our order and then rushed to get it to our table without checking if it was actually done. I ordered a burger and it was RAW. No, not undercooked and pinky red, but totally raw. Like blood was pooling on the plate after my first bite. Heck, I like rare beef, but not when it's nearly alive! Had to set it aside, take it home and cook it some more before I could finish it.

BF's veggie gnocchi was pretty disgusting. Gnocchi was flavorless. Didn't have any sauce on it and was served on a bed of nearly raw, hardly steamed veggies. It tasted like they washed the veggies, chopped them and served it straight up. They add a foam to the top of the dish which added no flavor in the slightest, and actually made it less appetizing.

Service was pretty terrible. Waitress forgot to smile most of the night and didn't notice waters were sitting empty until she remembered that she forgot our dishes as well.

mega-fail, too bad too since it used to be a cute neighborhood-y place that we went to.
author: Jen P.

description:
I've been here twice now.  Once for brunch and once for dinner on a Monday night.  Brunch was about a year ago and it was good, but nothing amazing which is why I didn't write a review.  I would give it three stars.  

Fast forward to dinner on Monday night (July 4th) and I have to bump it up a notch.  Half off all bottles of wine on Monday!  I really like their appetizer selection.  Kobe beef tar tar, salad with a fried egg and bacon, escargot and the soup of the day: tomato garlic.  We probably could have skipped the main course which was rack of lamb, but it's real hard to skip that.  My only complaint is that the tar tar was little heavy with mustard, but I still enjoyed it.  It's a great date place, but get there early cause as soon as we sat down the dinner rush came in and the place was packed.
author: Corey V.

description:
DOG FRIENDLY.  There, I SHOUTED IT FROM THE ROOFTOPS!  YAY!  I didn't come here for dinner, but lunch.  I came here on a rather typical bi-polar -- RAIN/SUNSHINE/OVERCAST/SUNSHINE -- afternoon in San Francisco with some friends from LA with their ADORABLE pooch extraordinaire, MILO.  I don't own a dog, so I would have no clue of where to go on such a day.  I thank friends on YELP for suggesting Chouquet's.  Cute, quaint with a very handsome server.  I enjoyed my omelette parisienne, coffee and friends (and their handsome, MILO).  

All in all, moderately priced, but worth every penny for outdoor, covered, heated, dog-friendly service.

Merci!
author: Hiromi N.

description: Just ruined my dinner date.  Bad customer service and confusing wine menu.  Waitress cannot explain the quantity of ML's in carafe, bottle or mini bottle and knows the list is misleading.  Manager did not like our suggestions about his wine list and the list deceptively lists the same item with different prices so you pay double.  Bad customer Service!
author: Fnu R.

description:
Went here on a restaurant.com coupon... won't be back.  And would never go here full-price (why bother, when there are so many other French bistros that are better?)

We had a bad feeling when the bread came out cold and hard.  

Starters were sad.  :( 
- lavender honey ribs - incredibly overcooked.  when our server asked us how things were going, we told him it was very dry & overcooked.  He didn't do anything to make the situation better, just told us that was the style of the ribs.  Even if the ribs were meant to be on the dry side (e.g., not the super fatty American style bbq ribs), these ribs were awful - stick in your throat overcooked dry.
- clam chowder - nice flavor, but incredibly salty.  Like eating a salt mine salty.

Entrees:
- rack of lamb - Ok.  Nice flavor, not too gamey, but I've had better.  Texture was a little off - usually like to get a nice sear on the lamb, with the medium rare inside, but this was just kind of mushy all around.  We were sad to have missed the braised lamb shoulder for which this place has gotten such good reviews.  The rack of lamb was just ok, nothing great. 
- mussels with pommes frites - Ok.  Nothing to write home about.  Some of them seemed overcooked and not too fresh.  Fries were a little limp, not piping hot.  

Dessert:
By the time dessert rolled around, we just wanted to get out of this place.  Was tempted to order the chocolate fondant (Yelpers have said great things, it looked decent) but was just exasperated at being served lackluster food with too much sodium.  

Service:
Eh.  Tried to be nice to us but they were surprisingly slow despite the fact that the restaurant was only ever half-full the whole time.  

Overall - won't be back!  I would have been really unhappy if I had paid full price, but given that we used a coupon, I just cut my losses and now know never to go back.
author: Annie M.

description: I like this place a lot.  Casual, not fancy atmosphere.  I enjoy their dinners better than their brunches.  However, the smoked trout salad is very good!
author: Laura G.

description:
Good:
Great location
Looks cozy from the outside

Average:
The service.

Below Average:
The food. 
The wine (temperature)


One of us had scallops, the other one the flatbread.  Both of us had white wine (I do not recall which). If you like better food, then this place is not for you. It was completely bland and it felt oldish and from mediocre quality. The wine was far too cold.

Would not go there again.
author: Debbie S.

description: Just had dinner here before a Bach Christmas Choir concert at the Calvary Church a block away.  There were six of us.  The service was fast, attentive and pleasant.  The food was great.  The lamb in the lamb stew was incredibly tender and delicious.  The filet mignon was also incredibly tender and perfectly cooked. I had the foie gras terrine which was full of foie gras and went great with the sweetened pickled onions. I had moules mariniere which was very good. We tried the floating island and the apple tatin.  Both were very tasty.  Everybody enjoyed the meal. Although the place was almost full, the noise level was pleasant.  We could hear each other easily at a six person table.  It was also nice and warm on a cold night.  I was pleasantly surprised by the whole experience because Yelp tacked a comment saying that this place had a poor health score. We almost canceled our reservation. However, as far as I could tell because my table was facing a window through which you could see the chef and other cooks, the kitchen seemed clean and the chef seemed to be keeping standards of cleanliness.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
The outside seating and location here seem to capture the essence of a European cafe. Although it's French it reminded me of a little place in the Cinque Terre in Italy. Chouquet therefore scores a full extra star for that.

Service was excellent and the eggs benidict was good too. The side salad was delish. I may actually go back for a Saldana because they looked really tasty.
author: Adam O.

description:
So it was a beautiful sunny day and we come in all enticed by the " menu" and the ambiance but it was all washed away by the oh-not-so-good attitude of the waitress. When we walked in, we asked her how much the wait was and she was like 10 minutes and " you're next". So one person who probably came after us sat down and we thought may be we were after them and the waitress was probably mistaken. It was almost 25 minutes to the wait and we saw another table getting cleared out and we were about to sit down when the waitress sat someone else instead of us. Man! What attitude. I think the owner needs to keep a "check" on his waitresses. If this is the attitude the customers get even before ordering food, let alone the attitude they will get after ordering the food.

So we walked away and told the guy who was cleaning a table (not the server) that we were going elsewhere, the waitress saw that and she didn't even apologize. Now I think this is what you call "service". On the other hand, we went to this quaint little cute cafe called Curbside cafe and the service and the food were outstanding.
author: Priyanka T.

description: This place has changed a lot in 4 years. Last time I was here was in 08 and I gave it 5 stars. What a disapointment. The staff are still nice but the food sucked. The filet mignon was overdone even though I asked for medium rare. The potatoes au gratin were crunchy raw. The sauce on the filet mignon was flavorless mushroom goop. They used to have amazing french fries. Now they are soggy like a bad fast food joint. Wtf happened to this place? It used to be a neighborhood gem! Pretty much everything across the board sucked. Maybe they changed the chef. Whatever. After paying $180 for 3 people, I'm not coming back. We're in SF and thankfully we have choice, plenty of french places around worth trying for less than that.
author: N S.

description:
My boyfriend and I found this cute little french place one afternoon while strolling around the city. It is conveniently located. it has  a great outdoor area which is awesome in a sunny afternoon, for coffee or just a nice glass of wine. Their Nicoise Salad is excellent & the wait staff (All French) is super friendly and nice. i notice they do remember you if you go there a few times like we had in the last few months. 
The food is great for both brunch and dinner. Nothing is over priced and their expresso est magnifique.
The overall experience is great.
