I hate to read reviews of people that go to a restaurant once and they feel entitle to give a place a bad review... I'm sure they are the ones sitting in a table being LOUD and oblivious about the people sitting around them. bless their hearts.
Anyway, if you want to try a good place with a nice french atmosphere this is your place.
author: Giorgio L.

description: Favorite part about Chouquet is the ample outdoor seating and dog friendly atmosphere. Great for brunch on Fillmore on a sunny day. Dinner is just ok.
author: Eric N.

description:
I was very pleased with Chouquet's. It is not La Folie, it is not Fleur de Lys, but it does not try to be. It is perfect at being what it is  -  a French bistro. The people who work there are French and extremely friendly. They were all genuinely happy and added to the good aura in the place. 

For the food...some dishes are really good and some are solid, but not amazing. I ordered a lentil soup, not realizing it was a pure. It was fine, nice, but nothing shocking or exciting. I've had better lentil soup from a box. My main course, however, was a true pleasure - lamb braised for hours fell apart on my plate. I lightly touched it with my fork and it fell apart into dozens of little pieces on my plate.  For lamb lovers, it is a must. Or for truffle lovers, it is a must as it is accompanied by a simple yet addictive tear-drop shaped pile of truffle mashed potatoes. It's total comfort food.

The tarte tatin is classic and well-executed - I'm a bit confused why people talk about apple sauce on Yelp in regards to it. Yes, the apples are caramelized and tender, much more so than apple pie, but they're not pureed! 

My only gripe is the corkage fee - $20 a bottle? Ouch. Overall, it is a quaint, bona fide French bistro with a typical trendy S.F. restaurant price tag. I was pleased and my expectations met, but I would not give it "exceeds expectations" except on service, where I truly got service with a genuine smile.
author: Kara A.

description:
Great little place to enjoy a taste of France.  Escargot served already shelled were very tasty, but not too rich.  Filet mignon was perfectly done medium rare, with a little more fat than I usually see in this cut (which is a good thing!).  

Dining room is small and cozy.  Service was attentive.  We had no special requests and no issues.  Just good food.
author: Stephen F.

description: We had a mediocre brunch here, wasn't bad but you could get the quality at any decent breakfast spot. The biggest turn-off was the service. The waitress was more concerned with chatting up the bar tender than paying any attention to us. Oh, and please don't be snooty over mediocre eggs benedict. I wish my tip would have gone to the bus-boy, he was great.
author: Hop I.

description:
Food was ok, but my wife got food poisoning from the steak tartare.  She had to run to the restroom as we were getting ready to leave the place... thank god no-one was in there.    I quietly told two of the staff... one of them gave her a glass of water, and they kind of apologized.   I would have expected more concern and some kind of compensation for the fact that they poisoned her.   Oh well. 

By the way my wife has never had this kind of reaction to any food the entire 7 years I've known her.   She says she's never had this experience in her whole life.
author: Jason M.

description:
Food: 2.75 stars 
Ambiance: 3 
Service: 3 
Price: $15 (pre-tax/tip) 
What we had: Croque madame and smoked salmon Benedict 

Potential, but in the end, disappoints all around. Partir maintenant! 

Sadly, I must concur with the plethora of reviews that warn against the matter-of-fact service that leave you feeling unwelcomed and unappreciated. The decor does not fair much better with it's gaudy red orange vinyl accents, parquet tables, and uncovered white walls. The interior reminds me of a gaudy 50's dinner trying unsuccessfully to masquerade itself as a modern french bistro. The menu is limited and from what we had a complete disappointment to the palate. For example, the brioche in combination with the smoked salmon, and bland hollandise sauce was much too rich and overwhelming. Maybe a little more lemon in the holladaise to help cut all that richness? The ham in our Croque Madame was very thin and the bread was not substantial enough to hold up against the melted cheese and sunny side up egg. Anyway...I think you get the point, stay away!
author: Vicky V.

description:
My French friend found this place noticing they had 1/2 price wine on Monday's and won Open Table's award last year.  Were the judges from England? The menu is small, but looked decent; they were missing a few things (Ok it's Monday).  The Clam chowder tasted like warm cream, absolutely no flavor.  My friends said the asparagus soup was also bland and heavy on the cream.  The halibut special, $22, was like an inch wide and 4" long.  My gnocchi special was mostly frozen peas and one of the skinniest asparagus I have ever seen served in SF; the gnocchi were ok.  Seared tuna was three tiny pieces of sashimi and mostly greens. Desserts were ok and the trout salad was something I would have again.  We wouldn't have stayed for dessert, but two of us had chosen the 3-course meal.

Would have been 2 star's but our waitress stole the show.  We were the only people in the place when we sat, except a few folks at the bar.  After ordering a bottle of wine, she came back a few minutes later to take the order.  When we asked for a few more minutes, she rolled her eyes and gave an audible "tsk" as she walked off.  Then later, upon ordering gnocchi one of us asked if there was any cheese...her response - "we're not an italian restaurant" (although they did have grated parmesan, wtf?)   

Funny, b/c she wasn't french either, and one of us was.  Definitely never coming back here.
author: Pedro B.

description:
Cozy place for weekend brunch and weekday dinners.

I lived few blocks away this restaurant and every weekend afternoon were buzy at this place. I have been here with friends and it is a not-so-black-tie but classy place. It is also fun for a lunch, just by yourself or with your partner.
Kobe beef burger is by far the best deal on the menu for lunch. For dinner, try the half-off on wine bottles day, it totally works for a group of 4 or  more even if you are driving.
Finding street parking could be tough on Filmore but its easier if you go 1 or 2 blocks away.

Nice place to try if you live around or are in the area.
author: Nadia C.

description:
This review is based on my Brunch experience.

I ordered the Eggs Florentine, Fries, and Mimosa.

Friend ordered Eggs Benedict.

What was ok: the Mimosa. 

The pouched eggs on both our plates were the size of ping pong balls. The in-house bread they were placed on were too thick. There wasn't enough sauce...I could go on and on.

Eggs Benny is my fav dish. I've had it at countless brunch spots in SF. this has to be the worst I've had in the city. 

Usually fries are the one food you can't stop stuffing your mouth with. After having a few, I stopped eating them. My friend and I sat and talked for 3 hours....so we had tons of time to eat those fries. 

I may go back and try this place for dinner since that's what all the great reviews are based on. But this is def. not a brunch spot.
author: Maria A.

description:
Perhaps I don't have a valid opinion because I came here for brunch and only had the "freshly baked croissant" and the fruit salad. And because I'm cheap.

Despite the deliciousness of the freshly baked croissant and the fruit salad, I still felt the price was not justified -- especially since I've had bigger and just-as-good-if-not-better croissants at my local French bakery for less. I mean, $3+ for a butter bread the size of my palm? Not cool.

The mimosa was good, though. And I guess boyfriend's eggs benedict was also good... but we probably won't return. Not for the croissants, anyway.
author: Jo L.

description:
Pronounced: [choo-ket]

My best foodie gal and I headed over here Saturday night with my $25 restaurant.com certificate in hand.

I absolutely loved everything we ordered and consumed here:

    - Flakey Goodness:
       tartlette of goat cheese & roasted tomato with balsamic sauce

    - Mediocre:
       moules & frites

    -  The Standout: 
        creekstone filet de boeuf (AKA filet migon) w/ sesame gremolata &        
        peppercorn sauce    
       (comes with fries, but asked to replace w/ mashed potatoes)
   
More pluses:
  _ french speaking friendly waiters (i did not encountered any wait 
     or bad experience as some yelpers have complained about)
 _  more or less it exceeded my expectations since reading the very 
     mixed reviews

Slight minuses: 
 _  the soggy frites (but lucky for them i dont mind)
 _  the seating is a bit too cozy for me (only 6 inch gap between each      
     table!)


Bill came out to be only $47 (including tax + tip). 

Will be back if I have another restaurant.com certificate! 

Definitely well worth it!
author: Sue Y.

description: They just kept the coffee coming!  The burger was very tender and done right.  Loved the fritz, crispy, non-oily.  Now if only they come with aiola sauce.  It's a great little neighborhood place, very welcoming.  I can actually have a conversation.  The fondant was so delicious, melty chocolate flowing out.  Perfectly done!
author: Helen L.

description:
Chouquet's is a twelve-year-old in her mother's evening gown: touches of elegance, but missing some fundamentals. Four of us ladies ordered the Prix Fixe menu, and it was immediately clear that the descriptions were hard to discern and that even the waiter wasn't sure what we would get. The wine list had a very nice array of choices by the glass, though, and we were all able to select dishes we liked. 

For the first course, I had the smoked salmon salad, which had well-balanced flavors and textures. Two of us had a clam chowder that went over well, but our fourth found her veggie bisque bland.

The veggie gnocci was a pile of contradictions. Good: crispy sage, butter sauce, and gnocci sauteed lightly for a very nice flavor and texture. Boring: peas, lots of 'em. Bad: lots of asparagus stems, one of them too tough to chew, but nary a single asparagus tip. That tough stem lost you a whole star, Chouquet's. Rookie move.

The kobe beef burger was confusing: the waiter seemed to think it would come with a potato galette, but it came with fries. The potatoes were billed as cooked in duck fat, but if they were I couldn't taste a difference. The seared ahi, on the other hand, came exactly as expected, with a zingy salad, and seemed to be the most successful entree. 

We all ordered the creme brulee for dessert, but then I saw the fondant-and-gelato plate go by and changed my order. Once again fooled by the description, I'd assumed it was mostly gelato with some kind of icing, but it turned out to be a dark-chocolate cake with a molten center. It was elegantly presented, rich, and satisfying, though a bit more bitterness would have been welcome with the sweet gelato. I didn't taste the creme brulee, but my friends seemed happy with it. 

Second rookie mistake: we were presented with the bill with no offer of coffee, tea, or dessert wine, any of which I would gladly have enjoyed. Since we each spent $50, all told, I can't imagine that we were being rushed away to let in the big spenders... A little port or cappucino would've probably added a hefty percentage to the bill and the tip, not to mention a star. 

I hope Chouquet's manages to stay around long enough to grow into its elegant ambitions.
author: Vivian V.

description: The food was alright, but the bread was not warm enough. The service was okay. The price was affordable, but towards the pricey side. I'll probably go back there again at a future date.
author: Allan W.

description:
Lunch yesterday, ordered the frisee salad, with proscuttio and a poached egg. Proscuttio was limp, should have been crisp. Salad didn't have much flavor. Could use a grilled slice of Parmesan bread on the bottom and dressing with enhanced flavor. Shrimp salad wasn't much better - had an off flavor.   Ice tea came from soda fountain - awful. Ordered hot tea (no lemon or honey). They can definitely do better for $40 plus for two salads and tea.  Corner spot in great neighborhood and outside patio was a good set-up.  
Service was very good and attentive but they should know the items better.    Let's hope they can get it together.
author: Jules T.

description: Thank goodness for all the good restaurants around this lousy place. Today is 6/10/12 - the host for this place is a guy with an attitude, crappy one too - very obnoxious and disrespectful. I won't go there if you pay me - why anybody wants to ruin their time interacting with this character? Lots of empty tables and that's not surprising.
author: Kean S.

description:
Fat, fat and more fat.

We went to Choquet's last night for an early dinner. Sadly, there was no fresh food on the menu.  I was hoping for a nice salad (the kind you get at a Parisian cafe) but I was out of luck. 

I ordered the asparagus puree soup, which the server promised was "mostly" vegetables.  It seemed to be *mostly* butter and cream, topped with olive oil.

I struggled to find anything on the menu that wasn't a heart attack on a plate.  I ended up with the burger for dinner which included a slice of duck fat (pure fat!) on one side, and bacon on the other.  Grease and blood were oozing out of the burger onto the bun. 

Tasty? Sure. But I felt awful the rest of the evening.
author: Jill D.

description:
$15 for bland pasta that tastes worse than a can of Chef Boyardee. 

My girlfriend had some $18 tuna dish and it was bland too. 

Both certainly tasted fresh and healthy, but the prices are ridiculous. I think people are willing to pay more for this French food simply because it's "French." Make crappy food, set a high price, say it's French, and boom, all sorts of morons will flock to it.
author: jerry k.

description: Really cute atmosphere. I'm a fan of their wine list... had a pinot noir that was really great... and you should definitely get their goat cheese/tomato appetizer - really yummy!
author: Natalise K.

description: Unfortunately I ate here during a week of eating out and during DAT. So my food choices were somewhat colored by wanting to eat the least caloric dishes for each course. That said, the lightest courses offered for DAT were still very tasty. I had the gazpacho and the salmon. The gazpacho came with tasty garlic toast and butter (I'm not sure it needs more fat or another flavor added to it as it was excellent on it's own with the soup), The gazpacho was light, refreshing, and full of flavor. The salmon was perfectly cooked and the assortment of asparagus and tomatoes that accompanied it were cooked and seasoned perfectly. For dessert, I had the creme brulee. It was fairly basic but cooked well.
author: Dani D.

description:
NOT FRENCH FOOD, NOT GOOD FOOD!
Tasteless, overpriced, minimum service, money hungry owner.
author: V R.

description: Nice place, well located, simple and clean.  Service: 5 stars.  That's where it ends.  The food is really bad: my burger felt like a frozen piece of meat, heated up in the microwave oven with some cheap bread, a slice of unripe tomato, and a leave of lettuce so strong that a shoemaker would fix the soles of your shoes with it.  My wife's dish was even worse.  Please please replace the chef and I'll try you again for the ambiance and service.
author: Philip I.

description:
Just fabulous. I came here a couple of weeks ago with a friend, and not in the mood for an incredibly busy, long-wait, trendy, over-rated spot, this was perfect. I love that it's in Pac Heights, as the crowd that Friday night (and all nights, I was told), was made up of neighborhood locals; the type of locals with enough class and decency to enjoy their own meal and keep to themselves without the ruckus of Marina locals. But then again Marina locals is a bit of an oxymoron, so...

Anyway, back to Chouquet's. Since it sits at the very top of Fillmore (at Washington), it's past the hustle and bustle of the street, but still in a central area. The space is small, but fills up quickly at dinnertime (I went around 7pm). The food was fantastic. We first shared the kobe beef tartar and then I had the salmon that came in a wine, cream sauce, plus a side of the frites (I'm a french-fry fanatic). Everything here is buttery smooth and just melts in your mouth. For dessert, we shared a chocolate, lava-sort-of cake that came with ice cream. Again, more meltiness in my mouth. Also, the wait-staff all speak French and will serve you in strong accents, so really, this place is ideal for a staycation; enjoy a little piece of France without leaving SF!
author: Melissa D.

description:
I'd come back! Recommend their brunch and also the wagyu burger.

Need to try their dinner.
author: Erika C.

description: A group of friends and I were looking for a brunch spot after striking out at Dottie's and randomly came across Chouquet's while heading into the Marina.  We had a group of 6, so we were expecting to have to wait wherever we ended up.  Chouquet's sat us right away, and enticed us in with the "Mango Mimosas" sign.  After sitting down and ordering drinks, half of us received our drinks pretty quickly, but the other half waited another 15 minutes for theirs.  They were pretty busy, but it didn't make sense that half the mimosas came out in one wave, where the second wave of mimosas took another 20 minutes.  Anyway, the food took forever to get out too.  I ordered the three egg omelette with bacon, onion and spinach.  Some of my omelette wasn't completely cooked, so I had to eat around the runny parts of it, meaning I couldn't eat my favorite item: bacon.  My boyfriend had the Wagyu burger with french fries and liked his dish.  The french fries were delicious, so Chouquet's gets one star for delicious french fries, and one for having a mango mimosa.  For my boyfriend and I, our check came out to being about  $75 for our two dishes, my two mango mimosas, his one mimosa and a glass of champagne and gratuity/taxes.  Considering some of the other available options, this just didn't seem worth it.  Good chance I won't end up back here in the near future.
author: Lisa I.

description: VERY dainty portions at not-so-dainty prices.  And it wasn't tasty.  Also a huge pet-peeve of mine: the iced tea was terrible.  Especially for a lunch/brunch place there's no excuse for that.  Tastes like they use the 'bar' iced tea instead of brewing it themselves (which I never understand, it's gotta be cheaper to brew it yourself.)  I may be wrong, but anyhow it was awful.  I know I'm going on a lot about something many people may not care much about, but I think it is fair to use it as a measure about how much they care about the effort they put into their food.  The LEAST memorable dining experience I've had in the last month.
author: Mike B.

description:
Despite living down the street, I hadn't been here until the Groupon came out because the reviews aren't stellar. But we went for brunch last weekend and I was blown away. Excellent mimosas, even better Salmon Benedict, great service and, thanks to the Groupon, we got a dozen oysters for dessert!! One of the best brunches I've ever had. We sat inside but it would have been really nice to sit outside and watch the neighbors stroll by with their tiny dogs.

Anyway, I'm looking forward to going back for dinner based on this experience, despite all the mediocre reviews here on Yelp.
author: Colin T.

description: My wife and I shared a nice omelette with potatoes and a really tasty soup.  It was a good meal that energized us for our walk through the city.  Friendly server (thanks Mark for the recommendations in Hayes Valley), relaxed vibe.  We'll be back.
author: Dave K.

description:
3.5 stars - a very cute neighborhood gem :) I love the area! One of those places where you can walk down the street and take a leisurely stroll after dinner :)

We were running a bit late and missed our 8pm reservation by a several minutes but Chouquet's was pretty empty when we arrived. We asked the server if it's usually this quiet but she said it's not.

The restaurant is pretty small and located on the quieter side of Fillmore St. They have a bar where you can sit and eat. Perfect for friends :) Very simply decorated with these beautiful orange napkins! I know, I know, what do napkins have to do with how well the restaurant is?

Absolutely nothing but I was thinking, these napkins are a great color... it would make a beautiful scarf or a tie.

Anyways.

I already knew what I was going to order since I looked at their very, very small and simple menu online.

We ordered:

- Beef Carpaccio: Beef carpaccio is one of my favorite appetizers of all time but I am used to eating it with lemon. So when my beef carpaccio came with no lemon, but instead, with these thinly sliced potato sticks, I was perplexed. I thought those "fries" were part of my entree when I realized they were part of my appetizers. OOPS. It was good but I still asked for lemon wedges :)

- Asparagus Salad: let this be known: this is no regular, boring salad. My boyfriend got this and I got to try a bite (or 2. or 3.) and it was SO good. Better than my beef tartare, which compared to it, had no flavor. But the asparagus salad was so delicious and the sauce was yummy!

- Lamb Shoulder: I got to try some of this and it was really, really under seasoned. I think they forgot to add salt or something. Good dish just under seasoned.

- Kobe Burger with Bleu Cheese: Pretty good and really big! I couldn't even finish it. Fries were okay, nothing spectacular. Honestly, real Kobe beef will never appear in a burger! But it was juicy and cooked perfectly (rare) and not too pricey either. Awesome!

The server was sweet and efficient. I liked the restaurant but the menu was very limited, and most of the items, I didn't want to try. If they changed their menu, I'd consider coming back!
author: T L.

description: Came here a second time at a friend's suggestion...only because I forgot that I had been here before.  Food is basically mediocre.  Service was bad - inattentive and aloof.
author: Eric C.

description: I was here for dine about town. The dinner menu was really disappointing. The entree I got (lobster tail) was so rough and my rice was hard. The service here couldn't be any worse. Our bread came after our appetizer and we had to keep asking them to come to our table. They didn't refill our water and never asked how we were doing. Not to mention when I asked for more bread the waiter stared and said okay but walked away and never returned with my bread. Annoyed. I would not recommend this place to anyone and I would give them no stars if that was an option. There's many other French restaurants... So I suggest you check those out.
author: Grace T.

description: Got food poisoning here and have not been back since. Rude service and bland overpriced food. It's only a matter of time before this place shuts down.
author: Rosie S.

description: Love this place, today hanging on the patio with a bottle of wine. Doesn't matter if it's inside at the bar, outside on the patio, lunch, dinner or just a refreshing beer or nice glass of wine you can't go wrong here. I defiantly prefer the patio on a sunny afternoon because its great people and dog watching. The service is always awesome, Vincent and the entire staff are always very attentive and the food is delicious.
author: Russell D.

description:
We had Dine About Town prix-fixe dinner there this evening. 

I like coming to this restaurant, so intimate & it's such a neighbourhood gem! The escargot stuffed in narrow bone & port wine was a divine! 

I'll go back!
author: Linda L.

description:
I went here for brunch a few weekends ago.  It was nice to be able to sit outside...I could have my dog with me...(despite my table neighbor's disappointed looks:)

Latte was very good.  I ordered the eggs benedict with the sauce on the side.  Pretty good, didn't even need the sauce.  The egg was cooked perfectly where it just can barely hold itself together until it just busts its yolky goodness all over your english muffin...but wait, this didn't have an english muffin...it was some baked/fried bready thing that was even better than an english muffin.  What you say? Better than an English Muffin. Oui.

A friend ordered the oysters, and was pleasantly surprised that they were so fresh...squeezed a little lemon, which made them move or something...freaked me out, but made my friend happy. 

This isn't the place for your 2 eggs over medium, fruit bowl side of pancake.  but over all....tres bien.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I didn't think much of this place. The food was good, the decor decently upscale (very pac heights look and feel) but nothing that blew me out of the water - especially given the prices.  I think I tried the steak and fries (fries in "french restuarants" are overrated in my humble opinion) and tried also the basa fish.  Nicely flavored but not really worth the wait and the pricetag. 

A decent place to take a small group of friends for a nicer but low key dinner, but I probably won't come back again.
author: Shinny L.

description: Service is terrible. Two table bussers, a coffee /drink bartender Anna waiter should be able to handle 6 tables. Had to ask 3x for the coffee I ordered when I sat down and was then faced with rudeness when asked a 4th time. I got my coffee after my meal. Eggs Benedict and other food like French toast is tasty but the service has gone down hill dramatically since we started going a year ago.
author: Anna K.

description: Cute place, lots of natural light, good location.  But brunch was just mediocre.  There are other places on the same street I'd pick next time.
author: Dana P.

description:
0 stars

Used a Groupon.

We had a salad with a little lettuce and a fried egg on top that was 
super disappointing.  

The entrees were just average.

Small portions.  Restaurant not fancy.  Didn't really like service.
author: Ron A.

description: We live very close by and have been here a handful of times. Each experience has been unremarkable and the food mediocre. Tonight, tired and not wanting to go very far for dinner, we wanted to give the restaurant another try. We walked in right at 9pm to only be told the chef decided to "close early due to a slow night" (the closing time posted is 10:30pm). I think the next time we are desperate, we'll just order a pizza.
author: Allison F.

description: I was really looking forward to this restaurant but it was a huge disappointment. Ordered the escargot, pate, salmon and lamb. Escargot was ok. The bread that they served with the pate was stale. I did enjoy my lamb. It was a bit salty to eat by itself so I packed it home and had it with some rice the next day. I've been to better french restaurants and I don't think I'll be returning to this one again.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
Very good food at reasonable prices
Menu has the common French bistro choices (for which I went) and additional interesting items as well.
Service was friendly and efficient.
I *liked* NOT being asked if everything was alright every five minutes.
Noise level was not oppressive.
Steak frites was perfect; spicy tuna tartare was excellent
all in all exactly what I wanted after a movie
Highly recommended (from someone who can be pretty critical :-))
author: S K.

description: 45 minutes to get simple brunches from order to table. All 4 orders are barely warm, and one is just plain cold (eggs florentine). The place wasn't busy at all. Food is very average, and not worth the hassles.
author: John R.

description:
I really want to like this place more. It's right around the corner from my apartment and has a good menu, reasonable prices, but the food is a bit sub par. Its certainly fine, but nothing to write home about. 

I've had slightly dry mussels several times and bland french fries. But its pretty easy to get a last minute table, the staff is nice, and a pleasant atmosphere. So I end up coming back regularly.
author: Katie S.

description:
Brunch destination just a bit more ways up on the Fillmore hill. Not sure if that's why Chouquet's is never really full for brunch. Granted it paid out for us as we were seeking breakfast options, but I think I understand why it isn't as popular - at least not during day time hours.

I had the Smoked Salmon Benedict ($13). I thought it was ok. I will say that the eggs were perfectly poached. Egg whites just firm on the outside, with a yolk that popped and oozed with slight pressure against the white. But then instead of an english muffin, they served the smoked salmon on a poppy seed biscuit thing. It was dry and a little hard. Not quite to my liking nor expectation.

My friend had the French Club Turkey BLT ($13). The presentation was impressive with a pile of lightly fried thinly cut waffle potato chips. Pretty and tasty when they were crisp. The triple decker sandwich was filling, and interesting with Canadian bacon and tangy dressing sauce. But it lacked the salty crisp bacon contrast in American BLTs.

I also ordered a croissant on the side ($3.50). It was a little overly toasted but it was very buttery and flaky.

Overall, I'd skip Chouquet's for brunch. I had better luck at dinner.
author: Cindy W.

description: We were there for the special valentine's day dinner yesterday at Choquet's and I really had to write the review. The service was pathetic, we had a reservation at 9 and from 9 to 9.30 we were standing in a line where no one attended to us to have us seated. We were the first and then followed 3-4 other couples and we were all frustrated. The restaurant wasnt even crowded and there were tables but they just left us standing. After a very bad beginning, we were served a supposedly 4 course menu which we thought included the wine/champagne but no it had to be billed separately. The food was just average and very very little in quantity. And as usual an enormous amount of dinner was just  in waiting for the dishes. I really didnt know what they were thinking. We paid a whoomping 187$ for the dinner and it was so not worth even half the money. We were relieved to get out of the restaurant and we were still super hungry that we went into a Mels Drive in for a second dinner. If I had known, I just would have avoided this costly mistake.:(
author: Lakshmi R.

description:
My experience here today clouded what otherwise promised to be a sunny Sunday.

I went today with two of my friends.  We saw a lot of people milling about outside the entrance and figured there was to be a long wait. Imagine my amazement when we arrived and saw that yes, there were people waiting, but there were also several tables inside open.  

Armed with a reservation, I entered and asked about my reservation. With at least three empty tables in sight, a server told me to hold on and someone would seat me. 10 minutes later, with the tables no fuller than before, I approached another server about my reservation. Only then did they seat me at my table. 

We ordered eggs benedict, smoked salmon benedict, and the wagyu kobe beef burger.  After ordering, we prepared ourselves for what we hoped would be a nice meal. We were startled out of our delusion by a loud THUD. This was the sound of the bread bowl and butter landing on our table as a member of the staff all but threw it on our table. 

The eggs benedict were almost cold. They skimped severely on the Hollandaise sauce as well. The burger was OK but nothing special. I imagine it's not their wheelhouse, in any case.

After we finished, we sat and chatted.  Or at least tried. The acoustics of the room made it such that we could hear conversations from people two tables down better than we could hear each other.  Meanwhile, there was no trace of our server or anybody else at all. No proffered refills of water or coffee, or even to offer us the check. 

Finally, our sever came around and ... took away an empty glass. No notice of the empty coffee cup, or the depleted food plates. You know what they say, out of sight, out of mind. Clearly my party was out of the staff's mind, as they did not bother to acknowledge our existence further until I left our table to bother the server about the check. 

In sum, disappointing food + extremely inattentive service = a bad experience for us.
author: Gene C.

description:
Chouquet's first caught my interest because it sounded like Fouquet's, the much too famous restaurant in Paris (which I could never afford to eat at). 
Then, I saw they were on restaurant.com, so I used my United mileage towards a gift certificate. 

I was very pleasantly surprised when I walked in. I thought it would be more uppity and big, but it was a pretty small, intimate space that was about the size of a smaller end bar. 

The asparagus frisee salad was delicious with a really nice dressing. 

The braised lamb shoulder was so yummy! Perfectly seasoned and it went well with some potatoes on the side. The lamb had spent so much time braising that it was beyond melt-in-your-mouth.... it was basically melt-on-the-plate. But I didn't mind; it was delicious nevertheless. 

My dinner companion had the wagyu kobe burger with comte cheese, which was also very satisfactory :)

I'd like to come back when it's a little warm and sit outside.
author: Saori E.

description: One of my traveling friends/guru invited me to lunch at this restaurant.  It's located in the heart of Pacific Heights and is in a great neighborhood.  It was sunny the day we were there, but a little windy so we opted to dine inside.  I ordered a tasty smoked trout salad and shared a creme brulee a vanille dessert.  It was a bit pricey for lunch, but was still a great lunch.  My GF said they have a great brunch on Sundays, but I don't know if I would make this place a choice for brunch.  It was ok.  Ambiance & service was fantastic though!
author: Arlene Z.

description: This place was so quick and good, although we made a reservation on Open Table.  Food was good and menu is quick and to the point.  Great for a quick gourmet lunch or brunch.
author: Liz A.

description:
Chouquet has turned me into a red meat fan!

So for dinner my friend and I decide to go splitsy. Although the menu was very limited (especially for someone like me who tries to stay with comfort food and away from red meat)...and unable to recognize %80 of the options, we thought that it would be hard to go wrong with anything this fancy.
We were soooo right!! So we had

-Tartlette of goat cheese & roasted tomato with balsamic sauce. (If you're scared of goat cheese b/c you think it's salt or to pungent...don't be. The goat cheese was creamy, and tasted slightly like cream cheese.

-Creekstone filet de boeuf with sesame gremolata & peppercorn sauce & fries. (medium-well, Oh lordy... cows have no chance if they always taste this good! it just melted in my mouth!)

- and Oysters in a white wine sauce (i can't find what they called it on their menu. LOVED IT!)

The service was GREAT...Attentive and very accommodating, and even French:). The waiter called my friend mademoiselle, and she was in awe.  
There was only two small tables left, and they let us chose...thank goodness b/c we didn't want to sit near the little baby (cute and all, but it's hard to chit chat around families). 
Also, both entrees came with fries, so we asked for mash potatoes as a substitute. Good idea too, b/c garlic mash potatoes with juicy melt in your mouth beef...OMG!

we didn't order drinks....but we felt like kicking ourselves for not getting dessert! Next time... we're going all out!
author: Lynn T.

description:
Went for the first time Sunday night dinner.  Place not too full, so easy to sit and had good attention.

We ordered the carpaccio, asparagus salad, spring vegetagle gnocci, with chocolate fondant and the raspberry financier for dessert.  Appetizers where quite good, although the very thin potato strings were a little hard to eat.  The gnocci was good, but needed some pop of herbs or maybe just some pepper.  Desserts were very nice, I'd get the chocolate fondant again.

We ordered four glasses of wine by the glass, and they were good but pretty stingy 4 oz pours (for 10- 12 bucks a glass.)
author: Richard L.

description:
Don't go here. At least not for brunch. It's really not worth the money. 

The food is OK but for the price it should be much better. I thought about giving this place 3 stars but really would I go back? No. 

Some low points: 
-Fly on the window sill behind my chair. I just cleaned it up and threw it away myself. 

-The kitchen, waiter and runners could not get it together. Our hot dishes were room temperature. The runner gave our dishes to the table next to us. It took them awhile to figure that out. Which is a little weird. Having someone else breath on your food while the runner figures out which table ordered what. 

So what did we order: 

-Coffee - good 

-Grapefruit juice - really good 

-6 oysters. good. a little small 

-burger - good flavor but was nearly cold when it reached the table 

-goat cheese tartlette - very very acidic. and tiny. the balsamic glaze on the plate looks weird (like chocolate). 
- 
chocolate hazelnut banana crumble: sounds good right? it really isn't. it tasted like a bad attempt at a Ina Garten recipe. how can they charge $8 for melted nutella with chunky bananas and burnt crumbly "crumble"??? 

Nothing was horrible but for this price you'd expect more. Better service and better food. Good thing I had a Groupon (yay Groupon!!) because I would've been upset to pay full price for what I received. 

Skip.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
I went here for SF restaurant week recently, and I can honestly say it was not worth the money.

I had the Salade De Truite Fumee, the Filet De Boeuf, and the Chocolate Fondant.

The Salad was okay. Nothing special.

The Filet De Boeuf is the reason this place gets 2 stars. I asked for it medium rare and though it looked medium rare, it was super dry, practically tasteless, and small. The combination of expensive + small + tasteless was really disappointing.

The Chocolate Fondant (basically a chocolate lava cake) was the only thing enjoyable during the meal.
author: Robert R.

description:
Chouquet's could be a bit prettier on the inside so minus a star for that.

Food was tasty so yay! 

I started with ribs in an amazing honey and lavender glaze, moved onto the seared ahi with cucumber salad and finished with the chocolate banana hazelnut thing.  Fresh mint tea did indeed have fresh mint but also a teabag that looked suspiciously lipton-y.

I hear good things about this place for brunch, I'd give it a go.

Wine half off on Monday.  Too bad we couldnt make it through a bottle, the prices seemed reasonable.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I am so pleased to have this place around the corner! They serve a couple of my favorites:
1. a delicious and very tasty Frenchy omelette with a fresh green salad for brunch 
2. Rack of lamb with scrumptious scalloped potatoes for dinner

With these 2 items available to me nearby, I am a happy diner! 

My only issue is that I needed to ask for my order to be taken at brunch...if the service had been more prompt, i would have given them 5 stars...
author: Kay H.

description:
What a lovely bistro!!!

I used a deal from one of the coupon places to go here - of course I don't use them to get a cheap meal. I prefer to use them so I can order more from their menu - and so I did!

Chouquet's is located perfectly on the corner of Fillmore and Washington - a very lovely neighborhood for eateries and shopping.  I can't believe I missed this place - it was never on my radar for French cuisine.  Well, I'm happy to report that Chouquet's is Fillmore's little secret to French bistros, as Le Charm s to SoMa.  Their offerings are wonderful.  At the same time, their wine list is fabulous.

I started with two apps.  Their oysters - awesome - it's really hard to frak this up.  Then I had their Clam seafood chowder  Sancerre wine, fingerling potatoes & applewood baconr - OMG!  This is so delicious I could of had a whole pot of it, and would of been sated for dinner!  For my main, I stayed with the seafood theme and had their Moules Marinieres, in a shallot, garlic, parsley & cream white wine sauce & fries  (again this is really hard to mess up) - it was delicious!  I took the bread and I had and dipped it into the cream white sauce.  Can you say YUM!

Last but not least I ended dinner with there chocolate fondant - this was so perfectly done, I don't know how to express my tastes bud's reaction, on top of the amazing presentation!

Consequently, my friend went with the red meat route and also enjoyed every portion of his meal - he started with their Natural Ribs in lavender honey & balsamic syrop, pommes maxim's & pistachio nougatine, and his main was their  Wagyu beef kobe burger, pommes gaufrette, butter lettuce, organic tomato, applewood bacon, red onions, duck fat galette & choron sauce - he savored every bite!  He then ended his dinner another of their chocolate desserts with crisp and nuts - he scarffed that down pretty fast!  In the middle of this we enjoyed many wines and drinks from their menu - merci beaucoup et jusqu'à la prochaine fois! Je serai de retour!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
What happened! It's been awhile since I had brunch here, so I was surprised at how unpleasant the experience was. 
The indifferent waitstaff !!...I could have handled it if the meal was the expected delish....unfortunately it wasn't. 
The omelet  du jardin was like rubber with salad bar like diced raw tomato and accompanied by uninsiring potatoes and a few greens. The only plus side was the strong robust coffee.
I'm sad, because I used to love chouquet's, the nice staff and lovely sidewalk tables and yummy food, now it seems to be just a memory.
Chouquet really harshed my mellow day.
author: Leigh C.

description:
Good quality food. My fiancee seemed to enjoy it more them me.
It was sort of a soup w/ large chunks of meat.
Recommend going here for a quick night out.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Depending on when you go, you either get lackadaisical, adorable waitresses or adorable, attentive waiters... i prefer the latter ;)

For brunch i've had the eggs florentine, croquette madam, smoked salmon benedict and the omelet jardin. The latter being the most unimpressionable dish and eggs florentine being the winner of the bunch. 

As for dinner i've tried the lamb and the kobe burger.... WOW kobe burger with duck fat, i've had dreams about you! get it and you won't regret it!
author: Emily T.

description: I have NEVER had a bad meal in San Francisco, until I went to Chouquets. First of all, I've never had a hostess decide for me that I would be sitting outside in short sleeves and bare legs during the winter. How bizarre...second of all, once they sat us on the drafty patio, we had to ask for menus as well as water and bread. Anyway, the menu was fixed - four courses for $65, so we walked in there with low expectations - just happy to have good company and somewhere to accommodate our party. Turns out our expectations weren't low enough...we can't eat shellfish or escargot, and they were unwilling to simply substitute the lobster or escargot for the rice that was already on the menu, as our first course. Oh well. We figured we'd give it a shot, but like I said, we had low expectations to begin with. This didn't completely tick us off. Well, our friends ate the escargot I ordered for them and said they've had better many times before and that they're usually smaller in size...weird. The second course was a quail and spinach salad "dressed with balsamic dressing." I could not taste balsamic anywhere in the soggy spinach salad and I could barely eat the quail. Maybe I swallowed one piece? The entree was a Beef Wellington...I've never had Beef Wellington before but I thought it was a safe bet considering it's filet mignon in a puff pastry. It had no flavor and the steak was NOT tender at all. The dessert was the most appetizing course of the whole meal but they took a chocolate lava cake (something that never disappoints) and infused it with a liquor (I think)...so instead of a delectable warm chocolate taste, it was sour. On top of all this, the patio cleared out as the evening went on and continued to get cooler and cooler. By the end of the night my toes were numb because they were so cold and it was not because I was in a dress with short sleeves and bare legs - my husband was fully clothed in jeans, shoes and socks, a long sleeved shirt, a jacket, and he was still cold. What a disappointment. I will never return to Chouquets and honestly do not understand how they remain open. And in case you're wondering, the waitress was rude and slow to serve us.
author: Kelsey K.

description: The food here was so yummy!  The lavender ribs were awesome!  The only thing that sucked was that it took awhile to get a table even though I had reservations.  Luckily, I was in no rush.  Definitely a place to try out.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad
- Blew my mind away!  Shreds of smoked trout and light dressing are tossed evenly in this refreshing light salad.  The potatoes are tasty too!

Followed by a stroll down Fillmore...a great way to spend an afternoon =)
author: Ames L.

description:
I wish I had come back to the place sooner.  I had brunch here about 3 years ago, but I didn't even think that they would have tasty dinner food.  The Kobe beef burger really hit the spot.  Cooked to medium perfection with nice flavor.  

The service was very nice. The one thing that worried me was the restaurant was so empty on a Saturday night :(  There were only a couple of other tables.  From what we could see, the other dishes looked good. 

I would definitely come back here.
author: Nita K.

description:
this place was pretty good. they had $1 oysters! :)

oysters - were pretty fresh, but the sauce they gave was kinda blah. 

wagyu tartare - was ok. not much flavor (yet a little too mayonaissey or something)

filet mignon - pretty good. not the best i've had (altho i shared with a prego girl, so we          couldnt order it rare.. -_-

ravioli - was sO good. i think that was our best dish

creme brulee was really good
and i think we also got the ice cream which was kind of 'whatevs'

overall, i think this is a really cute place. the food good. ill b back to try something different next time.
author: Lisa N.

description:
Came here after I submitted my med school applications. Time to celebrate! I had a restaurant.com gift certificate to this place and it was time to make use of it. 

Quaint little corner restaurant frequented by the Pac Heights crew. Came on a Wednesday night and there was plenty of seats. Friendly staff with great service. I got the lamb shoulder braised with mushroom truffle oil & pommes salardaise. OMG to die for! The meat was tender and juicy and just fell right off the bone. The potatoes were a perfect addition to the meal. My friend got the Wagyu beef kobe burger, pommes gaufrette, butter lettuce, organic tomato, applewood bacon, red onions, duck fat galette & choron sauce. He loved the burger and I loved the fries!  For dessert we had the baked banana and chocolate. The waitress warned me not to eat it just yet but to let it cool. Hmm... someone telling me not to do something, well that just means I have to do it! I burnt my tongue but it was worth it!
author: Tina Y.

description: Amazing! The burger with bleu cheese was soooooo good. Plus, we were splitting two dinners and they brought them on separate plates-split- in two courses! Amazingly nice staff!
author: Jaclyn T.

description: Cold food and snide service.. Ridic.  Had eggs florentine that came out cold and the servers stood around gossiping about the customers like we couldn't hear them.  Not cool.  Too many choices in SF and too many other Fillmore options to stand for below average food and bad service.
author: Win L.

description:
I feel bad giving such a low rating.  I would have liked to return to even out our rating, but we are sure we will not return.  

We've walked past here many times and it looks so cute and quaint.  Finally we decided to just go ahead and try it since it was 2 and there were a few people enjoy late brunches like us.  

I had the vegetarian omelette and my husband the club.  My portion was small, with a salad.  The club sandwich was just that, plus pommes frites (which our kid loved!).  My husband mentioned they put too much mayo.  We left quite unsatisfied with the food.  

Went to the park and on the way home picked up a sandwich (part two of my brunch) at Blue Fog.  

On the walk home my husband mentioned he felt sick, but we kept walking the 20 minutes.  When he got home he laid in bed shivering and going to the bathroom.  From 4-10 PM, we had the heat on way high in the house and he kept going to the bathroom.  Finally at 11 I awoke to him vomiting his guts out.  Four times.  After that, he felt much better.  Told him he should just have forced himself to do that when we first got home.

He got food poisoning from the food there, we think.  And I wouldn't be surprised it was the mayo because he had mentioned there was too much of it and he didn't like how it tasted.  Though we are not certain Chouquet's was the culprit, we were not happy with the portion and taste of the food so we will not return.  It is unfortunate because I would have liked to return without the baby to try other stuff on the menu.  

C'est la vie.
author: Mrs F.

description:
Came here for brunch this morning with my roommate and sadly did not have a good experience. We ordered two omelet's with almost exactly the same thing: prosciutto, spinach, tomato's and goat cheese. It took them a good 30 minutes to get it out to us, meanwhile people who had ordered after us were being served. I saw omelet after omelet come flying past us, every time thinking that it had to be ours! 

We finally said something to one of the bussers and he told us that it would be out in just a second...five minutes later, still no food. We had to tap somebody again and then finally they materialized. First of all, when they say that they give you potato's with the meal, I didn't expect 5 of the tiniest squares I've ever seen. Look, that may be how you do it in France, but here in America we're heifers (or at least I am)! I like heaping mounds of breakfast potato's! 

We dug in and then both realized that there was absolutely zero goat cheese in it. When my roommate inquired about it he basically accused us of not having ordered it. Um, okay... you couldn't have just said, so sorry, I guess I didn't hear that? You had to blame it on us? It's just like, come on. GET YOUR SHIT TOGETHER AND LEARN GOOD CUSTOMER SERVICE. 

It's sad because I loved the dinner I had here about a year ago. This experience has left such a bad taste in my mouth that I probably won't revisit or recommend.
author: Julia N.

description: This place in ok. Food was not fresh even for Saturday night. There was only one server for the whole inside dining room. My main complaint is that he put gratuity on my table of two people.  Since when a couple get's an automatic gratuity? Well, I tell you that it was his mistake. As a service industry worker I would leave him a 20% tip on the total of the check.  Anyways, he save me some money and earned a bad reputation. Dislike...
author: Olya K.

description: Always a good place to have solid french food and exceptional wine.  The service is friendly and the place is usually not too packed (a real hidden gem on Fillmore).  If you can grab the corner table in the back for two, it's super comfortable.
author: Mark G.

description:
So fun to return to this restaurant after an absence.  We went on a Wednesday night when they have live music, a Spanish guitar jazz sort of thing, and free corkage!  We brought a nice champagne...
I opted for the pre-fixe so had yummy salad of mache with a bit of salmon then seared tuna and chocolate cake.  My friend had the salmon entree and was very happy with that.  Of course the pre-fixe included smaller portions but a nice deal for $39.
author: Kara H.

description: While it looks like a nice place on the outside, the blond hostess couldn't have cared less about our business. She asked us to wait outside, then proceeded to ignore us as she set up several tables for no one immediate. There was no line! She was just rude, so we went to Dino's, where the staff couldn't have been nicer.
author: Julia S.

description:
solid french food, thats for sure.  three of us came here for dinner on a weekday and it was quiet and intimate, perfect for catching up on a week's activities.  the day we went, the special was that there was no corkage fee so we brought a nice bottle of wine to enjoy with dinner.  we had a plate of mussels for the table, then we got the scallops with rice, the slow braised lamb, and the coq au vin.  everything was really delicious though incredibly rich.

french food has never been my favorite, but i definitely had a good experience here.  the service was friendly, the food was good and came in pretty filling portions, and the ambiance was nice.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The restaurant is a cute small bistro along the corner by the Fillmore area in SF.  The ambience is nice, casual.. yet quaint.

For starters we had the carpaccio and the smoked trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad.  The two appetizers were extremely light and consisted of more salad than the actual "meatier" ingredients.  Husband was disappointed with the carpaccio.. it was a very thin slice on the plate with a heaping shovel-ful of arugula on top.  He's a foodie nutt from France and he says he's NEVER seen it done like this.  Please don't call it carpaccio.. the other strange was that it come pomme frites.  What's up with that?  

The smoked trout salad was good.. no complaints there.  Husband also had half a dozen kumamoto oysters.  Very good, but also very petite.

For entrees, I had the seared ahi tuna, hubby had the Creekstone filet de beouf.. the kid had the vegetable gnocchi.

-  The ahi tuna came out dry, overcooked and under seasoned.  Again, I had another shovelful of salad.  Can we lay off the greens please?
-  The filet of beouf was done well.. came out with more pomme frites.. but all in all, the husband loved it.  BUT DAYAM was it microscopic in portions.  We are not heavy eaters.. but DOOD, we are not children either.
-  The kid had the vegetable gnocchi "with sage/lime infusion with asparagus, peas, baby leek, clamshell mushroom & crispy sage".  By far, her dish was better than mine!  But alas, she is a dumb kid and they cannot appreciate complex tastes.. and so she would not eat her dinner.  We tasted it and then realized why.. it's because the gnocchi was undercooked (less than al dente), dry and pan-fried somehow.. it was crusty brown in some places.  The vegetables were good.. but that is not what makes the dish.

We skipped desserts at the end of the meal and headed over to Steps of Rome in North Beach.  And for a fraction of the price, had a wonderful dessert for each person, along with espresso.

I'm not trying to be harsh here.. but it is one thing when you are charged big money for a great meal.. but $134 WITHOUT tip.. for food that misses more than it "hits the mark" and portions are somewhat small and super light.. it isn't worth it.. 

Wait staff were very attentive and nice.  She was very pleasant and asked us how we were doing from to time to time.. 

Also, not kid friendly (only because of the menu options.  A simple olive oil tossed pasta would have worked for a kid or a soup.. but it wasn't available.  I guess that's why there was a screaming 2 year old behind me yelling about her food).

I can't give 3 stars because it's really more 2.5 stars..
author: Nancy H.

description:
amour au premier morceau.

ditched the DAT menu and ordered off the regular one.

smoked trout salad with fingerling potatoes was divine.

my scallop and shrimp "black" risotto was to die for. i always order risotto and am usually disappointed even at most upscale restaurants. not here. my scallops were cooked to perfection and the flavors were intense and so gratifying to my palette. it went perfectly with our French chardonnay.

bff Candice had the most amazing rigatoni w/ truffle oil and foie gras, which i pretty much wanted to steal from her. however- my dish was just as amazing so we really didn't want to share! lol jk!

service was excellent, food was above par and i literally cannot wait to go back!
author: Lily M.

description:
Went here two weekends ago with my bf and a friend for brunch. GREAT outdoor spot on a Saturday or Sunday morning. They have tables outside that get sunlight on the corner and it's really fun for people watching. Brunch menu was somewhat limited for someone like me, who likes pancakes and french toast-type dishes for brunch. They have lots of omelette selections. I got their special french toast with fresh fruit. Yum!! So good. Also got a mimosa, which was tasty. My bf got a bloody mary which didn't seem to have any alcohol in it...bummer. Total for 2 people, including one drink each, tip and tax was just under $50. Service was fine/ok.

One star for great outdoor spot, one star for tasty french toast, one star for decent service. One star off for limited "sweet" brunch choices and one star off for sub-par bloody mary. 

I would consider going back but only if they have a pancake or french toast special. Egg lovers will have lots of choices here!
author: Jacqueline Z.

description:
I have a love/hate relationship with this place.  All the food I have had is delicious- the Gazpacho is my favorite.  It comes as a beautiful presentation on a banana leaf (I think), with AMAZING onion butter, and olive oil brushed bread sticks.  I love dipping bread in my gazpacho, and always make sure to order some extra.  The salads are also very filling and creative.

The hate part however, is due to the service.  As a nanny, I brought the baby with me once, and they refused to give me a table in the shade.  It was a blistering hot day, with 5 single tables in the sun, and 2 multi-person tables in the shade.  As well, these tables were farther apart and left room for the stroller to sit next to me.
I understand that 4person tables are for 4 people.  However, they were nearly empty this afternoon.  When I asked for a shade table, I was told no.  I explained the stroller situation, and I was essentially told "sucks to be you".  I ended up seated about 3 ft away from a couple, with the stroller smooshed in-between us.  Uncomfortable and awkward much?  I'd say so.

So Chouquet...your food rocks, but work on the customer service please.
author: Anya W.

description:
Great, great place! 

Food is excellent and location is superb. Great place to hang out with friends and catch up.
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
Beef? Check.
Bun? Check.
Duck lard? WTF...Check.

The hidden gem at Chouquet's is truly their burger. It is a sinfully delicious masterpiece, served with cheese and bacon...while I have had neither on my burgers, it is still to die for. They put some sort of onion/potato/duck lard hash on the top of it, which adds the perfect amount of crunch. And the fries there are delish, too.

This burger was so good that even being stuck by the front door for a while, next to a man who insisted on having a very LOUD conversation on his cell phone while he was chomping away (and then having the nerve to say, "I hope it wasn't me" when we asked to move, then proceeding to talk crap about us to the person on the other end), well, not even that could deter our love. 

Oh, added bonus? It's on restaurant.com.
author: Annie F.

description:
the pros: if you're in pacific heights and want to escape the hustle and bustle that begins a few blocks down this is a great spot. when the weather is nice, they have a good amount of outdoor seating and it's on the sunny side of the street. the food is good. i've ordered several items on the menu and have always enjoyed my meal. well, once i ordered the burger and it was more rare than med-rare (red blood dripping out and red, not pink interior) but c'est la vie. 

the cons: they would prefer the kids were left at home. they don't like kids at their restaurant and they act like it -- almost every time. pacific heights is a family neighborhood. wrong location for a restaurant if you don't want families. 

very disappointing as i love the location, the food, my company, and the people i meet while dining on a late Sunday morning. however, i don't appreciate feeling unwelcome when there with my child, especially when i am paying for our meals and service.
author: Claire G.

description:
I guess I go back here once in a while because I get desperate
or get amnesia, or get optimistic.  I have been here many times, ever since they opened years ago, it was really wonderful at the beginning, and then BAM, bait and suck  switch.   But this past week was the last time, I swear.  I want to like this place! But the service is awful (who cares if that's French, half the staff are NOT French), the food is dicey (lots of cheap crappy shortcuts that get really obvious), and it's not particularly comfortable (torturous seating and bizarre graphic design 
on the walls).  One day I watched a busser sneeze into his hands and then proceed to set the table.  TRUE!  

They do have good wines by the glass, and if you order simple scrambled eggs, very good.  The frites are sometimes good, sometimes really stale and soggy.  The food just isn't dependable, though.  And the service!  I always wonder if
I have my invisible suit on when I go there.

Someone's on autopilot.
author: harmonia b.

description:
The burger and the fries were awesome! The real catch to this place is the outdoor seating on a sunny day. Get there early as sometimes people end up waiting a while for a seat. This place isn't too big which I think is part of the charm. 

My appreciation for this place was at a 5 star level because instead of providing Niman Ranch ground beef in their burgers, the menu at Choquet's listed the use of wagyu patties. Big ups for the quality meat used. Thanks! My appeal and stars are based on the burger+setting.
author: C G.

description:
It's nice because there's outdoor seating and in my book, anywhere my dog can go with me is somewhere I'll try atleast once.

Brunch wasn't really worth it...goat cheese tartlet is small and greasy.  The gazpacho was nice and refreshing.  One of my six oysters was strange and fishy tasting.  The creme brulee was lame.  The tables are small and slatted so it can be uncomfortable.

Good service.  Waitress was nice enough to bring my dog a bowl of water.
author: A S.

description:
I was really excited to dine here. So much so, that I came here for my birthday dinner. A pretty good compliment, right? 

Unfortunately, it didn't live up to what I had in mind. As I'm writing this review a few months late (no, I never procrastinate!), I don't specifically remember what I had, so I can't give specifics. 

The food was alright, but not memorable (obviously). I do remember thinking the meal was fine (I'm thinking there was gazpacho involved), but I was definitely disappointed with my dessert. I say this with added sadness, as dessert is my favorite dish- so I was hoping for a really good dessert on my birthday! However, I had some apple dessert which was too sticky and difficult to eat. :( 

I won't be suggesting to come back here for dinner, but I've noticed that this place has a pretty good crowd for weekend brunches. Perhaps I'll give that go.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
A nice place to grab brunch in Pac Heights. I had the eggs benedict which was served with salad and used buttered french bread instead of an english muffin. Everything was delicious. mmmm :P

Service was a bit slow and they seemed understaffed. The restaurant is quite small and the tables are very close together. You can basically hear everything the table next to you is saying.

Prices are reasonable. $12 for eggs benedict, $2.50 for coffee.
author: Kenny J.

description:
The closest I ever came to poaching eggs was hard boiling. Bulbous plumes of white albumen, growing from fissured shells, mocked my egg dispensing clumsiness. The idea of eliminating the shell and boiling eggs naked sounded sloppy and unappealing.

Yet given the right tools, know how, and a dab of magic, eggs benedict can be transcendent. 

I've had dinner at Chouquet, gotten drunk at the petite and lovely wine bar, and always enjoyed myself. But nothing strikes me as memorable as my last brunch here. 

My breakfast was kissed by eggy angels. The yolks of my benedict burst at my fork's tender touch. A river of gooey gold spilled over banks of tender salmon and crunchy yet pillowy brioche. 

4.25 * stars
author: Brady K.

description:
One of the reasons why I love Yelp! is because it helped me to better understand - and appreciate - this amazing city I happen to live in. San Francisco has a cosmopolitan nature, a remarkable tolerance for heterogeneity, and some of the best restaurants in the country.

Sometimes, however, even the best gastronomic experiences get misunderstood. 

I'll give you an example: Chouquet. 

At the risk of over-simplifying the complexity of the innumerable reviews that are hosted on Yelp!, I would argue that they could all be divided into two categories: the enthusiastic ones, appreciative of both the food and the quality of the service offered by this tiny and charming French bistro. And those written by harsh critics who wholeheartedly disagree and seem to despise both. 

How do you explain the apparent paradox, the love-or-hate relationship?
 
Ok, here's my theory, or, better, my story. 

I have been to Chouquet several times in the last three years and I adore it. I love it for the very same reason why most yelpers seem to hate it. 

Whereas some found the service slow, sluggish, and erratic, I consider it excellent. 

This is probably because I am European, actually, Italian and this kind of service - not intrusive, hassle-free, discreet, is exactly what I look for when I dine out.  The waiting time between the courses is not "excruciatingly long", but just about right. I mean: eating is not a race, isn't it?

On the other hand, I can't stand the intrusiveness of most waiters in other restaurants. You see, in an Italian restaurant - and the same applies to France or Spain - when you get a table, you basically 'own' it for the rest of the night. Nobody is taking away your dishes when you are still "working" (LOL!) on them. You don't get the bill unless you ask for it. That would be an insufferable felony. 

At Chouquet, the staff is usually very courteous and considerate. Not detached, but respectful of the customers' pace and desire to fully enjoy the social experience. 

Thus, while I appreciate the American way (in Rome do as the Romans do, right?), I like the Mediterranean style - the slow food philosophy - better.

Here's more contextual information that explains the five stars: Chouquet is where my friends and I engage in lively conversation about the film that we just saw or are about to see at Clay of Kabuki - in this sense, Chouquet is to Clay Theater what Globe is to the Embarcadero Center.

The culinary-cum-cinematic experience is a priceless pleasure: the two go together so perfectly. A glass of Bordeaux always makes the latest opus from Chabrol or Honore more palatable. We pretend we are critics from the 'Cahiers du Cinema' discussing things like 'mise-en-scene' and 'politique des auters'. It's San Francisco 2008, but it could easily be Paris, 1962.

Sure, the tables are so close to each other that sometimes it's hard not to eavesdrop on your neighbor's conversation. And just because the waiters are not pretending to worship the customers it does not mean that they are snooty or arrogant. They are just cool. You will find the same attitude in many European restaurants. In a sense, Chouquet is the real deal.

In short, this is an excellent place if you're on a date or with a group of friends who enjoy drinking, talking, and eating. And drinking. And talking. And eating. 

However, if you're in the hurry, you're definitely not going to like the experience. 

But then again, what's the rush?
author: Matt B.

description:
Feel good about yourself.  

I wanted to, after an intense week of on-the-job study.  We decided to have brunch in a prosperous part of town, and we wound up looking at the menu at Chouquet's.  Very yummy stuff!  

I decided to have eggs benedict, and the dressing on the salad was divine!  My Lady went for the burger and fries.  The fries were home-made shoestring fries, and I found myself sneaking handful after handful off her plate.  These would have cost us $25, but we didn't stop with that.  

We also had a kir royale, a bellini, 2 merlots, an almond crumble, coffee and tea.  The whole feast was more like $76 + tip.  

Yes, well.  It was a beautiful, warm, sunny day.  The waiter was really French.  The food that we ordered was delicious, and the food we saw going by to the other tables looked wonderful.  The customers were happy, and the inside and outside dining areas were full.  

I found my prosperous feeling, and I'd do it again without hesitation.
author: David D.

description:
Lets start with our waitress.  She certainly didnt wake up on the right side of the bed.  Service without a smile throughout the whole meal.  Plus when my friend ask if they have the crab salad, she didnt even realize they have a crab salad.  Wow...  The answer was no by the way, even tho i cant see how hard it could be to make a crab salad.  Im not done.  My friend then went and ordered the Laughing bird shrimp salad.  She wanted to NOT have grapefruit... and when she got it... there were the grapefruit.  Again.. she wanted it WITHOUT the grapefruit... they have to actually add the grapefruit... either the waitress didnt even bother putting it in the order, or the kitchen dont or cant read.  

Ok... next there were four of us, three of our order came timely, mine came at least 10 minutes later.  Bad bad bad.  leaving my friends sitting there waiting for my order to come before they can eat.  You must be thinking, well I must have ordered something special.  NOPE.  I got the egg Benedict, the first thing on their menu.

Overall, I thought the food was just OK...  nothing special.  With services that bad, how can the food taste good.  

I would have to say that our busboy was great.  He kept coming around to refill our coffee and give us more bread.
author: Janet S.

description:
Brunch: Best eggs benedict within a five minute walk. The eggs are perfectly poached and the sauce feels light and fresh. But its the bread that might be my favorite part - no hard english muffin here but rather a buttery half loaf of soft french bread. I also love that there is such a variety to their menu; the salmon salad is also a favorite. Whether sitting out side in the warmth of the morning sun, or inside at the wooden bar, it makes dinning for one a great Sunday indulgence.

Dinner: Nightly specials change often but the quality does not. My favorite dish is the Truffle Rigatoni, which is so creamy and rich that I literally dream about it! 

to sum up: Cozy bistro with a true french feel but without the pretension. I also love their flatware and their bar stools. My only complaint is that  they now serve coffee in tall glass mugs; I liked the ceramic cappuccino cups. phooey....
author: Mackenzie B.

description:
Don't be fooled by the flirtatious waiters and cute ambiance - the service here actually stinks. After ordering and waiting 20 minutes, our food arrived.... minus my dad's dish. So we all waited 10 more minutes while our coffees cooled, our salads wilted, and our burgers soaked into the buns... and still no omelet for dad. Long story short, they had run out of mushrooms, and didn't even start making his food until after our entrees had already arrived and cooled!

The food was ok, the coffee good, and the setting very cute, but I probably wouldn't return. Fillmore is full of so many cute little places, I would just move down a block and try another one!
author: Ahu S.

description:
I thought this place was good, but not great. To be fair I may not have  ordered the best thing on the menu. My friend and I got omelets. Tasty but could have used more cheese and all the good stuff. Oh, and the sides are  more like garnish; so expect reasonable French portions, not excessive American ones ;) 

The ambiance is cute, people seemed pleased, but I have to say the service was pretty slow and a lot of the time we felt like they forgot about us. All that said, I would give it another shot for dinner or something.
author: Shirin M.

description:
Looking for a great brunch spot post dog walking at Alta Plaza Park?  Give Chouquet's a shot!  The large outdoor patio (very dog friendly) caught our attention but the great food and friendly service will be what brings me back.

Croque Madame?  Oui, s'il vous plat
author: phil h.

description:
We came here for Dine About Town and were very pleased. The restaurant is small and cute, although it became rather loud. There's really no room for people who are waiting for their table, so it becomes crowded quickly.

The DAT menu is generous, offering 3 choices per course. We had the smoked trout salad (great, and the winner of the course) and the baramundi rolls (good), the gnocchi (good) and the lamb (absolutely brilliant, best dish of the night), and for dessert had the chocolate fondant (lava cake, winner of dessert) and the rum-soaked donut-type thing (good, but can't compete with the fondant).

I also had a great glass of Syrah, and my (non-alcohol drinking) wife had the "innocent passion" drink, which was very good.

The service was good and efficient -- we were done eating in just over an hour. I enjoyed the attentive, but unobtrusive service.

I've been by this place many times, but never eaten here. We'd definitely come here again. And we'll probably both get the lamb.
author: Kellie P.

description:
I'm a fan of this place. I had brunch here, and the seating outside (weather permitting) is lovely. Good selection of common brunch items, with good presentation and service.

I had the benedict, which is served with red potatoes; I'm a traditionalist at heart, sorry I can't report on a more adventurous pick. Benedict was very good, and portion of potatoes was conservative, but good (I'm not especially fond of a plate filled halfway with potatoes served with your eggs).

Service: Good

Food: Above average-Good

Ambiance: Good

Good place for a date, very cozy and cute. I'd imagine dinner would be romantic, and from my glance at their dinner menu, worth the trip down Fillmore to this cute restaurant.
author: Albany A.

description:
Je n'ai savais pas que tu peux parler en francais... Quoi d'autres suprises que tu gardes dans l'avenir...Je me suis envahis par ta sagesse et la simplicite de tes mots- assures et cordiales...Merci pour ton humeur sans rival!
Ok the omelletes were magnanimously stuffed with gruyere and good to the last bacon bits !  But coffee could be stronger- AND soy lattes could be a healthy addition too (-1 star).
A la prochaine fois ;-)
author: Arissa C.

description:
Went tonight with some friends and did the "Dine About Town" menu.  We were seated right away which was great. The restaurant is really clean and there is no stinky grease or "Restaurant" smell. So far so good.

We sat down and our server greeted us. He was very nice, pleasant and made some great rec's. We ordered and were really pleased with our food. Everything tasted great, but it wasn't a lot of food. It was definitely a light meal - which was fine. But just FYI. 

Suddenly, we noticed that the place was getting REALLY busy. Then we realized there were only 2 servers in the entire restaurant. It's not a huge place, but still. Suddenly, 30 freakin' minutes had passed and we still didn't have our check.

It was annoying because we wanted to leave and it was literally 30 minutes before we could get our check. We felt bad for the servers, but c'mon, what kind of management is this? did someone call in sick? that kind of ruined our buzz and left a bad taste in our mouths.
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
I would drive across town for their croque monsieur for brunch any day.  Light brioche bread toasted perfectly, not too much cheese, delicate thinly sliced ham.  Magnifique, honh honh honhhhhh!!  

Coolio modern design.  Dig the orange countertops that flow right up the walls as a painted orange wave.  Earthy modern wood tables.  Sleek glass sink in the bathroom. 

The Il Flottante(sp!) dessert is goooood.  Milky vanilla cream with a floating island of chewy sweet egg whip, covered with caramel.  Wow.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Hey, your place is totally cute. Hey, you forgot to put stuff in your salad.

Hey, CORRELATION...?
author: Shannon V.

description:
The tell it like it is part of me wants to write my most scathing yelp to date. The optimistic in me wants to point out what little went right in what might have been my worst brunch experience in the city. I'll compromise:

- Upon arriving, we were passed over in getting a table, even though we had a reservation. Then the hostess darted away to do something behind the bar. Um, OK. We were left standing not sure what to do. This led us to eat outside, only place empty tables, which ended up not being that bad.

- After sitting, coffee and water took an exceptionally long time to arrive. But it could have been worse, the people next to us were served tea but no cups. And they still had no cups after asking once. Twice did the trick.

- The facial expression on our waiter, Stephane, made it clear he did not like me at all as I requested egg whites and no oil in my omelet. And I thought I'd be kicked out when I asked for fruit instead of potatoes. He tried to discourage me by saying that would be $3 extra. I kindly accepted, knowing that on the plus side, this was only adding further foundation to a one star review.

- Requests for ketchup were forgotten once, but it did finally arrive. At least quicker then those cups for tea next door.

- Stephane didn't return once to see how our meal was. At least mine was OK. Fellow yelper Louis M. thought his salad was saturated with dressing and his benedict subpar. I'll let him get into the details.

- My dish was missing the salad, and when I told Stephane about this when we asked for the bill, he didn't really care. But on the other hand, his horrendous service made me feel totally fine not leaving a tip, pretty much getting me back the $3 I spent on fruit.

- At least the company was good.

I look forward to never returning, and telling everyone I can to avoid this place (and Stephane) at all costs.
author: Jason B.

description: I went there last night at 9:15 for a glass of wine with a friend and they said they were closed. Really, because the sign on your door says you are open until 10pm. I used to go there a lot because I live in the neighborhood but not anymore. The blond waitress was super rude.
author: Amy T.

description: Came back after 4 years. I live so close but somehow skipped this place after my first try.
