Well today is the turning point because I had a great lunch here and really enjoyed the experience. I will be back regularly now that I am reminded that this place has delicious food and really good service.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Dine About Town 2008

Soup Du Jour  -- Friends thought this was okay.
or
Crispy rolls of Baramundi with a ginger & coriander infusion  -- Was quite yummy -- I liked the ginger & coriander infusion
or
Butter lettuce salad with a balsamic vinaigrette -- HUGE portion


Second Course
Gnocchi with ricotta cheese and asparagus~lemon oil emulsion  -- Very tasty & pretty rich
or
7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes -- SMALL portion!
or
Ahi Tuna Carpaccio with shoe string potatoes and mizuna salad -- very good


Third Course
Floating Island -- if you want something light, this is what you should get.  It's like this marshmellow foamy thing...
or
Chocolate Fondant -- if you like chocolate-- THIS is what you should get!
or
Tarte Tatin -- if you like apple sauce...you'd like this.


Service -- very slow.  At one point during the evening, I believe there was only one waiter.  It took greater than 30 minutes before we got our drinks and the waiter took our orders.

Oh...and they played Michael Jackson!  Hmmm...
author: Lise T.

description: Hey, it's restaurant week, people, and Chouquet's on Fillmore/Washington is one of the few places offering two courses for lunch that aren't dumbed-down.  GET OVER THERE and sit outside if the weather holds.  You can choose appetizer/main or main/dessert.  I had a gorgeous salade nicoise with real ahi (not the canned stuff), followed by mushroom ravioli served with lightly sauteed fresh veggies.  For under $18 in San Francisco?  A deal.
author: B G.

description:
I'm a little surprised by the poor reviews this place has gotten.  In my non-expert opinion, they have some of the best brunch in all of San francisco.  There is nothing better IMHO than going to Chouquet's on a lazy Sunday morning, drinking coffee, eating an amazing brunch outside and reading the paper. The Gruyere cheese on the Omelette Paysanne (with ham, gruyre, & mushrooms ) and on the Omelette Parisienne (with prosciutto, gruyre, & mushrooms)  truly makes the omelette's the most delicious in the city.  They have a great South facing outdoor patio and lots of good eye candy walking by headed for the park.  

I would've given this place 5 stars, but I have to agree with some of the previous posters that the service is a little slow. Otherwise the food and the ambiance is top notch.
author: Spencer G.

description: I love this little french spot. Tucked away in a quiet corner on Fillmore. Food is unassumingly good - meaning it doesn't try to fool you with fancy presentation. The food is simply good and speaks for itself.
author: N. C.

description:
You can't beat the Pac Heights location for people-ogling and outdoor seating.  The menu is very limited for brunch (salad before 11am?  before coffee?  hmmmmm, that's a bit difficult to stomach).
Sit outside if you can get a table (we didn't) - better vibe than inside, which is coolly retro/modern, but a bit sterile.

We decided on a Croque Monsieur (which we breakfasted-up by asking the kitchen to add a fried egg on top and turn into a Croque Madame - they kindly did so.  Trust me, it's WAY better).  It was well-prepared without being too heavy/greasy, and the salad was well dressed.  

The omelet selection bugged me - you start off at $7-8 and then have to pay $1 each for each ingredient - couldn't they throw in 1 or 2 for free at least?  Or come up with a few suggestions (tomato, onion, chevre) for a set price?  Too...much...thinking...for...first....meal....of...the...day.

I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but it's a dependable place for a casual meal if you're in the neighborhood, and I'm there pretty often so I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Liz S.

description: Another excellent experience here.  Great food, great service, lovely intimate ambiance, and they made our special occasion even more memorable.  Two enthusiastic thumbs up!
author: Molly P.

description: I had a nice lunch here with my husband - it's very casual and a little pricey but the food was good, wine list was great and it had a cute atmosphere. It has a great outdoor seating arrangement for sunny days and the wait staff was friendly yet discreet. I saw a lot of people ordering a glass of wine with an appetizer and it looks like a great place to do that and catch up - I don't think I would come back for a full meal - the food was ok but nothing special.
author: Amy D.

description:
My husband and I still come here occasionally and lately we have been getting another brunch entree than what we used to get.

We now tend to get their Croque-madame.  Croque Madame at Chouquets is served as a giant slice of country bread with ham & tons of cheese on top, with a fried egg over it.  Side: green salad.  When we first tried this dish we really really liked it, but the last time we were there (and after we've ordered the same dish at Le Garage in Sausalito) we both felt that Le Garage served way better Croque Madame and the one here at Chouquets are generally too cooked.... bread hard/too toasted, fried egg not runny at all... also felt that it had borderline too much cheese and was salty.

We still like the general dining experience here, but I might revert back to Eggs Benedict and stick with it : P
author: Sascha O.

description:
I came here for the first time today with a girlfriend of mine who lives in the neighborhood and had a WONDERFUL experience.  I mean, I'm sure the fact that the sun was shining and that we scored an awesome curbside table enhances my review, but we also had great service and delicious dishes.

I ordered the Trout Salad with Fingerling Potatoes and was oh-so-pleased with the end result.  Come here on a Sunday, grab a girlfriend or two and order a Mimosa -- a perfect way to start your Sunday!  ;-)
author: Katie C.

description:
Came here the other night with my bff, Lily R for the Dine-About-Town menu.  It's a small, intimate restaurant on charming Filmore street right in the heart of Pacific Heights.  The ambiance is warm and inviting, very cute!! The service was very good and our server was very attentive! After reviewing the full menu, we opted to pass on the 3 course tasting menu and go for items that weren't offered for DAT. 

We started with the smoked trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad.  It is a warm salad and had the most amazing flavors, I literally was scraping the bowl for every BITE! We were excited that the appetizer alone was impressive, the entrees MUST be nothing short of fantastic.  

Sure enough, Choquet's did not disappoint!  I had the rigatoni with truffles, chanterelles & foie gras.  All I can say is WOW! I've decided that truffles make every meal magical lol!  I ate each bite so slowly, savoring every taste sensation!!! Lily R. ordered the black risotto with scallops & laughing bird prawns vadouvan emulsion.  The unique spices and seasonings in this dish were incredible!!! 

By this point we were stuffed and could not force ourselves to get dessert! (which is a great excuse to come back.....SOON!) I loved this place and I'm so excited that it's right in my neighborhood!
author: Candice M.

description:
I should've walked away when I wasn't greeted when I walked in to get a table, but the reviews on here were decent.  It took about 15 minutes for a patio seat to clear up (we had our dog with us), then it took them another 10 minutes to set the table, also an additional 10 minutes to even get us a menu.  I was really hoping the food was awesome because again, Yelp rarely fails me.  

My latte came out about 20 minutes after we sat down, it was decent.  Then the water came out, finally our food.  I ordered the omelet with gruyere, prosciotto.  It sounded tasty, but it was really greasy, no seasoning.  The salad that came with it was limp and the potatoes were tasteless.  My boyfriend ordered the hamburger, which looked better than my food.  He said it was okay.  

I don't think I'll come back to this place, especially since the wait staff was not apologetic at all to making us wait so long (it wasn't that busy).
author: Rachael J.

description: Was suprise with all the negative reviews that this place is getting. I came here twice already and they have been okay so far. The food is good, small portion, european style. Service is not bad. The place is small and they have outdoor seating, can be a problem if it is too cold outside. This place is pretty popular for brunch but I have been here for late lunch and dinner. Overall, I like this place. I think that the bad review could have been from the prix fix menu price that they offer which I have never tried out for myself.
author: J C.

description:
i came here for a saturday afternoon lunch and I was very disappointed. First of all there was no one to greet us, just 2 wait staff and bus boy. Finally I got one of the waiters attention after standing in the doorway for a good 5 minutes we were seated..and we sat...and we sat some more. No water was brought over, no bread with butter. I finally flagged the waitress again and told her we were ready for our order. Another good 10-15 min go by and i had to flag the other waiter to let him know we had no bread or water or knives which i have to say he brought over very quickly after the fact. As far as the food, the trout salad was good but the gazpacho was too acidic. overall I was extremely not impressed by this place. Bummer because I was excited to try it, but doubt Ill ever go again. 

Pro:  Great bread (once they ever bring it to you) 
Con: Bad Service.
author: Hot Tequila B.

description:
My S.O. and I went here with three friends during Dine About Town on Sunday, June 8, 2008. Our reservation was for 7:00 PM, and our table inside was ready immediately.

I enjoyed the menu's variety, and Choquet's let two from our party split one Dine About Town meal at no extra charge.

Here's what we got:

- Soupe du jour, which was a creamed mixed vegetable
- Crispy rolls of Baramundi with a ginger & coriander infusion (Tasty, but not out of this world, as they just tasted like greasy Chinese spring rolls to me....)

---

- Ahi Tuna Carpaccio with shoe string potatoes and mizuna salad (My friends said that the dressing over the salad was good but that the acid was overwhelming the taste of the tuna, and I agree. The tuna itself was perfectly prepared.)
- 7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes (The lamb fell apart when I looked at it, and the mashed potatoes were creamy. Delicious.)

---

- Chocolate fondant with whipped cream (This is what it says on their current menu on their Web site, but it was more like a chocolate lava cake with ice cream and chocolate sauce. Warm chocolate oozed out of the center of the cake. This was melt-in-your-mouth delicious, and I usually always opt for the vanilla or fruit option.)
- Apple tartin (Subtle flavor. In a dessert match, I felt that the chocolate fondant pummeled the apple tartin.)

We also ordered a bottle of "Friendly Wine," which was the Argentinian Malbec. A little spicy, which we all enjoyed. Still easy to drink without overpowering the meal.

Our server was attentive, yet also didn't make us feel rushed. Nice combination.

I'd return, but only for another Dine About Town next year, as the prices are a bit steep if ordering all of the courses from the regular menu.
author: Wendy K.

description: Highly recommend the oyster, escargot and chocolate fondant. All dishes were well prepared tonight
author: Hippo T.

description:
This is easily a favorite. Typical Upper Fillmore feel, for better or for worse... In my case, I found it delightful! The servers were polite and even, at times, friendly, which is a great deal both for San Francisco service and for French people (I kid, I kid). 

The food was scrumptious: we ordered the arugula shrimp salad and the smoked trout salad, which were both light and tasty, and topped the meal off with a couple of wine glasses, a filling cheese platter (with lovely jam and perfectly toasted slices), and a delicious espresso. Although it's on the expensive side, the good-quality food, the pleasant ambiance, the tasteful decor, and the abounding natural light flooding in through the large street windows make this an ideal spot for a weekend brunch. I recommend you snatch a table by the window and let Chouquet's do the rest! You won't be disappointed.
author: G. J.

description:
Food was good and the Virgin Mary was also good. Service was also good.
We went for lunch/brunch on New Years day.
Our server comes to take our order and tells us they are out of eggs, yes eggs! Needless to say this was kind of a surprise,how does a restaurant serve brunch and run out of eggs at 1pm?
Table next to us sent their order back because the eggs were almost hard boiled in eggs Benedict but they got new orders? Thought they were out of eggs! My salad Nicoise was not going to have the egg but then it did? And we saw a couple of omelettes? Really strange.
At least our server comped us our drinks to apologize but come on.
Won't ever go back
author: Fabienne M.

description:
I'm not buying all these crappy reviews.

1) People whine when snotty French restaurants don't have French waitstaff.  Well, this one does--and guess what, they act like snotty French people.  Be careful what you wish for, I guess.
2) It's overpriced.  Of course it's overpriced, you're eating at a French restaurant in Pac Heights.  If you know of any similar establishments with $7 entrees then please tell us hill-dwelling Yelpers all about them.

I've eaten here twice and both experiences were positive.  They did serve one of the most watery, tasteless espressos I've ever had, though.
author: S P.

description:
Meh, not that great.
Really disappointing Burger, the cheese looked like Kraft Singles and there was more bun than meat. The Chicken club was turkey not chicken. The bread was soggy and the "bacon" was Canadian ew.
The only thing that saved us was the fries.
    It's too bad, my friend that took me here comes for dinner all the time. She was really disappointed and it was enough for me to not make it a dining option.
author: Douggers M.

description:
UPDATE: received from Jay G:

14 hours ago 
  hi, this is JB , chouquets restaurant manager. I just wanted to tell you that after our chef 
arrived on JAN 5th, we closed for a week, cleaned the whole place and refreshed it while our
kitchen staff was working on the new menu.

We are celebrating our 2nd anniversary with a  free sampling food and wine
night on thursday 25th of January.

I d really like you to come so it may change your impressions on your last experience.

Feel free to bring a guest with you.

Looking forward to see you then,

J
********************

Wanted to sit outside with pookey and had smoked salmon benedict, coffee, and just thought waitress' FLoggie scowl was not worth the price. Hey lady, you are the slave here, if you don't wanna be here, get one chain saw to wipe your scowl off and get it re-sewn in Paris why don't you! Damn merde face, merde service, makes just hyper priced merde food.
author: miriam b.

description:
Came here for brunch, and
Oysters on a half shell--gooood. but i guess it's hard to mess up raw oysters, unless the quality of oysters aren't that good.
Arugula salad w/grapefruit and shrimp--dressing was really good, had some mint (which i'll have to try at home) but the shrimp was a little too cooked.
I had the florentine eggs, and it was okay, but I would say I still like crepevine's better. The hollandaise was a little bland, and though it was a cool concept to put little croissant rounds rather than english muffins, I think I still like the traditional style better. My friend had the turkey club sandwich and he said it was just okay. They did have homemade chips that were pretty good though. It came with this aioli dip that I think it tasted fine w/out, and the aioli actually was kinda bland too...i could do w/out the extra fat if it has no flavor.
Oh, and the service was heeeeeeelllllaaaaa slow....

I always wanted to try this place, but meh...
author: Emy s.

description:
This place is great! I eat here at least once every two weeks.

Located on the corner of Washington and Fillmore, this restaurant enjoys benefits of being slightly off the beaten path of the Fillmore hustle and bustle, giving it more of a relaxed neighborhood vibe. Perfect for before or after visiting Alta Plaza Park or the Fillmore shops... the lunch here has made me a lover of salads AND I highly recommend their goat cheese tart as well!!! SO GOOD. The creamy goat cheese, tomatoes, flaky crust, basil, and balsamic reduction make it an excellent dish worth savoring. 

This place is great for a relaxed or romantic dinner. I occasionally enjoy a lovely dinner here, then take a leisurely stroll down Fillmore to the Kabuki theater for drinks and a movie. For dinner, I recommend trying a few of their appetizers. My new favorite is currently the beef tartar. It's fantastic. The burger is delicious and satisfying choice, though if you're feeling like ravioli... the mushroom ravioli dish is positively out of this world delicious. YUM. 

All in all, I honestly love the food and staff here. They are really trying to switch things up. The adorable brunette waitress quickly became one of my favorites with her excellent wine suggestions, and the sexy french waiter is charming, efficient and nice to look at. Yum again. Always a gold star in my book!
author: Kate W.

description: ok this place is terrible for brunch. I mean Denny's would have satisfied me more.  We got a $15 omelot and it sucked.
author: nicole s.

description:
I would prefer to Yelp about places I love and recommend.  But, I had such a bad experience at this place that I feel compelled to warn others against it.

To begin, my friend and I waited for 15 minutes to be seated.  The cafe was only half full and there seemed to be plenty of staff on hand.  When we realized that no one planned on helping us, we asked it we could seat ourselves.  Once seated, it took an inordinate amount of time to get water and menus.  Though the food was good, it was not special.  Think of any little French cafe in the city and there you have Chouquet's.  The worst part of the meal was waiting for the check.  I swear to you, two other parties were seated, ordered, and one of them was served before the bill arrived.  This was a service nightmare.  Bottom line, I am not opposed to enduring pain for great food.  But, this meal did not begin to warrant such excruciatingly bad service.

As I side note, I promised to share that the iced tea here is not freshly brewed.  My lunch companion is a self proclaimed "iced tea snob"; she did not approve.
author: Margo C.

description:
Went back tonight and was sat at the bar due to it being fully booked.
Foodwise: Solid. I had the fillet and I asked for it to be rare and it was spot on perfect. That doesn't happen often when I eat out!
A few more veg options would be nice, my date had to combine the goat tart with salad and fries, however, he was very happy with it.
Servicewise: It is a relaxed place. You have to be prepared some thing to take a bit longer (not the delivery of food though once you order). We didn't feel pressured and enjoyed a lovely casual meal.
author: Mirto H.

description:
Chouquet's is cute, cute, cute! So, went their on a Saturday night for dinner and sat outside under the very comfortable and chic heatlamps.  People...I am always freakin cold and even I was comfortable.  I had the duck in the honey sauce and i was FABO! 

Most importantly though, they had several very cute Frenchie (is that politically correct) waiters.  I don't care what they were saying or what they were serving.  It all sounded very Frenchie to me.  

Definately sit outside to people watch and have the French donuts for desert
author: Jachyn D.

description: Escargot was succulent and the Moules frites were delicious. Prompt and courteous service and an excellent wine selection made for a very enjoyable dinner. Loved it.
author: Robert M.

description:
Yummy brunch with five girls on Memorial Day Monday.  We had some frustration with getting seated -- we think the waiter never told the hostess when he took our name, and we ended up wasting 30 min waiting.  But once we figured out what went wrong, the hostess tried to be as accommodating as possible, and though it was another 15 minutes, did some rearranging to get us a nice outdoor table.

We were famished and had orders of their Niman Ranch burgers all around.  I hear the fries are great.  I also got an order of gazpacho which was good - comes with enormous toasted bread sticks with onion butter.  A little overboard for a refreshing little soup but good.

I'd love to go back to try the rest of their menu, looked yummy.
author: Aki N.

description:
I started with the butter lettuce salad with balsamic dressing. It was the entire head of lettuce (served intact) which left me perplexed for a few moments.  How does one eat an entire head of lettuce presented so sculpturally? You just figure it out!  Great balsamic dressing and overall a great salad/head of lettuce!

When the entres were served, we knew we were in for an amazing meal. Visually stunning, artistic culinary presentations were just the start. I selected the filet de boeuf with a green peppercorn sauce.

If you have read my review of Rue Saint Jacques, you know I can be challenged by French chefs' definition of medium rare, medium, etc. I was in a particularly agreeable and forgetful mood as I happily ordered my filet medium rare.  Just as good beef should be prepared, yes?  YES! YES! YES! The chef de cuisine (Laurent something or another) truly understands how to prepare an excellent beef dish.  The meat was very much in the French fashion of medium rare; very rare in the center, but truly delectable. The peppercorn sauce was truly amazing and likely had enough crack (aka butter), that I am now addicted.  Wonderful fresh herb garni that brought flavors to yet another level. 

Ambiance is fine; nothing particularly outstanding, but very comfortable.  Service is very good; lovely French accents abound.  Prices are reasonable for such a great meal. Wine list is good!  We did ogle other entrees served to our neighbors (hard not too in this very cozy spot); while we certainly feel we ordered the best dishes, their dishes (including the tuna carpaccio) looked to be equally delish.
author: Danielle R.

description: good place for brunch, not too hard to get a table and located on a great street.
author: Adrian B.

description:
Delicious!!!!
Cute little french restaurant with awesome food.  We started with the goat cheese tart, which of course, was wonderful...but anything with cheese I love. I had the Atlantic Halibut with a delicious mushroom and tomato marmelade. My mom had the 7 hour braised lamb which melted in my mouth...and I don't normally like lamb. And the mashed potatoes...hands down the best potatoes I have ever had. For dessert with had the chocolate fondant...YUM!!!! Portions were not huge, but I left very full and very satisfied.
author: izzie B.

description:
Stopped in Chouquet's for brunch before the Fillmore jazz festival.

Liked: Eggs benedict, bread and Bloody Mary were very good. Restaurant was clean and had great window space.

Not so much: Tables and chairs are not comfy and close together. The host (owner? server? - I dont know) was on his cell phone while on the floor - in French nonetheless. Hmmm, not super profesh in my opinion.

The menu looked quite diverse. I would stop here again for the good quality.
author: Michelle M.

description:
DAMN eddie. (that's right, I can call the chef out by name). Anyway, we've followed him to a few places but this one? it is GOOD.
the scallops are killer. outstanding. 

good crab salad.. the veggie cassoulet is hearty and tasty.

oh! and how could i forget! chef blyden's signature grilled squid salad. tenderlicousness.
author: Margie L.

description:
Sleek decor inside.
I recommend the outdoor seating on a nice day.
Food is really good, salads are great, deserts are excellent.
Service has always been courteous and fast.
author: Elle H.

description:
Having read the reviews that were posted here prior to eating at Chouquet's, I was admittedly a little nervous about my dining experience. However, i was incredibly suprised at the quality of the three dishes that me and my friend consumed.
We started with the prawns..they were sumptious and cooked perfectly. Next up was the suprise fromagere...it tasted so good i wanted more...a lot more. The main entree was Steamed Salmon with Sauce Maltaise,and Pommes Persilles. Perfectly cooked, one of the best pieces of salmon i have had a sf restaurant in a while. 
We couldnt help but order two desserts: chocolate souffle and a floating merengue(?) with tiramisu....insane.
The service was done with a smile by Michael(sp?) and added to a perfect dining experience. 
I will be back!
author: Not M.

description:
We had dinner here recently.  it was a warm day and all the outside tables were spoken for, so we had to sit inside where the temperature had to be in the upper 80s since there was no air conditioning.  

Overall, it was not a good experience.  The service was indifferent and the food was so so.  I had the Waygu burger.  While it was okay, it wasn't what I would expect from a $16 burger.  My wife had their chicken.  It had a pleasing sauce, but the chicken itself was woefully undercooked.  We would have sent it back, but trying to get the attention to our server was very difficult.

So if you like indifferent service and poorly prepared food, this is the place for you.
author: Tim R.

description:
Excellent.

Soup was great, tuna good, maybe not quite enough, but then had dessert.

Portions are small, but enough.

Service was hands off and what was needed.
author: Rachel T.

description: Chouquet's is a nice local French restaurant.  The wine list is inexpensive but high quality, and the food was fantastic.  I loved the filet mignon au poivre and the creme brulee was perfection.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Very cute corner restaurant that Hue L., our non-yelper friend, and I went to for DAT.  

Ambiance:  Very cute.  Tables are all small and very close together.  It looks bigger from the outside, but is actually quite small.  

Service:  Not very good at all.  We had to wait quite a while for a table, even though we made reservations.  And we had to ask the waiter repeatedly for things like water and coffee and the waiter would forget.  We'd have to ask again or, as in the coffee, never get it.

Food:  GOOD!!!  I had the Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad to start.  It was super yummy.  I was a little hesitant about having a fish salad, but it was really good.  And the potatoes were yum!  The combination of the warm with the cold salad was really good.  For my entree I had the 7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes.  It was really yummy!  The lamb pretty much just fell apart.  No knife necessary.  And the mashed potatoes were sooooo good!  I'd go back just for the mashed potatoes.  For dessert I had the chocolate fondant.  It was pretty good.  Melty chocolate oozing out of the center.  Yum!

Final word.  I'd go back.  It's a little pricey and the service isn't that great, but the food is yum.
author: Kris L.

description: They have mimosas, great service, and horribly uncomfortable chairs (minus one star). The food looked great but since I don't eat until after 10 p.m. or a bottle of wine (whichever comes first), I stuck to pushing  the fruit bowl around and making other people eat it. There is a cute, enclosed, and heated patio that I think I'd like to sit on if they let you smoke out there (they don't). They were super sweet about the birthday boy we were there with and brought some delicious dessert and let us sing "happy birthday" badly and loudly during their brunch rush. Can't wait to come back for dinner- perfect place for low-key, laid back vibe but serious french bistro food.
author: Autumn K.

description: What can I say? My Baby and me tried you guys out for dinner the other night... BLAND, BLAND, BLAND!!! My kobe burger was crap! If that was kobe beef, I am the French prime minaster! The fries were the worst I have ever eaten.. anyplace! soggy crud! You should be ashamed! Places like you give Mc 'D's a good name! My Babies asparagus frisee, had like one runt piece of asparagus in it.. Plus half of what they stated was on my burger wasn't there? We had to send back the "flat" soda's we had ordered as well...The Orangina drink was the only thing with taste or bubbles... YOU GUYS SUCK!!! NEVER GOING BACK!!!
author: Kirk M.

description:
Cute, 1/2 below ground level French restaurant, complete with French-speaking waitstaff. They were friendly, attentive, and patient. Nice weeknight dinner. Close to home.

The goat cheese and tomato starter I could have skipped. My meal, however, the mussels in white wine, garlic, herb, and butter sauce, however, was exquisite! Frites delish. My co-diner's steak was also superb but probably not the best steak ever experienced. They had the new Beaujolais Nouveau, served chilled, very inexpensive. 

The tables along the window facing Fillmore all share one long booth style seat on one side, making things somewhat cozy with your neighbors and conversations at other tables impossible to ignore. 

This place is fairly reasonably priced for this neighborhood and cuisine. 

*bit concerned after reading Al L.'s review...and sadly, I was there around the same time, but never saw anything amiss.
author: Angela N.

description:
This is a great little neighborhood spot....at least that's the impression I got on the night we were there.

Luckily it wasn't too crowded and the night was not too cold so we opted to sit outside which also had heat lamps...which was perfect!

Since I was craving a burger, I went for the Wagyu beef kobe burger, pommes gaufrette, butter lettuce, organic tomato, applewood bacon, red onions, duck fat galette & choron sauce!  Yummy!

Of course I nibbled on and tasted my honey's plates...which were part of the Dine About Town menu (4 course meal of Soup, Gazpacho with toasted bread and the most amazing online butter!!, then the Seared Ahi Tuna in sesame seeds with Mizuna & Cucumber salad!)
The final and 4th dish was the most incredible chocolatey filled bit of goodness of a cake that makes you feel like you are living heaven on earth!
yes- it was THAT good!

We told ourselves that we have to go back to this place.
The quality of the food was superb.
We had an exceptional experience all around!
author: Ahnee M.

description:
French is my favorite type of cuisine. Chouquet's definitely hit the spot. Small and cozy, Chouquet's is the perfect restaurant for small groups and date nights. It's dim lit but looks inviting. They also have a cute bar that serves fun girly drinks. I had the organic veggie salad, the seared duck breast, and some sort of gelato chocolate thing for dessert. All very yummy. 

My only complaint is that they weren't perfect with service. I originally had a reservation at 8 but called the day before to change it to 8:30. They said it's fine, but when we arrived at 8:30, they were not aware of my reschedule and had already given away our table. We had an additional 15 minute wait. 

No biggie, just sat at the bar :D

Thumbs up!
author: Han C.

description:
Brunch @ Chouquet's = love.

Smoked salmon benedict = love.
Croque-Madame with a green salad = super love.
Omelette Parisienne with prosciutto, gruyère, & mushrooms = super duper love.
author: Jenny L.

description: I had brunch here with a few long time friends. We meet periodically to catch and this time we decided to meet up for brunch here. I liked the bright orange decor; it was very fitting for a bright sunny day. I was the last to show up in a group of six. They have outside seating but we sat inside.The server immediately offered me a glass of fresh orange juice or grapefruit juice.  I had the vegetarian omlette. I asked if they could make the  omlette with egg quites and the server obliged. The servings were European portions and tasty. However, the server did get a few of our orders confused. Overall: nice place with cute colorful decor and it's great for a beautiful sunny Sunday morning or afternoon.
author: Mike L.

description: My Girlfriend and I went here for lunch.  The service and food were substandard.  My order came out wrong and my girlfriends dish was over cooked.  The server never came back to see how our food was.  I hate wasting money.
author: Arron F.

description:
It sucked.  Period.  It took an hour...let me repeat...an HOUR to get a head of butter lettuce in a plain balsamic dressing.

NEVER AGAIN.
author: Joanne B.

description:
Ate here for brunch on Sunday afternoon.  Arrived around 1:15 PM, got seated right away inside.  No hassle.  1 star.

Ordered the omelette paysanne, which was accompanied by a mixed green salad (fantastic dressing) and potatoes.  The omellete was tasty, nothing special, and the potatoes left something to be desired.  

Since I was hungry, I ate all of it and afterwards my friend and I ordered the warm chocolate hazelnut and banana crumble which was delicious.  1 star.

After brunch I ordered a mocha, which was a little watered down and tasted as if someone mixed a packet of "DIY Mocha" with instructions that read, "Just Add Water!"  -1 star.  

The waiter never came back to refill our water glasses until the end of our meal when I requested a refill.  -1 star.  

Not a bad brunch spot, a little crowded at times, absolutely awesome people watching spot with a great location for shopping afterwards. 1 star.
author: Dennis M.

description:
I had a lovely time brunching at Choquet's yesterday. My friend and I both ordered the omelette with prosciutto, mushrooms, and gruyere. Oh goodness- the prosciutto was excellent- thick chunks of prosciutto. I was in heaven. The gruyere and mushrooms went with it well. The omelette came with some mixed greens and a bowl of fresh fruit. Every single piece of fruit was perfectly ripe- impressive. 

It stayed true to French food right down to the portions. There was not too much food and I left feeling just perfectly full. The service was great- I love that they take reservations for brunch. Our waitress who was French, was polite, pleasant, and gorgeous. I will definitely be coming back to Choquet's for brunch.
author: Laura D.

description: This place gets mediocre reviews, but I had brunch with my fiance over the weekend and we thought it was the best breakfast we had had in a long time.  We had the Smoked salmon Bénédict and Omelette Parisienne with prosciutto, gruyère, & mushrooms.  The best omlette I've had...not greasy like you get at Elite.  Everything was fresh.  Service was prompt.  Definitely will go back because there was no wait & the food was good!  While we were there, there was a party of 10 so it's good for groups also.
author: Kim D.

description:
Lets begin with the good: 

1. Outstanding wine list. My roommate tried a Bordeaux (and let me try) and  it was outstanding. I had one of their whites from the Loire Valley. It was wonderful.
2. The atmosphere was everything one would expect on Fillmore Street. Adorable.

Now, the not-so-good:

1. The food was only so-so. There was nothing memorable about the food. My roommate and I shared a chicken dish that, although it had a nice presentation, was dry and bland. We also tried their sea food chowder which was ultimately just really salty. 

If someone else was paying I would be willing to try again, however, I do not think I will be returning to this restaurant any time in the near future.
author: Laura M.

description:
Artsy. Bathetic. Calming. 

Great place for brunch!  Service isn't the fastest, but the servers certainly are friendly and flirty.  

Sat outside on a pleasantly sunny day for brunch with a gf.  The food isn't memorable, but isn't bad by any means.  Points for pretty presentation and great service bread.  Portions are slightly lacking, but it would betray the French to serve belly bursting orders of smoked salmon benedict.

Interior is accented with sexy red walls and gives off artsy feel.

$$Prices are reasonable for French brunch cuisine.  $8-15 for brunch items.  

Looks like this place does a 180 for dinner with dim lights for a more sensual feel.
author: Jane L.

description:
Chouquet's was a very nice surprise.  It was empty on a Thursday night - which was very strange to me.  The food was excellent - within our group, I tried the butter lettuce salad, the crispy rolls, the halibut and two divine desserts.  The wine recommendation was also wonderful.  

It warrants 3 stars for the service.  Not that it was snotty or rude, quite the contrary actually, but the wait between courses was excruciatingly long.  I very much enjoy a leisurely meal, but this was pushing it.  Slow service never sits well with me, especially in an empty restaurant.  I will say, it was so artfully presented on the plate it almost makes me fill guilty for complaining...
author: Kristin K.

description:
I want to start off by saying that I actually signed up for Yelp just now to write this review.   I'll start out positive, the restaurant is cute and intimate and we were seated with no wait at all.  

Shortly after being seated the busboy accidentally spilled an entire glass of water into my lap.  I'm not talking a little bump and some water jumps out, I'm talking an ENTIRE glass of water right into the lap.  Completely soaking through my pants.   While an unfortunate event, this is not why I am writing a bad review of the restaurant.  The busboy was very apologetic, running back and forth to get towels, and even taking my coat to the back room to dry off.  I thought he handled the situation very well given the circumstance.  I mean, accidents happen to everyone.  It was the management that was so disappointing.  There were only two other people working in there (our waitress and someone i assumed to be the manager), and neither even looked up to acknowledge that I was soaking wet and freezing.  I mean, it's a small place, and it was definitely a noticeable accident...I screamed for god's sake, it was an entire glass of water down my front.  The manager did however seem to notice that my coat was back in their kitchen...I could see the busboy explaining what had happened and watched as they had an animated conversation about it.  You would think this would be a great time for the manager to come over to check on us or to ask if there was anything they could do.  They did NOT do any of this.  They completely ignored the whole thing.  When the huge bill came at the end of dinner, they had not even comped us a drink or dessert.  At the very least, that would have been the professional thing to do.  Nope, no acknowledgement at all.

And since I've made an account just to write this review, I might as well comment on the food.  The onion soup and tuna tartare I thought were pretty good.  The entrees however, were very unimpressive.  The filet mignon was super raw, even though requested medium, and the pork special was extremely overcooked.  Overall it was unfortunate that we chose this restaurant and I won't be back.

I really hope the nice man that spilt the glass of water doesn't get in trouble for this review.  He earned the only star that I'm giving to this restaurant.
author: Mary C.

description:
la nourriture ici est trs bonne, mais mon Franais n'est pas.

Its cute, its white, its orange, its French. It's french. I love the french and all they do. In my eyes, they can do no harm. Except when I order some dessert with is pretty much an island of meringue in a sweet cream ocean, that was my fault,  I should know better not to order anything with meringue in the description. Their es cargo was trs magnifique, prepared  on little endive leafs and lightly seared with some tasty seasoning. My favorite dish so far was some duck breast medallions with figs and a citrus sauce, but it wasn't on the menu last time I went, and I kind of died a little inside. 

I hear they have a good brunch, but I am too busy at the bottomless mimosa spots in the city to venture here.

Does anyone know who designed the resto? I would like to know, if you do, please tell me and I will pay you back with a hug.
author: danny e.

description: Love. Went for brunch today and sat outside. The croque monsieur was the best I have had in the states, and better than the one I cook at home. The service was prompt,the champagne was delicious, the area is adorable. The place is definitely on the smaller side so I wouldn't come with a group larger than 4.
author: Kaytee M.

description:
Dinner at Chouquet's is consistently excellent.

Over the past six months, someone in my party or I have tried everything on the menu except for the escargots and the saumon au riz noir. Not one dish disappointed, but a few were especially memorable: the french onion soup, trout mâche salad, moules marinières, filet mignon, and crème brûlée. Each surpassed expectations and was properly prepared -- the French way.

The ambiance is casual/intimate. Dishes are reasonably priced given the high quality and consistency. Bring a date, eat well, and enjoy each others company.
author: Zack B.

description:
Yet, there are even more reasons Chouquet's is my go-to French spot in both my neighborhood and the entire city.

1. It is modern French and not insanely rich (I am not really into loads of butter and my tummy is sensitive)

2. Fresh ingredients. The organic veggie salad is a must and all ingredients in the salad are purchased from local farmer's market

3. Ambiance. Small and charming, great staff. 

4. Cocktails. Must try a "Chouquet's" martini. A variation of the mundane French Martini but so much better with the fresh Mango. If they are out of Mango, Peach is an excellent substitute ($7.50).

5. Dessert. They are french, enough said. Great sweets, cheeses and the espresso is good.

Check this place out! Their menu is constantly changing and doesn't disappoint.
author: Theresa T.

description: Absolutely wonderful. The very cute french waiters amplify the French dining experience. The food was delicious, dessert chocolate lava cake was melt-in-your-mouth orgasmic. The service is attentive, and the super cute waiters offered to take pictures of my roommate and I. It was a perfect way to start off a Sunday morning which lead to some sunny  Fillmore shopping.
author: Michelle A.

description: Ordered the mushroom ravioli and 7hr braised lamb. The mushroom ravioli was OK but tasted like it came out of the freezer aisle of a grocery store. The braised lamb was tender but the sauce was kind of goopy.  For the price, the food is NOT worth it. $18 for 5 pieces of ravioli, and $24 for 4 small chunks of lamb, definitely disappointed.  Luckily we had a groupon so it ended up being bearable. Service is kind of slow given that they were fairly empty, but they were nice when available. If you want to give it a try make sure you get the groupon NOW.
author: Aj P.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of Chouquet.  On the plus side, it's right in my immediate neighborhood (which, let's face it, not a whole lot of places are), they seem to always have oysters, the decor is cute, and the food is yummy.  On the other hand, they only have one vegetarian entree (gnocci with vegetables), which is fine because it's a really good one, but it would be awesome if there were other options.  Most of their menu is focused on meat.  I guess, uh, because it's French.  

I took my dad here when he came to visit, and we had a lovely meal.  The chocolate desserts were great, but the creme brulee was oddly watery--I probably wouldn't get that again.  

Anyway, I just want to warn (and amuse) others regarding this totally insane and weird guy that sometimes hangs out at the bar there.  He harassed me for the entire 45 minutes it took me to have dinner (granted, I was dining alone, and obviously women who are alone are "asking for it," right?  no).  He acted like he was just joking around, but he was really being rude and annoying, asking me personal questions and making fun of what I was reading.  I blame my girlfriend for standing me up for dinner.  But the wait staff was really apologetic and sympathetic to me about it.  Of course, the most sympathetic thing they could have done would have been to kick him out, but I guess I'll save my "getting others kicked out" karma for bars, not cute little French restaurants!
author: Rebecca N.

description:
Fourth and last Dine About Town. 

THE WINNER! SO good! Who woulda thunk it?

I had never, ever heard of this place, but their menu caught the eye of my friend, Kara A., when she was reviewing some dinner options on Open Table...what can I say, she's got a good eye! 

I had: Crispy rolls of baramundi...Wow. Gnocchi w/ ricotta and pine nuts...DOUBLE WOW! and to finish, the molten lava cake...the hot chocolate lava was just gushing out of it....the only thing that would've   made it more perfect would be if it came with vanilla ice cream instead of whipped cream. 

Very beautifully presented plates, too, and pretty small portions (I actually see small portions as an asset...hey, it allows me to EAT more!)...but the flavors were all so great. My friends said that the 7 hour roasted lamb was tender and amazing, and they both loved the truffled mashed potatoes that came with it! We brought a personal wine and paid a corkage ($20).

This was a definite value for Dine About Town! LOVED it, will definitely consider going back, too...small, intimate, romantic, authentic french service, and nice burnt orange and wood decor. Spectacular!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Super cute bright restaurant in a great neighborhood!  I came here on a Sunday evening with a party of 5, parking wasn't bad at all.  From the Dine About Town menu, I got:

- Crispy rolls of Baramundi: really great presentation on a rough cut stone slab. The rolls were tiny and kind of tasted like any other fried spring roll, but came with a side of funnel salad of some sort.  Cute and small.
- 7 hour braised lamb: the most heavenly mashed potatoes I've ever had. The lamb was melty and good, but I was confused about the circular disc shape.. Didn't know lamb came cookie cutter style :)
- Apple tartin dessert: subtle, delicate, great combination of flavor and texture.

I would definitely come here again for a non-DAT meal!
author: Wendy T.

description:
My friends and I came for the Dine About Town 2008 menu. From the previous reviews, doesn't seem like a lot of people picked the Gnocchi. I liked it. (I thought it was good for lumps of dough anyways, but I guess it's not really worth it.) I regret not getting the chocolate desert though.  it looked good with all that molten chocolate flowing from the center. I got the apple-tart instead, which wasn't bad, but I'm sure it would have been better with molten applesauce flowing from the center.

So I have to talk about the bathroom. Don't get me wrong, the bathroom was clean and smelled Glade-fresh. This is probably because the guy before me used the provided Glade spray to mask his lingering odor. I also think he, with good intentions, opened the very tiny window that faces Filmore street to air out the room. I noticed this as I was "cranking out the juice." All the while, I wondered if it there was such a thing as a one-sided window screen. I was (un)lucky enough that I didn't need to find out since no one walked by. When I left the restaurant, I ran around on Filmore St just to find out, and the answer is no. So make sure that window is closed before doing your business. I'm sure you wouldn't want people see you.. uh peeing, pooping, or snorting cocaine or anything.
author: Hue L.

description:
A nice lunch spot with my girl J-Bear pre-work.

   Exuding French-ness, down to the French conversation I totally eavesdropped on (men in every country can't get enough lesbian viewing, apparently), and even our waitress sounded straight out of Nice.

   Food was good, but I wasn't too stoked on the price of the veggie marinara pasta.  I could have made it myself for about 50 cents, but it's all about the experience, right? 
 
  I did immensely enjoy the organic veggie salad, but seriously, I mean SERIOUSLY, did that menu say $22.00??  Twenty-two, in case it works better for you spatially if it's spelled out.  I opted for the smaller 14.00 version (which wasn't sprinkled with gold nuggets, pearls, or fire opals).  They were sneaky about getting the cucumber in there, slivered into pieces so small, they practically Bondo-d themselves to every frond of lettuce.  I really hate cucumber, so this was not a good thing for me; I spent most of my meal disbanding frisee and cuke marriages.

   Miss J had the club sandwich, which she, too, was dismayed to find had copious amounts of hidden cucumber nestled in its' folds.  Does a Club typically have cuke?  No clue, but it rubbed her the wrong way.  

   There was also a ridiculous amount of mayo, which does not a good Club make.  She ate one triangle of her sammy and let the rest go.  Oddly, she was never asked if she wanted it to go, a question that should be fresh on the lips of any server who sees you've eaten none of your meal.  Perhaps our petite cherie knows the Club should remain something you beat your man over the head with when he comes home drunk and smelling like Eau de Stripper.  Not something you order at Chouquet's.

   Overall, way too pricey for what we got, but decent service and nice outdoor seating.
author: Lea N.

description:
How do I put this, hummm, The service was great. I had my starter the Spinach / pear salad. Very good I might say. 

 Well I know that sometimes you will see a roach, time and again. But more than one. I was cool until I watched three then a fourth come frolic on the mirror behind the bar. 
Our server under stood and we left. I hear they are changing chef's and cleaning the place up. Maybe a try later will be in order.
author: WildBill C.

description:
We went here for dinner and had a 3 course menu. It was great. Service was very friendly and attentive, the food was really good. Mmmmh, those truffled mashed potatoes and the lamb shoulder, mmmmh, those ricotta gnocchis..
and the dessert was also a very exciting experience, especially the warm chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream but also the sponge cake that sucks up the rum, if you like rum.
My co-worker said she's known this place for many years, first it was great, then it sucked for a while and recently it has consistently been great again, so we wanted to try it.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
If I could give this place 3.5 stars I would.  I don't mind it but its not my go-to place for eggs benedict and mimosas.  I will say their food presentation is decent and its a treat to eat outside in warm weather.  
As for service, its not super fast nor super slow. Its the right brunch pace where you are attended to and not pushed out the door.  I give them mad props just for that.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Had been here many times before today but will never go back. The most recent changes of staff and management have destroyed any allegiance I have. I'll spare you the details other than to say that the waitress who worked our table copped a major attitude about turning on the heat-lamps and lowering the canopy telling us that if it is cold why don't we just go the hell inside instead of inconveniencing her this way. She then brought us the wrong drinks (simple mistake that could have easily been rectified) copped an even worse attitude, refused to admit her mistake and started a heated slanging match with us, accusing us of not knowing the difference between Sierra Nevada and Kronenbourg (I mean, duuuuh!) It went from bad to worse and ultimately required the manager's intervention to calm her down and stop her shouting at us, but still no apology was forthcoming from either manager or waitress.

So... If you like going to places where the attitude from incompetent staff and uncaring management is "Eff you, Mr stupid American customer" be my guest, knock yourself out and experience it for yourself.

As for me, I will never go back. There are plenty of other places on Fillmore to eat and drink where regular customers' business is valued and the staff are competent and courteous.

Hard to see this place staying in business if this is the experience they offer.
author: Nigel R.

description:
I had dinner here tonight for the second time, and so far I've been pretty happy with this place.  I had the steak frites, which was good, with an overly generous helping of the frites.  Also had a glass of a really delicious malbec.  The desserts are good, too - the profiteroles were yummy, as was the mango creme brulee I had last time.   Or if you don't really want dessert, you can just have the little cookies that they present with your bill.

Our waitress was very gracious and attentive, and advised us to wait a few minutes for a better table to open up, which we appreciated.  However, the guy who brought out our steaks mixed them up, giving my well-done steak to my friend who ordered his medium, and vice versa.  We didn't discover the mistake until we were halfway done.  Also, another waiter didn't ask if we wanted more wine before clearing our wine glasses away, which we thought was weird.  Oh well. 

I like a place with outdoor seating, but when I ate outside last time I got a little cold -- I could've used a stronger heatlamp!  Or maybe I'll just do outdoor seating during the daytime only.  But there were still a few people sitting outside when we left at ten tonight...what a nice spot for a rare warm-ish night.

12/07 Update: They serve a really nice brunch here - Chouquet is a good choice if you're on Fillmore and looking for some place a little bit nicer for breakfast than Crepevine or The Grove.  The omelet was delicious (and not too huge) and the potatoes were perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  I actually wouldn't have minded a bigger serving, but at least this way I didn't feel like I had to waddle out of the restaurant afterwards.
author: DD B.

description:
From all of San Francisco's Dine About Town menus, Chouquet's had the most alluring one.  It was a full 3 course price fix dinner for $31.95. In all honestly, I was on a date when I came here so I was more focused on the conversation than the food. However, I do remember some of it though their online menu has changed so I cannot recall everything.

ATMOSPHERE:
Very romantic. It is a small intimate place with dim lights. The location is great as it is on Fillmore street where many interesting shops are. Though, parking can be tricky.

SERVICE:
Good - nothing to complain about.

MENU:
It looked good. Like many price fix menus, it wasn't a large menu, but had enough delicious choices to have you scratching your head.

FOOD:
My date and I shared to optimize on the variety. For the first course, I got the ragout of veal sweetbreads (glands) with wild mushrooms. It had a very strong salty and organsy flavor and the balls (size and perhaps texture of testicles) were floating in a bed of thick sauce. It was good to sop up the sauce with the provided bread. My date had a multi-layered thing. I don't recall what the layers were but it was quite good.

For my main entree, I went with mussels which is one of my classic favorites. I cannot recall what my date had as I was clearly focusing on my mussels (cough) I mean his advice on getting a promotion.

By the time it was time for dessert, I was full. We peered at the table next to us and one woman had a strawberries and cream parfait. Being the sheep that I am, I followed suit. It was great - light and creamy and fresh. I forgot what my date had. 

Apparently, as the meal went on, our sharing decreased. By dessert, we were hugging our plates.

VALUE:
I didn't pay so it's hard for me to say. It wasn't cheap though, so if I had paid, I may have felt a little gypped. Perhaps it was my choices - the sweetbreads being a little too salty and the mussels being too...easy. The dessert was easy too but tasted oh so good.

OVERALL:
Romantic restaurant so it's great for a date. The food is pretty good but not the best I've had for Dine About Town.  Interesting because their foods seemed to either be safe foods (mussels) or unique foods  (sweetbread). Based on how many other great restaurants in San Francisco, I would probably recommend some of the others over Chouquet's. 

(January 2007)
author: Alice H.

description:
The best thing about this place is the patio: big, sunny and has heaters overhead that come in handy on chilly Sunday mornings. 

As for the rest of the brunch experience, given how many great restaurants there are in this city, I would recommend you pass on Chouquet.  The menu is pretty limited: your choice includes eggs, croque three ways or a burger.  We ordered omelets are were sorely disappointed.  My friend's 3 egg omelet showed up with the wrong ingredients.  My garden omelet was cold inside (note to chef: making the filling in advance might save you time, but remember to reheat it at the very least).  I asked for no potatoes and extra salad but got the opposite.  The potatoes were so fried that they were dark brown and I highly doubt there was much starchy goodness left. 

Finally, two pet peeves of mine: they only have full fat milk and they charge a ridiculous price ($4.50) for half a wine glass of grapefruit juice.   

You're better off going down to Curbside Cafe or the Grove.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Chouquet's is a personal favorite, an unpretentious place with interesting food and kindly service.

An old friend was in town and we trolled up and down Union Street, checked out Greens at Fort Mason, looked up and down Chestnut Street, but nothing was appetizing or sufficiently attractive.  

What to do but fall back on a old favorite, Chouquet's, and they did not disappoint.  

Hurrah!  See you again soon.

==========================================
PS I see from reading some of the other comments that the Dine About Town group has been to Chouquet's, perhaps several times; good for them, they know a good dinner when they consume one.  

But a suggestion for Chouquet's:  some time ago, we stopped in without reservations at Chouquet's (which usually works, but I do try to call ahead at least) and were told there were no tables available, which seemed odd, because the place was nearly empty.  When we expressed surprise, wondering if there was a new chichi dress code, one of the workers replied breathlessly that Dine About Town was due to arrive.  

Okay, that's a perfectly reasonable business approach, BUT it made us feel like chopped liver.  It would have been fine to be told "A very large party was about to arrive, but we hope you will visit us again soon."  To be told that someone more important and exciting was arriving soon was not very welcoming.  It took a while for us to try Chouquet's again.  Just a thought.
author: jack c.

description:
Ok, for me to give a place only 1 star is a sad thing.
The reason for this is the service (or lack thereof).  There is/was a waitress who works there that is so incredibly rude (not just once, but all 3 times that I've been there), that I refuse to go back.  I felt rushed and was refused "special" menu alterations when it was entirely possible to accommodate me.
I definitely don't think the food is worth more than 2 stars. The soup I had the last time I was here seemed like it was just cream & pepper - the salad was bland - the dessert was so-so. 
A sad overall experience my friends. Which sucks, 'cause it's so darn close to home.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
We frequent Chouquet's for a weekend brunch in Pac Heights.  If you call ahead and make reservations, your wait will be nonexistent - which is always a plus with me.  My favorite is sitting outside (on the Washington side), with a view of the park and people out playing with their pups.   (Added bonus to animal lovers!  It's located right across the street from Pets Unlimited.)

I'm surprised to see that so many Yelpers have had bad experiences with the service here - service for me has always prompt and friendly, and very prompt on the water and coffee refills.  I'd recommend the egg dishes or salads - a little on the pricey side, but given the location and quality, it's expected.
author: Tina H.

description:
A few Sunday nights ago, we celebrated a birthday here.  The service was great - very accomodating, they even let us bring our own cake and didn't charge us for plating (and the chef made us a big bowl of whip cream too).  

The food, however, was very "eh."   My vegetarian "cassoulet" was more of a boring bean soup - not much flavor to be found.  Mister Francophile's salmon was equally so-so.  Nothing particularly wrong, the food just didn't sing to us.  Even though they theoretically close at 10, by 9 they were starting to break down for the evening, and we were one of only two tables there.  With so much outstanding food in the city, I just don't see a reason to go back.
author: Katy M.

description:
I was here for Brunch with a friend for our annual holiday get together. I'm getting lazy and don't feel like writing a story so I will review this place by category ;)

Location: Good but hard to find parking

Atmosphere:  Love the outdoor seating and intimate environment

Price:  Reasonable

Service:  Acceptable

Food:  Eggs Benedict, Excellent!   but the Spinach, Mushroom omelette was a little disappointing.

If I have a craving for Eggs Benedict, I will surely come back here.
author: Anna L.

description: This is a great place to meet up with friends for a nice lunch or dinner. Stopped by last night to meet a friend and ordered the house salad and Creekstone filet de boeuf with sesame gremolata & peppercorn sauce & fries. Yum!  I love the sauce they serve on their filet! Service is always great here and the food is fresh and tasty.
author: Cat K.

description: One of our favorites in San  Francisco great bistro style food
author: Mario c.

description:
I really love this place! The atmosphere is cute and the food is delicious. I've been for brunch and dinner, and I have to say I like the dinner even more than the eggs benedict (this is one of my favorite spots to get it because the hollandaise is light and lemony, which I find to be a tasty twist to what is usually a lot of butter). The oysters they have are awesome!

I've been here 4 times at least in the past 4 or 5 months, and have only seen one bad dish -- a lone breakfast special among a plethora of marvelously delicious entrees. This is a great neighborhood place and my boyfriend and I will continue to be repeat customers.
author: Michelle W.

description: I've been here maybe 4 times for dinner.  The service is always good.  The food is always tasty although I wouldn't say it's exceptional....except for the kobe burger which rocks.   Decent wines by the glass.  The menu has something for everyone although it's not especially creative or exotic.  What I like about Chouquet's is that is has a nice bistro feel, good service, and consistent quality but since it's not uber-trendy you can have a very nice dinner without having to book a week in advance.  It's my go-to place when I want to dine somewhere yummy on a Friday night last minute.
author: Melanie L.

description:
I stumbled upon Chouquet's when trying to find a restaurant in Pacific Heights. Wasn't sure if I'd be in the mood for French food, but I was quite pleased. Lo and behold, they took part in Dine About Town, and so I grabbed at the chance for the 3-course.

1) Smoked Trout with fingerling potatoes & mache salad:  YUMMY! It was a warm salad, and I rarely try those types. But the flavors melded together so smoothly it left me wanting more!

2) Seared Ahi Tuna in sesame seeds with Mizuna & Cucumbers salad in Meyer lemon dressing: Equally YUMMY. Although, I suppose it also could have passed for an appetizer. Portion size was just larger as an entree. 

3) Warm chocolate hazelnut & banana crumble: TO DIE FOR! This dessert was made so fresh, hot out of the oven. I'm also a huge banana fan, so this dessert couldn't have been more perfect.

I definitely plan on trying them out again someday.....
author: Janet R.

description:
I have lived on Fillmore for three years and up until now- hadn't ventured in to Chouquets. I figured I should try it since it's in my neighborhood and I've tried just about every other place on Fillmore. 
I am a big sucker for brunch, LOVE Bloody Mary's and hopefully Eggs Benedict. I searched the brunch menu on-line and saw that Chouquets had both of my cravings so off we went! 
We sat outside and the staff were kind enough to turn the heat lamps on since it wasn't exactly a warm morning. The waitstaff was friendly and no-fuss, our server appeared to be the only one in the entire place that morning (poor girl). 
I ordered the Omelette Paysanne with ham, gruyère, & mushrooms and a Bloody Mary, my husband ordered the Smoked Salmon Benedict and a coffee. 
The Bloody Mary was pretty good although I was really disappointed that it came with 2 little pickles and a piece of lemon instead of lime and celery. I realize they don't have a full bar so its neat that they are creative enough to find a way to make Bloody Marys (so essential to any "brunch"). The coffee was delicious- seriously, get the coffee. 
Our food came pretty quick, which surprised me, until I cut in to my omelet. I was severely disappointed. The omelet looked like a perfectly groomed egg omelet but once you cut in, all the filling came out- but it wasn't the ooey gooey filling that I was hoping for, it was almost not cooked. The ham and mushrooms were diced so small that I could barely eat them with my fork- and the topper was that the Gruyere wasn't even melted! It was grated cheese and you could see it on the inside of the omelet but it didn't' melt enough to hold the goodies inside. Really terrible, almost inedible. 
My husband had the Smoked Salmon and the salmon was good- the Benedict as a whole was good but not great. It appeared that they make their own biscuits but they weren't my favorite. 
Both of our dishes came with a salad that we both agreed was the best part of the meal- whatever dressing they are using is fantastic! But, again, the salad was mediocre, it was just greens- nothing else tossed with it. 
When you live on Fillmore, i don't see why you would go to Chouquets when you have SPQR, The Grove, and The Elite Cafe just down the street, same price range, and fantastic food.
author: Janell D.

description:
I usually stay away from French places, cause I never have much luck with vegetarian options, but this place turned out to be a winner for both me and my carnivorous date.   I had walked by this place lots of time in Fillmore and liked the cozy interior. Stepping in, you're greeted by a modern interior and  soft lighting. 

Along with a bread basket, you're gifted with a yummy tomato caponata and garlic toasts.   I guess the caponata replaces the butter, and in this case, it did the trick.  The wine list is pretty extensive, covering many of the major wine regions in the world. My only complaint is that some of the more interesting sounding wines are only available by the bottle.

My dishes: 
Appetizer: Green Salad.  Portion-wise, it was largeish- more than I am accustomed to getting in most restaurants.  Simply dressed with a lemon vinagrette, it was tart without making my mouth too puckery.

Entree: Millefeuille of Eggplant, Zucchini, and Chevre.  a WINNER. I found it well seasoned and again, quite filling.   I agree with the previous reviewer--not quite 100 slices, but preety damn good at about 7!

Entree #2: Steak Frites.  My date's clean plate says it all!. The fries were crispy, lightly salted, and thoroughly addicting!

Dessert: Chocolate Fondant- crispy on the outside, gooey on the inside and real whipped cream to spoon on top.   This was the only course where the portion was small,  but between me and my date, I think it was just about enough to sate us and push us into pleasant food comas.

Extras: With the bill, you get little yummy cookies--macaroons, I think.

I would definitely go back here when I'm in the mood for a mellow meal--not a destination dinner, but one that folks who live within walking distance are lucky to have!
author: Smruti S.

description:
Mileu:
Small, uncomfortable seating.  Cold.  

Service:
Waitress was okay, but dude, this place was so small, and she really did not have too many people the wait.  I don't know.  Poor service.  Plus, they made us wait in line when there were open tables, and we had reservations.  

Food:
Not great especially for how much you are paying.  I will definitely not go back here ever.  Even their wine was not great.  For sure I will never go back.  Man, I even spent so much at this place.  It sucks.
author: M L.

description:
I do not know if there is a curse on the premises or what..... This establishment used to be called Pauli's. The food has not changed, in fact it has gotten worse since you really cannot tell what is on the menu since there is a huge french twist to everything. 

I ordered the spinach salad. How could someone mess up a spinach salad I asked myself. i thought i was safe. WRONG! It was bland and overdone with walnuts. The plus side is if you are looking for a pretty presentation on your plate (big whoop and no food) here is the place to go.
author: Jeannine V.

description:
Yum! What a cute little place on Fillmore that was easily ignored until now. I came here on Sunday for a Father's day dinner with my family. We were able to try the dine about town menu which was delicious. I thought the food quality was really good but the portions were a bit smaller than expected. 

We had the tuna salad, vegetable soup, gnocchi, braised lamb, chocolate cake, and floating island. Everything and I mean everything was very tasty! I even found myself trying to pick out the flavors of each dish to see if I could recreate it in my own kitchen. I was stuffed full by the end and happily surprised that I had found a new restaurant to frequent on Fillmore. Who doesn't love another cute French restaurant to add to their list?
author: Josephine L.

description: Had a lovely brunch with my hubby.  Service was fast and efficient, despite the mother's day crowd.  Recommendations are the Turkey Club and any omlet.  It is not often that you go to restaurants and receive the correct amount of food that a human should consume.  I left feeling happy, and the perfect amount of "full"..
author: Roya T.

description: The service was great, as was the atmosphere. Unfortunately the food was the letdown. The steakburger was unremarkable, the fries the greasy limp kind, and the bloody mary was just tomato juice with soju (no spice at all). My date's salmon was adequate, but again you can do a lot better for the money.
author: Sean F.

description: I am very disappointed in this restaurant. I made reservations 3 weeks in advance for Valentine's Day dinner through their Web site that directed me to Open Table. I was happy to get a reservation when I wanted with no issues. I looked at the menu and found a few items that I would enjoy and my wife said there were only two things on the menu that she would eat. 4 days before Valentine's Day the restaurant called to confirm and then told me that it was a prix fixe menu for the night. She said that I could go to their Web site to view the menu. First, that was the first I had heard about the prix fixe menu, which triples the cost of dinner. Second, the menu was NOT on the Web site as stated. Not knowing what we were going to eat, I had to cancel the reservation, and at that late date, where are you going to find a good meal. My issue is not about the menu or the price, it is about the fact that we were not given notice until 4 days before the big event. Too bad, I was looking forward to Chouquet's. Now it is off the list on principle.
author: Ken M.

description: Little overpriced for smallish portions.  Par for french restaurants in this neighborhood.
author: Eugene P.

description:
Disclaimer: This review might be biased because I have not found a french restaurant that appeals to my (rather pedestrian) taste.

Dinner for 3 will run ~95 total after 3 entrees, tax, tip, and 2 virgin drinks.  My gf thoroughly enjoyed the kobe beef burger.  I thought the filet de boeuf was adequate.  My friend was appalled to discover only a single thinly-sliced piece of beef in her carpaccio dish.
author: Duy V.

description: Service was good, trout salad was yummy but the fries that came with my meal were soggy and barely warm. :( I'm pretty disappointed... I gave my food away but not the salad though. lol
author: Mayana P.

description: Casual yet Fancy. I bought a great deal Groupon for this restaurant, and we ordered Clam Chowder, Kobe Beef Burgers, and drank champagne. The Clam Chowder was not what i was used to. It was very fancy and very tasty...Tasted like it was freshly made and had a smooth consistency. I would visit again.
author: Ana S.

description:
I have been going to Chouquet for a long time- but today was my last brunch there. The food is priced comparable to much better French places like Absinthe, and the quality just does NOT match up. I got a $16 penne dish today, coldish, and I could have done better at Pasta Pomodoro. The Eggs Benedict ordered at my table were a bit pathetic too.

In addition, the sour-faced waitstaff destroy the experience. No one checked if the food was ok, I had to wait 10 minutes to catch someone's eye to get fresh ground pepper. My coffee ($2.50) was cold, and I was not offered to freshen it up. Every neighborhood diner knows better. There was no cutlery on our table, and I finally had to resort to stealing forks from the next table. The only smile and eye contact I got was with the bill!

I say you cant have it both ways- you can have indifferent food and service with high prices. Specially in SF.
author: Geetika G.

description:
I also did their 2007 Dine About Town menu, and I am never going back again... until their new chef comes. Did you know our waiter told us they haven't had a chef in 2 years and their menu hasn't changed since? 

"It's totally unheard of.. and I'm surprised we're still around after 2 years!" ~ our waiter.

My friend had the Veal Sweetbread, the Millefeuille d'aubergine, and the Creme Brulee. I had the escargots, the mussels, and the melba. 

All of her food were just mediocre, nothing to "wow!" about. The sweetbread was a very thick portion for an appetizer! I didn't know there was a white meat veal.. it looked and tasted like chicken.

Then there was my food. The escargots.. dry and grainy. I prefer to actually dig it out of the shell, so I know what I'm eating is relatively fresh. Mussels were alright.. then comes the melba. My friend almost spat that out because it tasted like it was fermenting! And trust me.. we're definitely NOT picky eaters.

I almost gave this place a 1 star, but I'll throw another in because of ONE waiter's service. He kept apologizing for our waiter because he:

1) never refilled our water.. EVER.
2) didn't give me a bowl to put the shells in
3) where are our butter knives?
4) forgot out 2 spoons.. after we told him 2 times.

I felt bad for the nice waiter. At least he was nice enough to inform us that they ran out of the soup, crab salad, AND the chicken. Oh right.. and they don't have a chef, but when the non-English speaking Parisian chef comes, they're going to redecorate the place, fix the crooked awning, AND change the entire menu. Stay tuned!
author: Natalie Y.

description:
Our server only showed up twice--one to take our orders and the second time to give us our bill. I thought they switched waiters on us in the middle of our dinner because we saw someone else come over to our table more than him.  Big No-no! 
The food was way tooo salty--the appetizer (duck) and chicken entree left my mouth tasting yucky.  We ordered the Apple Cinnamon dessert thingee, strawberry porfiterole looking thing and the chocolate soufflee for dessert. If you want dessert, do NOT order anything except the chocolate soufflee. It was alright but it was better than everything else.  
I don't think I'll be going back to this joint for awhile...or ever!
author: Bren L.

description:
Go eat here!

My bf and I had a wonderful dinner here last week...

We had for starters: 
Pan-seared 4-spice Foie Gras served chilled with honey & a fig chutney ---ok, HE had this and loved it, MY conscience in still clear

Main course:
Ahi Tuna Carpaccio with shoe string potatoes and mizuna salad 
----so FRESH so YUMMY so FLAVORFUL

Fillet de Boeuf with sesame gremolata & fries
----Tender, Tasty, and they sure make a mean fry! That's French Fries!

Desert:
Warm CHOcolate hazelnut & banana crumble
----think melted Nutella and take me now!


Service was knowledgeable and courteous- it was a simple and unpretentious affair-- definetly will go back for the same meal!
author: J S.

description:
Chouquet's is a French restaurant located off of Filmore street in the Pacific Heights, an area full of fancy restaurants and boutiques; most of the stores in the area were private with very few chainstores. I went to this restaurant with a group of chefs; we all liked it. The quality of my meal was very good, almost everything is made from scratch including the desert; which is usually 'outsourced'.

Here's what I had for an entree : 7-Hour Braised Shoulder of Lamb with truffled mashed potatoes & Morrel. For dessert I had: Homemade Baba au Rhum with light Vanilla Cream.

For a fancy French place the waitstaff was pretty cool, (I like their French accents), though the service can be pokey. If it weren't so darn expensive I would go back more often.
author: vinh t.

description:
Any place you can tolerate (let alone love) with a splitting head-ache and sparingly little sleep is A-OK. Chouquet's is a perfect place for brunch or lunch and quite lovely for dinner as well. It looks totally different in the evening, by the way. 

The food's great and the house selection of bay fresh "beautiful people" is impressive. Act now. They go bad after a day.

Five is a bit of a stretch but someone unfairly gave this place a "1."
author: Michael P.

description:
The food is delicious and well presented at this quaint neighborhood bistro. Sadly, the poor service is almost unparalleled. In fact, it was probably one of my top 5 worst dining experiences ever, and I wished I had walked up the street to eat at the Crepevine. 

It all started when we arrived at noon on a beautiful Sunday. We were seated immediately (thumbs up). Then, 15 minutes passed before our server greeted us (thumbs down). I had a feeling the restaurant was slammed, so I encouraged my dining guests to place their food order along with our drink orders.  Our drinks arrived 20 minutes after the bread was placed on the table, I had to get up to get silverware to spread butter with, and then when the food finally did arrive, our server messed up the order. AAAGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG! 

The quiche was good, but not good enough to counteract my frustration over the service. Our lunch lasted an hour and a half becuase of poor service.
