To add insult to injury, the iced tea isnt even freshly brewed... it is from concentrate and has a wierd acidic after taste to it.
author: M T.

description:
Burger is very good. 2 stars for that.

I asked for mayo, and got aioli. I asked for mayo, not aioli, a blonde guy with a French accent said it was mayo. I said,  its not its aioli and he walked away. 

People, French or American - mayo doesnt have herbs in it, umkay? Just say we dont have any!!

Tables are too squished together, service not friendly.

Over all - meh.
author: renee m.

description:
Arguably my favorite place to have brunch on a nice weekend morning/afternoon.  The food is consistently great (I love the omelettes and my boyfriend will never order anything but the marinated salmon, its delish), and they have absolutely wonderful fresh sqeezed oj and grapefruit juice--hits the spot after a long night.

It is always easy to get a great little table outside in the sun, surrounded by friendly people, with dogs and babies in tow.  The service is always fine, something about being greeted by "Bonjour bonjour!" just makes me smile, and our food has always come out pretty quickly and my whole party has always been served at once.

Never been here for anything but brunch on sunny days (I have never sat inside), but highly recommended for great food at reasonable prices, and great atmosphere!
author: Megan Z.

description:
First DAT restaurant of 2009. Leaning towards 3.5 stars.. I'd go back and try their other dinner menu items or brunch.

Decor: cute, modern but neighborhoody 
Food: baramundi crispy rolls, 7hr braised lamb w/ truffled mash, chocolate fondant. I would get the smoked trout salad over the baramundi crispy rolls. The entree was good-lamb was tender; the appetizer and dessert were okay- nothing amazing. I did like the fondant cake over the floating island. And they did have the cabernet franc I really enjoy - maybe thats why I'm inclined to give the exta 1/2 star. 
Service: really nice waiter and staff in general, attentive and friendly (and they were French- which is cute for French restaurants)
Price point: Would I be happy paying the normal price for the food? Probably not entirely..Chapeau! and Fringale still ranks higher in my book for food. But they did have a cute/comfy space with quick service. Although I did go on a Thursday night so I have no idea how crowded weekends get...
author: Monica P.

description:
Went here on a Saturday afternoon for late lunch.  We sat outside on thier patio, which is a prime peice of people watching real estate.  

Unfortunately, the food was a complete dissapointment.  We ordered an omelette and the "kobe" hamburger -- which should be right in the wheelhouse of a French bistro on Pac Heights/Fillmore....

The omelette was something out of Mel's Diner and the home fries were just below that level.  Totally unimpressive.

The burger was worse.  The patty, which was completely well-done (they did not ask us how we wanted it), was way too small for the bun and the bun was mealy and untoasted.   The worst part --- we ordered it with cheddar, but they used american cheese (congealed to the top of the patty).  Now, I am all for american cheese when we go to in'n'out for a double-double, but at a french bistro in Pac Heights, when we are paying $12 for a "kobe" hamburger -- I expected more.  I will admit that the fries were actually pretty good.  Also, the lemonade were ordered was not real -- tasted like a generic Walmart powder version. Very disapointing.

The waitstaff was friendly and re-filled the waters frequently. 

Ultimately, I would reccomend coming here for a latte or a glass of wine.  Dont come if you want a good meal --money would be much better spent at Crepevine...
author: Alon R.

description: Small Portions.  High Prices.  Average Taste.  Ambiance sub par for french restaurant.
author: ron a.

description:
My husband and I love having brunch/lunch here. I nearly always have the goat cheese/roasted vegetable tart, and my husband tends to try different things each time.  We stopped by for dinner recently, however, and didn't like the menu as much.  Some of the lunch items were on it, but the overall selection seemed small.

The outdoor tables, surrounded by a plastic tarp/tent, remind me very much of being in Paris. The clientele is very chic San Francisco, however.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
very creative french cuisine. Fin et savoureux.
small and cosy, and quiet. Nice atmosphere for a small table.

Prix fixe 35$ before 7:30pm (never tried).
Une bonne adresse
Nice people
author: armelle p.

description:
One of my favorite spots for lunch and brunch. I love to eat al fresco when the weather is fine and in is just as well. I have only had wonderful times dining here and bring friends when they're available =) 
I enjoy the club sandwich  especially and the eggs benedict of course. I also enjoy the niman Burger et pommes frites... well really I have enjoyed everything. I have usually come for leisurely dining so I am never in much of a hurry; I prefer to enjoy my meals, so I never really noticed if the service was not speedy enough for some.
My advice: relax and enjoy, c'est la vie....
author: RojiFox Q.

description:
I ordered the Penne and halfway through my dish I find a hair in my food!

My friend ordered the same dish and guess what he finds? Another hair.

And although I do prefer some hair on a man, my food is the last place I'd like to see some. 

As expected, they offered to replace our dishes with others on the menu. My friend enjoyed the pasta so much that he ordered the same thing (but didn't look too closely for hairs this time). I opted for the oysters, which were not fresh at all and tasted horrible. I contemplated not eating them for fear of getting sick. I left the restaurant disgusted and hungry... 

By far the worst meal I've had in a long, long time.
author: Alex A.

description:
Been there for both Brunch and Dinner. The Brunch is 4 star, while the dinner is about a 3. 

The service was great both times, but the dinner left me wanting more.
author: yoni s.

description:
Yummy!

I love this place.  Early evenings are the best before the Marina crowds arrives.  Goat cheese and tomato tart with Balsamic makes me drool.   Great Friendly Staff.
author: Forrest G.

description: Since coming here the first time, I've returned twice.  I've come for lunch as well as dinner.  Both times the food was terrific and the service was quite good.  I've come with three different groups of people and each different group has said they've enjoyed their experience and they are likely to return.
author: Jenn A.

description:
My wife and I found this place while shopping on Filmore for furnishings and home goods. It resembled a little French cafe, without the service. It appeared it was a one man show, but the food was a pleasant surprise.  Portions were good, and we sat outside and enjoyed people watching.
Not a good place to go unless you have a few hours to kill.
author: mike s.

description: Had the penne pasta.  It was average.  Noodles were a bit too soft.
author: Adam B.

description:
Their Eggs Benedict were very disappointing.  They shouldn't call them Eggs Benedict.  The watery sauce wasn't Hollandaise sauce,  the English muffins were replaced with old, stale bread, and the eggs were cold and not cooked as requested.  

The service was so-so, slightly better than the food.
author: Emma Q.

description: Chouquet's is one of those places that either blows your mind or disappoints you because it didn't live up to the last time you were there when it blew your wine.  Try it first for brunch or lunch and order a glass or two of French wine for the full experience.
author: Richard B.

description: We really enjoyed this little bistro place for dinner. It is very casual, with big windows and little wooden chairs with a lot of small tables for 2 people. The seafood dishes e.g. mussels, escargot, etc were lovely and the steak was divinely cooked, just until it was brown through but incredibly tender. The salads were very nicely done. The coffee was excellent quality and the wine list was small but solid. We did have a few tiny little quibbles which is why this didn't quite make 5 stars: a bit heavy on the salt on the green beans, and the french fries were mushy rather than crisp. The waitstaff was polite, helpful, friendly without being intrusive, and relatively prompt. They were nice about extra requests for napkins, extra plate, etc. This was an impulse last minute dinner plan and because of that we chose this previously unknown restaurant on opentable due to a 30% off coupon - which greatly increased the happiness factor. Would definitely go back.
author: p v.

description:
I've been here 5 times at least and it's always fabulous. The lamb is amazing: melts in your mouth, great flavor. Chocolate fondant is the best dessert.  I tried my friends gnocchi: worth getting and the same goes for the burger. The cold tomato gazpacho is heavenly and slightly different as it has a hint of balsamic vinegar added to it, served with bread sticks and onion butter. 

The staff is casual, corteous and professional. No complaints.

the atmosphere is romantic but relaxed. you could go with a group of friends, on a date, dress up or dress down.

true neighberhood gem. love it!
author: Mymy B.

description: came here last year for dine-about-town, never got a chance to review this place until now.  honestly i forgot what we ordered... but it was a really GREAT experience, small/cozy/intimate, somewhat casual, food was yummy!  i would definitely want to come back in the near future!!
author: Cal C.

description: Delicious Creme Bu lee! Nice waitresses.
author: chuchu z.

description: great food and excellent service.  Thanks for the special treats.  I am a fan!
author: tomcat f.

description: We had a great dinner. 12-11-12...we had the pork, filet, vegetable soup, good wine, great desert, and the service was friendly and relaxed.  They didn't try to rush our Meal but were there when we needed them. Cute little corner with a decent price!
author: Joanna B.

description: Very well done. Great feel with the low ceilings and modern decor. The food was solid. I liked the Kobe beef burger with comte and the asparagus/frisee salad that I got...and there were plenty of other things that looked worth trying. Will be back. Prices were reasonable.
author: Brian B.

description:
GF and I had 25 minutes to kill before haircut and shopping. We walked in and it was 5:05, not until later did we realize and did they even mention they don't officially open until 5:30. Had a very tasty Arnold Palmer and we shared the Ahi carpaccio. Not a big fan of onions, the salad on top was loaded, but the fish was excellent.  GF loved the salad. I would have too, if I loved onions. Service was very good, though we are of the opinion it's always better at the bar, which is of course where we were sitting.

Oh, and GF loved her cappuccino...

Bien Sur!
author: BP N.

description:
The 7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes is so amazingly wonderful that I almost didn't write this review. I don't really want everyone to know about this place or that dish; I'd rather keep it all to myself. Sigh.

Worth every one of the 5 stars I am giving it.
author: Genevieve W.

description: Went for lunch.  I ordered soup du jour + Tarte Tatin, my wife ordered the mushroom ravioli and 2 glasses of wine.  The soup was just OK but the Tarte and the Raviolis were excellent.  Presentation on the plate was a piece of art and the texture and taste was really good.  $60 for lunch (including the wine) is a bit over the top but the food and presentation was worth it.  On Mondays they have wine at half price; can't beat that.  I'll be back someday when I am in town again.
author: Ian E.

description: good, polite service but soggy french fries, sent them back and they were returned even soggier! I am sure they were yesterday's leftovers!very disappointed
author: anne c.

description: What is it with these uber-tiny brunch holes? Just like Maverick, I think Chouqet's is taking intimacy a little too far with the 'cuddle your neighboring table' factor, but my personal claustrophobia aside, it remains a decent eatery option in a great neighborhood. They have a nice range of menu items and do offer some outdoor seating, which is always a plus in my book (weather-permitting). Heads-up: If you order their delicious Niman burger, specify if like your bacon crisp, as they tend to go a little too au naurale in my opinion. Some may dig that, but not moi.
author: Gregor G.

description: Had lunch with a girlfriend here today. The Gazpacho was delicious. And my friend's Arugula Salad with Seared Laughing bird Shrimp & grapefruit with lemon/mint dressing was really good. My main dish, Croque Monsieur was kind of ok because it wasn't hot. Overall a pleasant experience.
author: Julie K.

description:
great place to bring the pups and have brunch al fresco.

loved the eggs Benedict!
author: A P.

description: Will not go there again. I dont know if it was because I had my bag of laundry or because I had jeans and a t-shirt on and the fact I ordered a virgin mary cocktail... maybe they thought i was a bum person or too young to know how to tip. Little did they know i've been a waitress, that I tip well for good food and good service, that ive been in the hospital for 2 weeks and that was my little 2 hour break Ive had to go do laundry and get lunch out of the hospital. I know the bag looked bad, but I saw they were quite busy, so I chose to sit at the bar to be out of the way as possible and not take up a table that could seat 2 + people. Is that not considerate? At first the cocktail lady was nice, I asked about the smoked trout and fingerling potatoe mache salad... I had to ask what mache was though :/ $14 for a bowl of salad :/ water glass went empty even though the cocktail lady was in front of me the entire time. Only once was I asked how it was. The other two waitresses ignored me. The guy serving food basically threw it in front of me. As I was eating looking around and seeing new people come saw they were getting bread and butter, noticed that I had a bread plate (next to me) when i sat down (I assumed it was for someone else, the waitress didnt even move it in front of me and I got my salad w/o utensils... big no no in my book) so i finish my salad, waited for the check. At this time I said, "do you have to have a certain entree to get the bread?" she then looks slightly embarassed and says, "oh there wasnt any, but there should be now, do you want it to-go?" "hell yes" thanks for almost letting me pay $14 for a salad that was, admittedly, good but not including the bread or even mentioning you were waiting for some, and for ignoring me practically the whole time. Only reason for 2 stars is because salad was good. Too bad for them I wont be back, nor will my family that stays with me and or visitors that come down to see me as I make routine trips to hospital. Ill take my business elsewhere.
author: Tabitha E.

description:
-THIS REVIEW IS FOR DINNER ONLY-

I just got home from a dinner at Chouquet's and felt compelled to write about them- but not in a good way as you can see from my 2 star rating of them.  

It was my first time dining there and I had never heard of it before. My boyfriend made reservations for us as a surprise because he knows I love French food and wanted to try something new.  Unfortunately, he did not Yelp it beforehand and that was his first mistake!  We were late for our reservations but were able to get seated without much of a wait. We started with the soup du jour which was a lobster soup.  The soup arrived pretty quickly, and tasted exactly like the pureed tomalley  of crab or lobster.  Some people like that (I do) and others do not (like my bf).  It's an acquired taste but I thought it was a decent dish and worth the six dollars.  The main courses we ordered were the 7 hour lamb shoulder with the truffled mashed potatoes and the pasta with truffle, chanterelle mushrooms, and seared fois gras.  I ordered the pasta dish and when it arrived, I knew I had made a mistake.  I took one bite out of it and saw a pool of oil sitting on the bottom of the plate. The chanterelles were dry and shriveled- the fois gras over salted. Almost everything about the composition of this dish was wrong.  I tried to be a good sport and eat it, but I just couldn't.  My boyfriend felt bad so he offered to switch plates with me, but he couldn't even eat more than two bites.  I hate sending food back, but I felt like I really needed to tell them that this dish was inedible.  

After getting a hold of one of the waitresses, we explained to her that we were unhappy with the dish and that it was swimming in oil.  I consider that unacceptable for a dish that costs 27 dollars.  My boyfriend politely explained the situation to which the waitress basically argued with him that it is the most popular dish there and that was exactly how it is supposed to be.  Then there was an awkward silence for about 1 minute during the time when we had expected her to offer a substitute (which became extremely uncomfortable). She rudely asked if we wanted something else and by then, we were already over the restaurant.   We told her that she could take it away anyway because there was no way any one of us was going to take another bite.  

The lamb dish wasn't so bad, but nothing memorable.  We ended up splitting that dish.  Then the male server came over after some mumbling with our server and the kitchen staff to explain the dish.  His explanation was that the oil we saw in the dish was the oil from the fois gras and it was supposed to be there.  I'm sorry but I don't see the need for 1/2 cup of extra oil to be sitting on the bottom of a plate. There was also no way that the fat came from the fois gras because it was only about 2 inches in diameter. Secondly, there are plenty of dishes that use  bacon or pancetta and even if some of the rendered fat is used in the dish, it is unlikely that there is any need to pour all of the fat into the dish.  I don't know a single person who thinks a pool of fat on the bottom of their food is a good thing.  Fat comes out of delicious things and helps flavor them- but we certainly don't need to drink the fat! 

Whatever the reason was, we just didn't like it and I just think the situation was handled poorly.  There was no reason for the servers to argue with us and tell us that it's normally a popular dish.  They could have simply apologized, taken the dish away and offered us something else.  The period between the initial complaint and the final offer to fix it just took too long.  

In the end, they didn't charge us for the pasta dish but I will most likely never return to this restaurant again. From now on, I'm completely banning any restaurant in the upper Fillmore area.
author: Jade L.

description: Lots of reviews but people, none of them matters except for mine. Let me clear up some of the misunderstanding that is posted on Yelp. It is a small restaurant and things can take a little longer than expected. Sure your salad probably takes a little longer than expected. That is only one item from about 5 items you chose that night. What about the other 4 items and your friends food. Can it get a little cramp there? Sure, like I said before the restaurant is pretty small but they will try to seat you at a table, outside or at the door. The majority of the food has traces of Truffle oil, making your food jump with excitement (is it real truffle oil, I do not know, I do not care). All of the help at Chouquets can answer all of your questions, most of them with a French accent. Stop in, grab a Chouquet Drink or a Pilsner Urquell and be ready to eat some great French Food. Ciao.
author: Edson C.

description:
UPDATE:
I guess the chef of this restaurant didn't like me review. I just recieved an email from him (through YELP) calling me a fat CUN*, in French, of course. No wonder his food sucks so bad. He's got time on his hands to write nasty emails. I still stand by my review:

Should it have been a sign that a sandwich board outside this restaurant was advertising "diner"? It's not that hard to spell 'dinner'. But we didn't see the sign on the way in. The food was awful. It was just one mis-hit after another. Our apps: Foie Gras, seared then chilled. OK, that's different. But it was slathered with Chinese Five spice that completely over-whelmed the flavor and nuance of the Foie Gras. They also did not take out all of the veins. This made me sad. Cured salmon served with warm potatoes and a truffle beurre blanc. It didn't work for me. I don't like luke-warm raw salmon sliced way too thick. It kind of grossed me out. My 'Crying Tiger' steak (menu did not specifiy what cut) was ordered medium-rare. It was cold in the middle, totally raw. Service was terrible. A busboy was trying really hard to take away my appetizer because the chef had obviously fired our dinners way too early. Eventually he brought our dinners out and placed them on the table next to us. Not kidding. The place was fairly empty so there is no excuse for the bad timing. The presentation was laughable. Our dinners both came with mashed potatoes that were thrown on the plate (think Jackson Pollack painting, with potato puree). Our wine glasses were empty when our dinner plates were put down. My husband just said it was the worst dinner he's had in San Francisco. One more observation. The people next to us ordered a butter lettuce salad. They were served the entire head of lettuce, in tact. It was funny watching them try to eat it. And then extract the core and put it aside. Really, that chef needs to get a CLUE!
author: Neile R.

description:
My wife, me and friends have always wanted to try this place so while in the Fillmore last Saturday it was the logical choice for Brunch.  The restaurant has a couple of things going for it.  They have a great location right on a busy corner of Fillmore and Washington and there is plenty of street parking nearby. They have a lot of windows for people watching, good light and a nice outdoor seating area. That's about it though.

We arrived and were seated immediately. Our waiter seemed lost and unresponsive to questions.  She took our order eventually after first taking the food order then coming back for the drinks order.  Bread was delivered but it took a while to get butter to go with it.  Now I must admit the drinks were great; the Bloody Mary and Anchor Steam beer are easily one of the best that I have had in the city and I eat out allot.   But that was where it ended.  3 of us ordered various omelet combinations and 1 ordered the Eggs Benedict.  The portions were small and all of the dishes were fairly bland and no better than what you would get in IHOP; the cheese tasted and looked like it was processed and the potatoes were under seasoned and soggy.  Here's the hard part to swallow, this place is by no means cheap.  An omelet is around $14.

So...mediocre (at best) food, uninspired service and dark ambiance led to an experience that we are not in a hurry to repeat.  I really wanted to like this place but it's a big miss...especially with their overinflated prices.
author: John R.

description: Cute location, authentic French waiters (with attitude). Just don't come here hungry - or expect to leave with a fully tummy. My lunchtime trout salad ($14) was wilted and had about 2 oz of fish in it. My companions shrimp salad was also wilted and had a sprinkling of crustaceans. It might be because we ate at 2.30pm and they ran out of ingredients. Or maybe they expect us to order four courses? We won't be going back.
author: jane t.

description: Really, nothing special. It's a cute little French restaurant on the corner with warm lights and friendly service. We started with the natural ribs which smelled so incredibly strong that I coughed. They also left our fingers smelly and sticky way past dinner and past a couple of washes. I couldn't taste much of the lavender nor honey, and our waitress said it was a balsamic taste, but all I tasted was burnt toughness. The pistachio nougats sprinkled on top were tasteless--maybe because the black sauce was so thick. The entrees were a little better but not by much. The veggie gnocchi sauce was not too creamy which I like, but the gnocchi itself was really tough and overcooked. My chicken plate looked gourmet and was very well presented, but was very dry and tasteless. The carrot, mint salad was good and made up for the rest of the mishaps. I think we could've done a much better job elsewhere, especially for the price we paid.
author: Hana J.

description: This is a really cute little place, and though I'm very new to SF, I feel like these places are hidden all over the city.  I had the salmon eggs benedict which was not served on your traditional English muffin along with a side of salad.  Being a French restaurant the portions are what I expected, and thought everything else was just OK.  The best thing was the yolk in the eggs benedict.  Most abundant and runny and perfectly cooked benedicts I've had in a while, so I appreciated that. I also had the Chouquets cocktail which was nice, fruity and gave this lightweight a very light buzz.  Husband had the Kobe burger and thought it was just okay as well.
author: Jen T.

description: Dude...it felt like I was in Santa Monica when I had brunch here. The food was delicious! If you're looking for a bunch spot, this place delivers! The outdoor seating was perfect. what I really liked about this place was the vibe. Yes, half the people there (like us) were hungover from the previous night's festivities. You could identify them as the ones wearing the dark sunglasses. We were mixed in with yuppies with their dogs as well as families. It was still a fun crowd, and a relaxing day in the sun. I can't wait to go back!
author: Samir P.

description:
too much buttah!  but other than that the food here is good.  

Asparagus arugula salad with truffle had a too much oil on it but had great earthy springy flavors and texture contrast.  The oysters came with a well executed mignonette but some of them were poorly cleaned.  The riblets had an awful vinegary sauce that lacked the depth of bbq and was more reminiscent of Chinese sweet and sour.  They also tasted like they were nicely braised before being fired to a dry, crisp with the sweet and sour sauce.

The mains were also mixed.  Chicken had a great Indian flavor profile and was nice and juicy.  The fries that came with the burger were limp and uninspired.  The burger itself was pretty good, featuring a nice juicy patty and good toppings.  The bun was over-buttered.  The weakest dish was the gnocci which were fried and had lost all of their plump.  The foamed sauce contained too much butter.

Overall this restaurant is good but it feels like Chouquet is dressing up its dishes with frills at the cost of some basics.  That's always a bad trade in my book.
author: Calvin N.

description:
yum.  great burger.  good dessert.

very, very good service.
author: Java Z.

description: Recently came here for a late brunch on a Saturday and was surprised to find it with plenty of open tables. The place was quaint and clean with very friendly waitstaff. Our party of four each ordered a different dish and were extremely pleased- the portions were just right- not like most brunch places that are overflowing with greasy potatoes and eggs. The flavors were light and didn't overpower. The staff was very attentive to us. Overall a great experience.
author: Gabrielle P.

description: We've lived nearby for 2 years and I don't know why we never walked in to this place area. In the past week, we've eaten here twice. The wagyu burger is awesome. In general, the food is terrific and a good value. The service has been less than stellar, but the wait staff is nice and friendly. We were starving and waiting forever for a salad so we asked someone to check on it and got a "uhh ooook" kind of response. Later they comped my hubby's beer. Came back for brunch - omlettes are terrific but what absolutely loved were the homemade croissants. They bake each fresh for you (or at least that's what it tasted like) and served with fresh jam. Wish we didn't wait so long to try it!
author: Kathy L.

description: Had dinner at Chouquet's last night as part of "Dine About Town." My choices for the three-courses included the cauliflower soup, salmon, and for dessert, the chocolate souffle. The soup was rather tasteless -- I can't remember the last time I went to a nice-ish restaurant and had to add salt to my food. The salmon was very good -- a nice-sized portion, cooked to perfection, with a tasty sauce around it. The dessert was sub-par. We needed to ask for our water to be refilled -- in a restaurant with only ~15 tables, you'd think they'd have that covered. What really got my goat, though, was when we realized they were actually charging MORE for the "Dine about Town" prix fixe than their usual prix fixe. The waiter accidentally gave one of us the regular prix fixe menu when we were to decide on dessert. The menus were IDENTICAL, yet the prices were not -- $29 for the prix fixe usually, but $31.95 for the "Dine about Town" menu! Doesn't that defeat the purpose of "Dine about Town?" We pointed this out to the waiter and though he later brought us 2 complimentary glasses of champagne, we were still charged the $31.95 each. Dishonest management + mediocre food = a dining experience I don't intend to repeat.
author: Pamela S.

description: Wine is good. Steak is fair. Frites are so so. Very french waiters are very...well...fronnch. But. BUT!!...the outside seating is in juuuust the right spot for maximum sunshine during brunch and happy hour hours. It's actually a good place, in case I sound like I only go there for the outdoor seating.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
we went here because the 'dine about town' menu looking amazing. beyond amazing - it was a french dream come true.

but then we got there and, though i was fairly drunk, the craptastic quality of the food sobered me up and thoroughly disappointed me. 

they didn't have the menu the advertised and they didn't even have the stuff on their menu for the evening. and we were there at 8:30. 

my chicken tasted awful and burnt. the desert tasted like cool whip covered with soggy almonds. 

i do have to say their duck won ton thing (obviously, I'm not used to fine dining) was good. as was their foie gras. 

definitely NOT WORTH IT.
author: Pam Z.

description: I don't know if you have read any of my other reviews, but I like brunch!  Why do I like Chouquet's?  The splendid oudoor seating area.  I have had outdoor dinner here and I have to say, go for the brunch or a midday snack!  I feel very French when I eat here.  It is the one place in the city that reminds me of a French brasserie.  You can eat outdoors and sip wine.  The croque madame is not a true croque madame, more California but very good.  The eggs Florentine are delicious.  Omlettes and potatoes keep you coming back.  You can grab brunch with fresh squeezed orange juice and stay for a glass of wine!  The tables are very close together so you can make friends with your neighbors!  The weather in the area is warm, but they can turn on the heat lamps if you are cold.  If you want to feel like you are in France, go here.
author: apple r.

description: Lovely little brunch spot (which is the best way to get an affordable meal there). Don't try to park though.
author: Chaney K.

description: We came here recently for dine about town and it was a waste.  I had the lobster soup which sounded rich and delicious when the waitress described it, but ended up being gritty and bland.  Not worth the calories!  Then I had the ahi carpaccio which had way too much happening sauce-wise.  It was an assault on my taste-buds after the nondescript soup.  I had the chocolate fondant for dessert which was good, but one of the easiest desserts you can make.  My fiance had the barramundi appetizer and it was pretty blah too.  Not worth the effort--I would have enjoyed a homemade turkey sandwich more!
author: Eleanor E.

description: Not so great. Been there 3 times and every time it was off. Employees all talking with their friends and smoking in front. Yea I know they are French. Small portions of decent but not that great of food.
author: Howard L.

description:
Hi my name is stephane and I'm working at chouquet's and this is my answer to Mr Jason b bad review!

Dear Jason B,

First of all let me tell u that I love my work and will do everything I can to make my clients happy but come on Mr jason b! 
When u come to a busy, crowded restaurant for brunch at the rush hour and you have so many special request about your food witch is gonna make me give a bad quality  service for others clients (because spending so much time for Mr jason b request) you don't expect a big smile on my face!

I have to admit that your attitude made me have some as well (And it was a mistake cause I certainly shouldn't have respond to it!) Nobody is perfect! I'm not perfect but I try to be at least  professional when I'm working! 

By the way your friend was really nice! Take example to be a nice custumer!

I'm still convinced that the quality of service at chouquet's is really good and the food is excellent!

The chef is providing a great and consistant quality of food day by day!

much love and respect for you Mr Jason b

Your beloved waiter Stephane
author: Stephane G.

description: Beautiful servers behind the bar.  A modernist interior, it has a decent wine list and simple menu, with Pac Heights prices.  It is not a destination place to dine, but a great spot to split some bottles of rose or white wine after work, especially if you consult your almanac and somehow manage to catch the sun as you sit outside.  The servers are young and friendly, and when we left at closing, they invited us to have some of their carbonara.  Mostly serving a local Pac Heights crowd, the staff probably look cooler than the clientele.
author: ed y.

description: Went there for dinner and it was a nice, fairly casual French bistro, but the food was fairly boring an unoriginal.  Nice wine list.  Great people-watching, from people with yappy dogs outside to some pretty attractive waitresses inside.  But the food is uninspired to a fault.
author: Geoff K.

description: This place gets 4 stars just for the wonderful outdoor seating!!! I'm always on the hunt for restaurants with patio or "curbside" seating area and this place is perfect or lunch under the sun! My friend and I came here for lunch and we had the best time relaxing under the warm spring weather. The food was good, but nothing special. I had a huge chicken salad topped with shaves of fennel and slices citrus fruits. For dessert we shared a simple strawberry sundae. It looked fabulous, but all it was was strawberry ice cream with whipped cream and slices of real strawberries on top. Overall, if you're looking for a chill place for lunch or brunch on a lazy day, this is the spot!
author: Denise L.

description: I've never been here for dinner (which i gather is much more of a cluster f**k), but I dig this place for lunch - you can sit outside and catch some rays and it's low-maintenance, super-casual dining during the day.  Menu is small and sort of basic: they serve burgers and steak sandos and decent salads.  Kind of freaked out by the Cockroach comments, though.  If that is true, that is NO GOOD.
author: Ryan W.

description:
What a find!  I'm SOOO psyched about this place.  Food was incredible.  You have to try the rosemary-honey pork ribs with pistachios.  Unique combination... completely delectable!  Even came with a bowl of warm water and a clean towel for handwashing (very thoughtful!).

Friends both had the burger... which looked phenomenal.  Fries were extra crispy/greasy... oh the yummy!

They were great on the water refills, always the sign of a place with good service.  Wine list wasn't anything to write home about, but they had a nice selection of French wines and seemed very knowledgeable about them.

Dessert looked terrific (lots of chocolatey options that you couldn't possibly go wrong with), but we passed.  Next time!  (Yes, there will definitely be a next time!)

Don't let the fact that it's never full in this place keep you from venturing inside.  Their organic French/Californian cuisine is not to miss!
author: Lindsay M.

description: I love early breakfasts and sitting outside with a cup of tea, enjoying the sun. This place doesn't open till 10(too bad) on weekends, but it is worth it. The eggs Florentine was great, and their fresh Ruby red grapefruit juice was Delicious! Not too badly priced, and if you get there early, you beat the crowd.
author: Sara A.

description: The omletes were amazing. And so was the smoked trout. Chocolate fondant is highly recommended.
author: John T.

description: Mediocre.  Their eggplant millefuille (sp?) was delicious, but their chicken was bland and very average.  The service is good.  Kind of pricey for what they offer.  I wouldn't go back given that there are much better choices in this neighborhood.
author: Christina S.

description:
Man oh man, this is one intimate (that's French for "cramped") space.  I spent more time chatting with the duo to my right than I did with the better half of my own two-top; eavesdropping on--and contributing to--their conversation was nothing short of impossible (that's French for "impossible").

The primavera risotto was delicious, though, and I spent a moment in agape awe when presented with my most beautiful dessert.
author: Hannah J.

description: I've been here for brunch twice, and have always had a nice experience. They've got these really yummy grapefruit mimosas - perfect for a Sat or Sunday brunch with friends. I'd also recommend their croque monsieur's. If you can snag a spot outside on a sunny day, it's perfect for people watching.
author: meagan m.

description:
Food was amazing.
Service was mediocre.
Atmosphere is nice.

Stopped by here on Sunday and got a cute little table outside for a late brunch.  They were out of lillet (sad for a French brunch) and had a grapefruit mimosa instead (the fresh squeezed grapefruit was a little bitter for the drink- but not bad).  Ordered the trout and an omelet and  some banana nut chocolate desert thing.  I asked if I could have goat cheese in my omelet (since it was listed in some of the other omelets- just not the one I chose) and she said ok.  When the food came out the trout actually was a trout salad with lots of pieced trout- but it was super delicious.  The goat cheese seemed to have been overlooked, and when I mentioned this to the busboy (whose attentiveness compensated for our somewhat absent server) he came back in a minute with some.  The omelet was really nice and would have been fine with me either way.  The desert was to die for and I'm not really a sweets person.  Overall the food was lovely.  

Downer- they charged me like $13 for the side of goat cheese- a fact I didn't notice until later when I was wondering how our little one-drink brunch bill got up to $65.
author: Dina A.

description: came here a while back with a groupon type deal. i've never sent my food back, ever, but this was the closest i ever came. sorry guys. not only was the food bad but the service so astonishingly unprofessional. back to the drawing board.
author: carolyn a.

description: At 8pm on a Friday night, hardly anyone was in the restaurant, but I wanted to try it anyway. I guess that was indication number one that this place is not good. The ambiance is terrible. I got a chill each time the door closed, I felt I was dining with strangers and I was left to enjoy average food and later, an even worse dessert. If you want good french food, Baker St. Bistro is the place to go.
author: Julia S.

description: Great neighborhood bistro.  Filet of beef was very tender and full of flavor (and I appreciated the little cup of gravy to add as I saw fit), and the french fries were light and plentiful.  We split a gnocchi entree as an appetizer and it was ample and great (yes, it had peas in it...I like peas, unlike another reviewer).  The only disappointment was the banana crumble chocolate thingy...wasn't awful, just confusing.  Service was pleasant, helpful, and never overbearing.  I'll be back.
author: Keith J.

description:
ok so i've only gone here for brunch on a lazy sat and sunday.  
i always order the tried and true - croque madame - a tasty french version of a grilled cheese with ham sandwich with an egg on top.  it comes with a side salad which makes me feel like i'm eating a little healthy.

glass of fresh OJ - ok mimosa for you alchs.  coffee or cappucino, a good gilfriend or newspaper and a pair of designer shades and you can fit in easily.

i like that i can take my dog there too and eat outside though the tables are set a wee bit too cozy.  i could eat off the plate of the table next to me if i needed to.

the ile flottante (floating island) dessert is a fluff of eggwhite with creme anglaise (sweet thick english cream)  - is par but works for me since i'm usually full from the heavy carb meal.  i wish it was done a little lighter and tastier since it's my fave dessert from when i lived in paris.  

the minus stars are from the wait for the outside tables on the weekend, sometimes slow service, and the fact that they seated me once even though the kitchen was closed (i was starving!)  and had to head down to crepe vine down the street.

parking isn't great - i had to circle four times before finding a spot and cussed a few times since i was behind the fillmore snail bus.
author: Anh V.

description: This is my favorite place for weekend brunch on Fillmore.  Relax outside in the sun and eat consistently good food.  Can't beat that, especially with no lines.  My fav is the Croque-Monsieur.  I also like the benedicts and the club sandwich looked awesome too, especially with the homemade chips.  You can also eat here for a tasty dinner on those rare warm SF nights.  Go for the steak frites or gnocchi, both are excellent.  I recommend that you immediately go chillax at chokeit and get so drunk that you start talking french.
author: Jake A.

description: We tried Chouquet when it first opened and were disappointed, but today is a whole different story!  We've been back about four times now and each time the food is amazing and the service is great as well.  Low key atmosphere and you can sit outside too.
author: Lisa M.

description: It was a beautiful day and we stumbled upon this cute French restaurant for brunch in the area on our way to the Marina. We sat outside, under the awning, and I enjoyed my fresh orange juice mimosa, while my husband got a fresh grapefruit juice, which I thought was a bit bitter. My goat cheese and roasted tomato tartlette with a balsamic vinegar reduction was excellent. My husband's chicken with truffle sauce was also fantastic. The portions were small -- European style, which I like. I would totally come back for the other omelettes listed in the brunch menu -- but in the lunch/dinner menu, I think the only vegetarian entree is the goat cheese tart that I already got.
author: Antara B.

description:
My friends and I went on a Monday night during Dine About Town, so the restaurant was fairly empty.  However, this surely added to our positive experience, as the wait-staff was attentive and un-rushed.  Our waitress answered our numerous questions about the menu with ease.  A few of us chose items off the DAT prix-fix menu... I chose the "Crispy Rolls of Baramundi" for my appetizer, the "7-Hour Braised Shoulder of Lamb" for my main course, and the Apple Tart" for my dessert (this was technically not on the DAT menu, but the chef allowed me to order it since I am lactose intolerant.  The app was pretty tasty, and the lamb was absolutely delicious.  Oh, and the bread is really good... so good, in fact, that our group of 6 had 6 baskets' worth of it!  The dessert was so-so, but everything else was solid.  With a bottle of wine, our total bill was $320 after tax and tip... not too shabby for a French place.

C harming restaurant with warm decor
H unger-inducing menu with a nice selection of dishes
O utside patio area is great for dining during nice weather
U nder-whelming serving sizes, but just enough to fill you up
Q uality French meal for a relatively affordable price-point
U nless you've already had it, try the lamb or filet
E ach dish was presented well on the plate
T he chef was accommodating of my dietary restrictions
'
S o-so dessert... but maybe we ordered the wrong items?
author: Kenny L.

description: This review is for the food. The place is located in a great spot, very busy on a Friday night. For starters I ordered the seafood chowder and was suprised by the over powering use of salt. I literally could not taste the chowder as all I could taste was salt. Surely just a one time thing, so looked forward to my main entree. I ordered a vegetable gnocchi dish. Well, have you ever had an overcooked, beyond doughy and fried gnocchi? What was supposed to be a delicate gnocchi, tossed in a light sauce with vegetables turned into a dish that was "burnt" gnocchi, a sea of peas, some mushrooms, and a few asparagus tips. The waiter literally never checked back on us until the end and just threw a dessert menu before we received our check. The weird thing, is that when we got our bill, somehow the horrific gnocchi dish was taken off. So did they deliberately send out a bad dish, and hoped that I wouldn't complain? My husband ordered the filet mignon, and like most reviews, it was way undercooked and almost raw. Another weird thing, the steak is 4oz, and yet it was undercooked. Overall, we came with a groupon and I am glad that is all I spent. I honestly do not recommend this place if you are expecting a decent meal.
author: Jennifer A.

description: I have been a member of yelp for a long time, but I've never had the urge to write a review... until tonight. Our dinner at Chouquet's was just a big bowl of underwhelming. The wait was atrocious. GF's soup was bland. The ahi tuna was twice as expensive as pacific catch's, but it tasted half as good. My gnocchi wasn't really that good. There wasn't that much of it, there was no sauce to add flavor, and the peas were lame - like a bag of frozen peas. I really don't know what we paid for. Nothing was downright awful, but nothing was good either. I take that back - my oysters appetizer was good. That's why it gets two stars instead of one. And the staff was rude too. Even though we had a reservation, they took forever just to recognize our presence at the front door. It took a while to get our bread so we asked about it, and she said responded in a sharp tone, as if we were jerks for asking. Our main course took forever, and they told us it would "be right out" and that really meant 30 minutes. I've lived two blocks away for about two years, but the groupon finally forced me to go. Meh. Skip it.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Four hours of shopping and a mad craving for oysters landed us at Chouquet's one gray Friday evening. What a neighborhood gem! The wine recommendation from our waitress was superb, as well as the overall service throughout the meal. 

Obviously the targets were the advertised oysters on the sidewalk chalkboard menu. I have to say that the dozen was both fresh and bursting with oceanic flavor. And $20 for a dozen is a deal! 

After observing the passing meals, we changed our snack into a meal by ordering the vegetarian gnocchi. My meat-loving boyfriend said he wanted to give this place 5 stars based on this dish alone. Phenomenal and creative flavors. We will be coming back.
author: Shannon M.

description:
another brunch favorite of mine. this cute lil fillmore spot is wonderful place to enjoy a sunny day and a glass of wine or mimosa, esp if you can get a table outside. but even if you can't inside is just as charming. i love the little french guy that works here. he's like a french version of woody allen--in looks anyway. he's a lil harried at times, but he's on his game.  

i'm a fan of their eggs benny and their omelets.  with fillings like ham and gruyere, spinach, mushrooms and pancetta, you're gonna leave happy and full. it comes with a lovely side salad and they give you bread. the coffee is also good. haven't done dinner here, but i would.

solid 3 star food
1 extra star for ambiance/location
author: rachel p.

description: Plates are quite a bit larger than the food, which can leave your entree looking more like an appetizer. My boyfriend ordered the "roasted half chicken" which turned out to be only a single chicken breast. It still came out on a plate that was big enough for an entire chicken, making the poor chicken breast look pewny.  The orange sauce on it was good. Excellent french fries!  I ordered the lamb shoulder, which had some fat, but otherwise the taste was good and meat was tender.  The staff was pleasant and attentive.  I think if the food and presentation were improved, this would go from a good to an excellent restaurant.
author: Kelley P.

description:
Everything about my dining experience here was flawless.  We had my little pug with us as we strolled up to the restaurant around 9ish and it looked like the patio was shut down.  But when we asked, they were happy to serve us outside.  The menu was fantastic with an assortment of salads, seafood, and poultry served with a variety of unique veggies & sauces.  I had the roasted red & yellow beet salad, served with chevere dumplings and two separate sauces to complement.  The bf had the ahi tuna, served rare and warm, and it was placed over a creamy sauce you could dabble in at your leisure.  Before the entrees were served, they brought out french baguettes and little croutons served with a warm roasted pepper medley that was superb.  Post dinner, we were surprised by 4 little light dessert pastries brought with the check.  Good wine, efficient service, fab fare, and a clear & starry night all melded for our delight and guaranteed our return to this Pac Heights pearl.

Update:  the brunch here on a nice day is amazing!  Fresh squeezed OJ & grapefruit juice that oozes with goodness!   The smoked salmon benedict is exquisite!  The benedict florentine was great as well, with its fresh spinach.  Both benedicts were cooked to perfection, left me full yet aching for more!   It might have been the weather or something, but we found very chatty & friendly folks at every table!  Good for people watching, and perfect if you want to bring ur pooch and then hit the park.
author: Tara G.

description: We went to Chouquet's on a Friday night at 7:30. We didn't wait for a table, nor were we crowded, despite the small space. Not sure why it was not very crowded b/c the food is excellent. They seemed a little short on the staff, but that could be b/c there was a big party but only one waiter. The atmosphere is quaint. It's definitely a small space -- contemporary, but comfortable. I was most thankful for the recommendation of the Andrew Rich 2002 Syrah. It was perfect with my steak. Others had the pork chop, which was high-rated as was the monkfish. I'll go back for sure.
author: elizabeth s.

description: This is a great brunch spot. It's located in a great area (Filmore Street) to walk around before or after. I had their Omelette Paysanne and it was very good.  I sat inside but on a nice day, their patio area should be really nice.
author: Barney M.

description: Last night at Chouquet's was simply SPECTACULAR!!! The food was AMAZING!!!!  For appetizers we started with Oysters on the half shell and a cold frosty Pilsner Urquell. Then for the Main course, I ordered the Seared Ahi Tuna in sesame seeds with Mizuna & Cucumbers salad in Meyer lemon dressing. Everything we ordered were in perfect proportions. All I can say is WOW!!!!
author: Rod C.

description: "careful the plates are Hot"--too bad the food was cold and the waitstaff tolerated your questions about items on the menu like you were a child. Tried them out during the "Dine Out SF" prix fixe meal. The goat tartlet was good, the soup tasteless, the Kobe Beef unseasoned as well as the salmon with--frozen peas and carrots--really????The chocolate lava cake was cool inside as well. We went early-6pm- and were the 3rd table in the restaurant -to get such poor service when it's slow--come on. I won't be back
author: kathryn h.

description: A cute, satisfying place to have a good lunch or brunch. The beet salad is to die for (Deep fried Goat Cheese? Could it get any better?) And the Croque Monsieur is probably horribly bad for you, but it tastes sooo good...every once in a while it just hits the spot. I went for a weekday lunch, so the place wasn't crowded, but it wasn't scarily empty either. The servers were very attentive and friendly...every person there had a smile on their face! Can't wait to try it for dinner or a busy brunch to see if it's just as good.
author: Tuyet N.

description:
This place started off great, good service, good start until I spotted a roach. I wasn't going to say anything unless I saw another and of course where there's one...

The place is infested! They were everywhere, I couldn't believe my eyes, in an upscale restaurant in The Fillmore??

We left before dinner even made it to our table.  If the roaches are that bold in the dining room just imagine the kitchen. :(

The waiter was very gracious, he obviously knew this was a problem.
author: BH ..

description: There's something about this area that just makes me want to skip around like an idiot--its quaint boutiques, the hills, and pedestrian friendly ambience. Most invitingly are such restaurants such as Chouquet's.  I love sidewalk cafes and this place just fits the bill so perfectly for lunch. I'm such as a dork as to think even the salt shakers are cute.  I didn't try much, just the salad nicoise, but I've had a few, and this one just was so darm good, from the seared ahi tuna to the perfectly boiled egg. Ha, I think I just had a good day shopping in the sunshine, but this place hit the spot.  Prices are good, and there's a decent wine selction.  Friend had the club sandwhich  which was wonderful and topped with huge, freshly fried chips.  Other options included croque monsieurs/madams, niman hamburger, and other tempting options.   WIll try again!
author: Jennie T.

description: Came here to try their dine about town menu.  It was pretty good for $40 (with tax and tip).  We started off with a butter lettuce with balsamic vinaigrette and an apple celery soup.  Both of which were very light and refreshing.  Then I got the 7 hour braised lamb and my husband got the ahi tuna carpaccio.  I absolutely loved the truffled mash potatoes (and so did my hubby!) but the lamb needed just a tad bit more of that amazing sauce they drizzled on top, it was a little bit too dry with out it.  Then we got their chocolate fondant which was really a molten lava cake with whipped cream and their tarte tatin.  Both desserts were really good.
author: Kit E.

description:
So I have been here twice now - my favorite restaurant for a "smart" lunch before hitting the Clay theater.  I love going to a French restaurant that is very simple looking, as it reminds me of Paris, and of course sitting outside on a sunny day is reminiscent of Montmarte, and having a French waitress helped bring the entire experience full circle.

So this Tuesday afternoon I ordered the Tuna Niçoise, and it is probably one of the best I have had in San Francisco.  It came with four pieces of tuna (sliced thin, so if you are looking for big lumps of tuna, you ain't gonna get it here), hard-boiled egg, French green beans (okay, not really sure they are French), Greek (or probably French) olives - hard for me to tell, as my palate is not that developed, and another type of fish.  I had to ask the waitress what the other fish was.  I thought it might be herring (it was not pickled), but I was shocked when she said it was anchovy.  I was shocked only because the ones I have had in the past were very salty, but she said this is not salty because it is a fresh water anchovy.   Who Knew??  It also came with a crispy piece of bread with an olive tapenade.  This particular salad is very salty at times, so beware.  If you are not a "salt", you will probably send it back.  The only thing about this salad that I didn't care for was that it had parsley mixed in with it.  Because parsley has a strong, distinctive taste, if you don't care for it (like me) it can be a bit much.

Food was great.
Servers were very attentive.
Mixed crowd of locals (younger and older) and a couple of tourists.
Outside tables are comfortable, and nice that they are on Washington, not directly on Fillmore.
author: Jason I.

description:
This is a great hidden gem in Pac Heights.  I was one of the early customers when it opened three years ago.  I was impressed then, with some of the old favorites like the delicious crab-salad appetizer, and the "chouquets" given at the end of the meal.  

I went again last night.  The free chouquets are gone, but I had the best hamburger I've ever had.  I'm not kidding.  I've had a lot of burgers: Zuni's Harry's, the high-priced truffle burger at Bix, you name it.  The wagyu kobe burger with a bit of applewood smoked bacon and compte cheese (substituted in for another french variety that was on the menu)....  One word: devine

For a neighborhood bistro, it's tops.
author: Rhonda M.

description: Average french bistro. Nice service. We had an early dinner and got a great service as it was almost empty.
author: Liza A.

description: We liked it. Went for dinner, had a restaurant.com gift certificate-it's in our neighborhood. Probably wouldn't go out of the way to frequent, but an overall pleasant experience. I had rolled-up "spicy" chicken ($18?) with couscous. It was delicious, very tender and a nice flavor, although didn't like the mint herbs on top. Husband had the burger ($16), which he loved. It came with fresh waffle potato crips, which were yummy. For dessert, we had a banana/choc/hazelnut crisp pudding-like dish that was brought out hot. We gobbled it right up. Service was fine, somewhat slow, but we liked it that way. Definitely didn't feel rushed or forgotten. We arrived around 6:30 pm on a Friday and walked right in. Got busier as we finished up (about an hour later). Good, solid neighborhood spot .
author: Heather I.

description:
Girlfriend and I went for DAT and found the overall experience relaxed and enjoyable. Its a nice, small place where you can hear yourself talk! The food was good, but nothing spectacular. We had;

1. Appetizers - Smoked Tuna, fingerling potato salad, which was great. Good flavors, perfect dressing. We also had the rolls which were quite good, filled with mushrooms and white fish.

2. Main - We all had the lamb with truffled mashed potatoes. The mashed P's were wonderful, creamy with the right amount of truffle oil and butter. The Lamb was tender and good - but not inspired. The flavor was one tone.

3. Dessert - we orderd the floating island - terrible. Gummy eggy meringue floating in very thin creme anglais. Yuck. We also orderd the rum babba which was tender and flavorful, and the chocolate fondant, which was just a molten chocolate cake, run of the mill, nothing fabo.

Would I go again? I'd try another French place first....
author: Nelly H.

description: Kevin had a burger which, while not quite as good a meat quality as the Kobe beef at Harry's, had the distinct advantage of incredibly fresh tomatoes, grilled onions, and a bounty of goat cheese. Great fries, too! I had a Salade Gascogne with Duck Magret, Melon, Artichokes, and Pinenuts served with a honey mustard dressing. I'm usually not a fan of honey mustard but this was a whole-grain mustard and the tanginess worked well with the sweet melon and bounty of pinenuts. Pretty decent winelist by the glass as well.
author: Carolyn T.

description: I've been here a couple of times with friends from out of town, and have always enjoyed it. The food here is decent, along with the service. I've had the Niman Ranch burger and frites which were both yummy. My friends have had breakfast items like the eggs benedict and croque monsieur which they thought were very good. Although a tight space outside, I especially like the patio area on a nice, sunny day.
author: Fern D.

description: No thanks. I won't be going back for the mediocre food or service. The prices were a little ridiculous for the quality and bland taste.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Eh, cute atmosphere, lousy service, mixed food.

Server was MIA for most of the meal. took him like 40 minutes to get our order. never checked in on us during the meal. (ps we were a party of 6 ordering wine, apps, and entrees- so no small bill!)

butter leaf salad - horrible! tasted like lettuce. You could see that there was balsalmic vinegar on it, but couldn't taste it! I ate two bites. 

(the server never stopped by to ask how we liked everything, so i couldnt voice my complaint. it was cleared with two bites missing by a bus boy who seemed oblivious to its uneaten state).

Had a bite of the goat cheese tart - that was good.

Main course - had the tuna special. was pretty good. still not sure if i was actually served the special, or the tuna carpaccio on the menu.

desert - not memorable.

Dinner took 3 hours. 

might go back sometime maybe.
author: Kay T.

description:
I went with a party of ten to celebrate two of the guests' birthday.  We made reservations for 7:00PM on a Friday night.  The table was already set up so we were promptly seated.  There weren't that many people in the restaurant but it quickly filled up.

I ordered off the DAT menu: gazpacho, braised lamb shoulder, and chocolate fondant.  The gazpacho was served with two pieces of toast and onion butter.  The toast was EXTREMELY greasy, saving me from the need of buttering it.  The soup was on the spicy side; I suspect they add pureed raw onion.  The serving size and presentation were good but I'd say it was OK overall.  I was REALLY disappointed in the lamb shoulder.  It was dry but tender (I know this sounds like an oxymoron) and under seasoned.  The lamb didn't taste like lamb AT ALL, except for the parts that were near chunks of fat.  The mashed potatoes with truffle oil were MUCH better; everyone at my table who either ordered it of tried it agreed.  The meal's saving grace was the chocolate fondant.  I was confused when I read this on the menu but from reading yelp review's before dinner, I guessed that this was the chocolate lava cake people were talking about.  THE CAKE IS REALLY GOOD.  If you are unfortunate enough to go to Chouquet's, just get the cake.  The cake cracked beautifully and the chocolate center flowed out and mixed with the vanilla ice cream to create an ending that just barely made the meal satisfactory.

What made the whole experience even worse though, was the fact that the waitress miscounted the money we gave her.  We paid the majority of the bill in cash and the rest on one credit card.  She returned some 10 minutes later to tell us that we still owed around twenty-something dollars.  My friend and I went over the bill again and counted the money three more times and only found a $1 discrepancy so we threw in the extra dollar.  My friend brought the bill up to the cashier and told her that it was likely that they had counted the $50 as a $20 (although that doesn't make perfect sense either) but the waitress insisted that she hadn't miscounted and didn't apologize.

The general consensus between my friends and I was that if you must go here, use the restaurant.com coupon.  That's the only way it'd be even CLOSE to being worth the visit.  I'm giving two stars because the cake was VERY good and using the coupon made me feel better [I got it during one of their major discount sales].
author: Denise C.

description:
I went here for Dine About Town - it was really great.  I am also European and often feel rushed at restaurants and find the service too intrusive.  I really don't like it when you are having a really great conversation with your friend and the waitor comes and interrupts you to ask how things are going, it is very annoying.  Whenever I feel rushed, I decide never to go to the restaurant again.  Also, I eat slowly, and I really don't like it when my plate is grabbed before I am finished (or, IMMEDIATELY after I have taken my last bite).  Eating out is not supposed to be another thing on your to do list which you have to check off asap.

I was pleasantly surprised that at Chouquet's, the service was non intrusive, and they waited until we asked for the bill to give it to us.  The food was also really great, and the atmosphere was very cozy and inviting.  I will definitely be returning to this restaurant.
author: Fereshteh S.

description: I took my sister in law here and we were over 20 minutes late, the table had still been kept for us, so 4 start for that.  What a tasty dinner and friendly waitress, I shall visit again.  One less star as they were out of the French wine we wanted.
author: JBO ..

description: If you're in the neighborhood and looking for a good lunch then this is the place to go. I had a Salad Nicoise sitting outside on the terrace in the sun - and life was good.
author: AntonEgo C.

description: Went here for DAT. The wait staff were friendly and attentive unfortunately, there were only 2 of them for the whole place which slowed down service considerably and prolonged what would be a torturous evening. The decor of the place was rather simple and just didn't seem to impress me very much. First off, they gave us burnt bread, which I had to scrape off with my knife. For appetizers I got the trout salad and and fingerling potatoes - tasted really good unfortunately there was hardly any trout or potatoes in it. Girlfriend's seafood chowder was watery and not what I consider to be "chowder". For our entrees, we had the Kobe burger (good but nothing to write home about) which they messed up on by putting cheese which we didn't order and filet de boeuf (what a disaster). We ordered the filet medium, which they gave it to us well-done. We sent it back and got something on the order of rare, which we sent right back again, only to get something on the order of medium-rare (which was still too bloody). For dessert we had the chocolate fondant which was good, too bad it was too little too late and wasn't enough to save the entire meal/experience. We couldn't wait to get our check and get out of there.
author: A N.

description:
Fabulous brunch spot. 

Omelette du jardin is one of the best in the city.  The eggs are fluffy, portions are generous, mushrooms inside are perfectly seasoned, and the accompanying side salad's dressing is DELICIOUS.  

The croissants here are almost as good as Tartine... really.  (And they're not on the menu, so make sure to ask your waiter.)

The orange juice is better than Boulange- freshly squeezed and never bitter.  The cafe au laite is perfectly executed - although no skim milk (it feels a little french in this way - waiter will give you a snooty look for any substitutions or changes.)

And... outside eating.  I honestly don't know how this place isn't packed every weekend.

So why 4 star?  It's not cheap (about what Roses's is priced), and their fruit salad comes in a bowl of water.. (??).  That aside, this place is just as good if not better than Roses and no wait.  Enjoy!
author: Casey M.

description: I've been back twice since the first review. The asparagas salad and chocolate fondant are always terrific. Highly, highly recommended. The lamb, however, was pretty dry and tasteless when I ordered it again. That was a shame, because I still have a vivid memory of how mouth-watering it was the first time. Maybe they were just having an off night, or there's a different chef? I haven't given up on this place, however. Next time I'll probably try the Kobe burger; many people around me ordered that and it looked very tasty.
author: Sasquatch M.

description:
Went there for a birthday dinner this past Saturday night.  Food was ok.  Nothing wowing, but decent food.  Why's this a one star review?  Cockroaches.  On 3 separate occasions we saw them on the wall and crawling around the food service counter.  Before leaving saw baby ones crawling outta he baseboards along the floor.  
Complaint went out to the Department of Public Health.  Hope they got it.
author: Al L.

description: We ate there on Valentine's Day and were very pleasantly surprised. The food and the service were both excellent. We Foie gras, snails, duck lasagna (more like a crepe), and scallops. All were flavorful, and properly sauced. Moreover my wife has certain diet restrictions and they were able to accommodate them without any problems. My only negative was the pace of the service. We were in and out in about one hour. Too fast for a really romantic V-day dinner.
author: Paul S.

description: This was my neighborhood place and they always seem to do a great job.  Their appetizers are all top-notch, sometimes I stick with those and skip an entree.  I recommend always saving room for dessert.  Chouquet's is so much an improvement over Pauli's Place.  The chef changed in the past year, food is still good.
author: The B.

description: We recently celebrated here my birthday and everybody loved their friendliness and good food which was wonderfully presented!
author: Bettina O.

description: I went here for their Dine about Town menu, and I must say I was quite impressed! I loved the cozy atmosphere of the restaurant, the warm, lively feel inside and the glass windows to peer out on an adorable corner location. For my first meal I had the escargot in a pastry shell--I love escargot and it was nicely done! I was weary of the pastry shell but it was quite nice with the buttery sauce that went along with it. And if you didn't want the pastry--it was easy to pick out the escargot. For my main course I had the mussels which I LOVED. I finished every single mussel which says a lot because I feel like there are usually a few scrawny little guys in the mix that I am too afraid to eat. The buttery sauce was sooo yummy with the shallots! Exactly how I like mussels prepared. The French fries on the side were cooked perfectly too--thin but not too thin and seasoned just right. The crème brulee as a dessert was also quite delicious--all the desserts at our table looked yummy. Overall everyone at my table of 5 loved their meals, except one girl who ordered the salmon which came out a little bit undercooked.  Really my only complaint is that our wine was literally almost hot. We ordered two bottles of red and I know it doesn't have to be refrigerated but it was just too warm. Other than that, amazing meal! I was especially impressed by our tres francaise waitress--she had the whole place to herself and she still managed to also play hostess. Mad props to her. Would definitely go back--so happy to find a great, not too expensive spot in my neightborhood!
author: Heather M.

description: Conveniently located on Fillmore where all the nice boutiques are, it's a good restaurant to go to for casual dining after all the shopping is done in the neighborhood.  It has both indoor and outdoor tables available, and you are very likely to get a table without reservation.  The dinner menu has a nice selection of appetizers; I especially liked the foie gras and the duck pastilla.  As for the entree, we ordered the seared duck breast and veal carpaccio.  It wasn't the best duck dish I had; it was overcooked alittle too much, i like it with more pink.  and the skin wasn't seared enough to give it the crispy finish.  The veal carpaccio was just thinly sliced meat served with a sauce made with i think just oil, scallion and some other herbs.  The taste reminded me of the Chinese dish "chicken with ginger and scallion."  However the staff were very friendly and attentative.  Overall it was a positive experience.
author: Tadaa T.

description: Great, great place. I took my wife here for Valentines Day for their 5 course dinner and was not disappointed. Great ingredients, super cozy decor and decent price.
author: Scott D.

description: Chouquet's recently took over the space on Fillmore St. formerly occupied by the passable (if boring) Pauli's Cafe.  The owners and chef are all legitimately French and hail from Chezs Papa and Maman on Potrero Hill and Crepe Express on Haight.  The food is slightly to the lighter side of classical Loire cuisine, emphasizing mostly seafood and fowl, but they also provide the heart-clogging staples of Steakfrites, Beef Carpaccio, and Veal Sweetbreads.  My Millefeullie of Eggplant, Zucchini, and Goat Cheese was quite tasty even though it featured far fewer than the 1000 slices of eggplant I had been promised.  The interior is bright and airy, the staff friendly and knowledgeable, the outdoor patio inviting on rare non-foggy evenings, and the wine list has many excellent selections that are quite out of the ordinary.  Like it's progenitors, it's not exactly a destination restaurant, but it serves delicious food at decent prices.
author: Gabriel S.

description: We had a great dinner. The service was lovely too. Our waitress spent time helping us select a wine and reviewing the specials. We had the burger which was excellent and the fish special which was a rather small portion, but very good too. I would dine here again.
author: Laura H.

description: This was a nice place to have brunch and sit outside on a sunny day especially we had a dog. The service was very friendly and nice and the waiter even gave the dog water in a dish. They kept asking us if everything was alright but not too much which is nice. The food was good. I ordered the Croque Madame which is like a big ham and cheese sandwich with salad and an egg on top. The sign outside the entrance entices you with homemade croissants which we ordered. They're really good and served with jam.
author: Bryant W.

description: in an ideal world, each day would start out w/ soft-crunchilous quarter baguette et sweet butter, wondrous smoked salmon benedict et side spring salad delicately tossed in a lemony vinagrette -- all accompanied by perfectly brewed coffee et the folky smoothness of sir david matthews et his band warming you up on an otherwise all too familiar et too common grey san francisco morning. in an even better world, you crumple in a pool of warm hazlenut crumble. experience w/ the most special of special loved ones.
author: Pax, Formerly Known As Rufus D.

description: Short, sweet, and simple, this place.  Although simple, the food is sexy and sophisticated.  For contructive criticism, my asparagus wasn't bright green... but other than that, I could see myself as a regular here for a casual lunch or dinner.  Anything with truffles on this menu is a delight.
author: Violet B.

description: I'm frequently on Fillmore and have been wanting to try this restaurant out for awhile.   This weekend provided such an occasion since I was entertaining a friend from out of town and giving her a taste of No Cal living.  I like the interior of the place, and it's much roomier than many of the bistros that I've been to around town.  Although, our table was just close enough to the next that I could hear the man bitching about the size of the burger.  Or the lack of size.  And that for the price he was going to have to go somewhere else afterwards to eat something else.  He didn't really look like he was going to be malnourished anytime soon, perhaps next year and he was getting quite obnoxious.  The wait staff didn't seem to care all that much.  My friend had ordered the Niman Ranch burger, and she was quite pleased with it.  Perfect dimension that didn't weigh her down too much.  I ordered the salmon with salad, and it was perfect.  More salmon than I could handle and the toasted bread and cream cheese hit the spot.  However, I didn't really care for the dressing on the greens...but I would let that slide.  Definitely worthy of a return to try something else....like brunch.
author: Amy Z.

description: On my continueing quest to try every breakfast place in the city, today I tried Chouquet's. The place is super cute, right on Fillmore close to all the shops and c afes. The wait staff is excellent, very friendly and attentive. We got there around noon on a Sunday and were seated right away. The menu is not that extensive but it has a good selection of omelets. No bacon anywhere on the menu though. I love bacon. But that's another story. The boyfriend had an omelet with gruyere, ham and mushrooms and I had the omelet with tomatoes, spinach and mushrooms. My omelet was fantastic, I was particularly impressed with the fact that each component was cooked perfectly and the egg part was also done perfectly, neither too runny nor too firm. They also serve potatoes and an exceptionally delicious salad with their egg dishes. This is a great place to take parents or meet with friends for a nice but casual Sunday brunch. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Cathy T.

description: I'd stick to traditional french brunch items here. but they do them really well! had a homemade croissant which was *excellent*. this was actually what made me go in there in the first place. if you write homemade croissant on your store sign, i will come in. no questions asked. shared a croque madame, which is a croque monsieur with an egg on it. very simple, but oh so good. i also enjoyed my $5 grapefruit juice.
author: B H.

description: This place REALLY went downhill.  While I was a regular for a while, the service is now so atrocious that I refuse to return, even though it is super convenient and has a pretty interior.  I had a terrible soup recently, which was not a huge problem, except that I wanted to send it back.  I explained to the waitress that I didn't care if I had to pay for it, I just didn't want it.  She was totally peeved and gave me the evil eye the rest of the meal, in addition to dragging her feet to bring us the check, etc.  Lovely..... there are too many great restaurants in the city than to waste your time here!
author: Caroline B.

description:
Dine About Town 2008, we ordered:
First Course
Crispy rolls of Baramundi with a ginger & coriander infusion  -- good but not special
Butter lettuce salad with a balsamic vinaigrette -- huge  leaves, fresh and sweet, good and a litte special, but not much for a salad though, large enough portion for me.
Second Course
7-hour braised shoulder of lamb with truffled mashed potatoes -- very tender, meat is cooked just right, some lamb flavor but not too strong.
Ahi Tuna Carpaccio with shoe string potatoes and mizuna salad -- very good, light, a little sour 
Third Course
Chocolate Fondant -- warm liquid chocolate inside a small chocolate cake, taste chocolate and not too sweet
Apple Tarte Tatin -- applesauce, soft, medium sweet and Yum!  very different from what i had before.
VERY good overall, however, service was slow, the waiter forgot our water and didn't give us bread while we were waiting for our friend.
author: Charlotte C.

description: Delicious food everytime...lunch, brunch, dinner. It's a neighborhood gem and they are so friendly whenever I come in. The food is yummy and it is very comfy inside.
author: Pam C.

description:
